business.start.para: Mr SPEAKER (Mr Neil Andrew) took the chair at 9.30 a.m., and read prayers.

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 4 April, on motion by Mr Anthony:

motion.para: That the bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: —in reply—In the past, Australian courts have complained about the inconsistent jurisdiction provisions in the child support legislation in Australia and New Zealand. There have been cases where individuals have been issued with both Australian and New Zealand assessments. In other cases, payers in New Zealand have obtained New Zealand assessments for the purpose of extinguishing arrears owed under Australian maintenance orders. The agreement will put an end to the conflicts over jurisdiction. It will also provide for the recognition and enforcement of existing liabilities.

speech.para: Turning to the Hague Convention on the Recognition and Enforcement of Decisions Relating to Maintenance Obligations, for practical purposes Australia's accession to the Hague convention would have the same effect as establishing many bilateral reciprocal arrangements. The Hague convention obliges authorities in the convention countries to recognise and enforce maintenance decisions made by the judicial or administrative authorities in convention countries. It applies to both spousal maintenance and child support obligations. Australia's existing international arrangements for the enforcement of the child support and spousal maintenance liabilities are of limited value to the recipients of payments as they are largely dependent on slow and cumbersome procedures for the initiation and pursuit of proceedings in foreign courts.

The Hague convention provides for the relatively simple and speedy enforcement of existing Australian liabilities by overseas courts and administrative authorities. Like the New Zealand agreement, the Hague convention provides for the recognition of administrative assessments, rather than just court orders or court registered agreements. The Attorney-General's Department and the Child Support Agency have already been meeting the costs of enforcing overseas maintenance decisions in Australia and of obtaining support for Australian payees in foreign countries. Accession to the convention would have a number of savings implications for agencies currently involved in overseas maintenance enforcement.

Australia already has child support enforcement arrangements with many states within the United States. There are no formal agreements. Legislation and procedures vary from state to state, leading to complex and time consuming dealings. The US Congress recently passed legislation putting international child support enforcement in the United States on a federal rather than a state basis. The US State Department has proposed that the Australian government sign a new agreement with the US federal government which would put the existing arrangements on a federal level. The United States agreement provides for the recognition and enforcement of administrative assessments of child support. By entering into federal arrangements, the existing complex and time consuming state based legislation and procedures will be replaced by a coordinated approach.

The Child Support Legislation Amendment Bill 2000 provides for real improvements to the international child support arrangements. I am particularly pleased that the opposition have agreed to support this bill. It was a little disappointing that the member for Grayndler raised unsubstantiated concerns that child support payers and payees would be adversely affected by the introduction of the new tax system. Australians with dependent children, including both child support payers and payees, will indeed benefit from tax reform. With tax cuts included in the government's tax reform package, effective marginal tax rates for custodial and non-custodial parents will reduce. This will mean that a large number of child support payers will get more income than is currently the case.

Sole parents and other social security recipients will also benefit from tax reform, including increases to the pension free area, a four per cent increase in the rate of payments from 1 July and a reduction in the taper rate from 50 per cent to 40 per cent. For eligible families, the new FTB will mean an increase in the maximum amount of assistance by $140 a year for each dependent child. On top of this, single income families with children under five will also receive an increase of $350 a year or, where the youngest child is over five years, they will receive an additional $61 a year.

This bill supports the recommendations of the Joint Select Committee on Certain Family Law Issues. The measures contained in this bill are positive. It is appropriate for Australia to enter into international agreements for the reciprocal recognition and enforcement of child support liabilities. Once again, I thank all members from both sides of the House for their contributions to the debate, and I commend the bill to the House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

subdebate.1.para: Leave granted for third reading to be moved forthwith.
Bill (on motion by Mr Anthony) read a third time.
Debate resumed from 8 March, on motion by Mr Anderson:

motion.para: That the bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: —At the outset I indicate to the House that the opposition supports the passage of this bill, the Aviation Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) 2000, with a very serious proviso in relation to the aspects that change foreign ownership laws. I also indicate that it is my intention to move a second reading amendment going to some serious issues which we believe the government should pursue in effecting the implementation of the bill if it passes as proposed. I also indicate that I have no opposition to that amendment being circulated at this stage. The proviso goes, as reflected in the second reading amendment I will move, to issuing a strong recommendation to the government to consider certain matters that fundamentally relate to Australian jobs and services in regional and rural Australia. I will come to those matters in more detail when I address that amendment.

speech.para: It is also fair to say that the bill contains two schedules: one going to the foreign ownership issue, the other going to the operation of Sydney airport. Schedule 1 contains the proposed changes to liberalise the foreign ownership restrictions of Australian airlines. It also contains other minor technical amendments to the Air Navigation Act 1920. I will return to address that schedule at length. Schedule 2 of the bill increases some of the penalties for breaching curfew legislation at Sydney airport. These amendments correctly increase fivefold the maximum penalty for taking off or landing at Sydney airport in breach of the curfew in the Sydney Airport Curfew Act 1995. The effect of these amendments is to increase the penalty for an individual operator from 200 penalty units to 1,000 penalty units. For a company, the increase is from 1,000 to 5,000 penalty units. In dollar terms I suppose this is the crux of the amendments. The new maximum penalty for an individual operating an aircraft in breach of the curfew will be $110,000 and $550,000 for a company. In a lot of ways it is a shame that we actually have to talk about such huge increases in penalties, but it comes back to a failure of some operators to adhere to the intent of existing endeavours by this parliament to exercise a curfew. Because of those inadequacies we are required to increase the penalties to try to effect a greater capacity for those operators to adhere to the curfew.

The amendments in items 3 and 4 of schedule 2 will apply new maximum penalties for taking off between 10.45 p.m. and 11 p.m. from a runway not permitted by the act. These new maxima in section 10 of the act also represent a fivefold increase. They will now be $55,000 for an individual and $275,000 for a company. It is also interesting to note that the maximum penalty for breaching some other restrictions imposed by the act has not been changed. I draw that to the minister's attention: namely, the failure of the bill to increase the penalties in section 11. That section imposes a penalty for taking off or landing on a runway not permitted by the act between 6 a.m. and 7 a.m. or between 10 p.m. and 11 p.m. on a Saturday or a Sunday. Whilst the penalties for that section are the same as the existing section 10, the government for some reason has not seen fit to increase these penalties. Other penalties have not changed, such as those for failing to lodge notices for landing noisy aircraft during the curfew and providing false or misleading information. I think it would be appropriate in the minister's response at the conclusion of this debate for him to explain these apparent anomalies, as they raise some serious questions conveyed to me by constituents living in the immediate vicinity of Mascot airport.

Whilst the minister is on his feet explaining this apparent oversight in his policy change, I also invite him to discuss the situation at Adelaide airport. As the House would recall, during the last session of this House we passed the private member's bill in the name of the member for Hindmarsh going to the question of a curfew at Adelaide airport. As a result of discussions between the member for Hindmarsh and the Labor opposition, agreement was reached on that bill, on the basis of which it was passed with the support of both sides of the House. I therefore draw the House's attention to the final reading of that bill, in which the member for Hindmarsh, despite my best endeavours in a bipartisan way, declined my offer to take forward the cause of people in the immediate vicinity of Adelaide airport. In a proper and constructive way, we had clearly come to terms with a curfew—which was received with great support by constituents in the member for Hindmarsh's electorate.

I then also rightly requested that the member for Hindmarsh join with me to try and legislate for the provision of insulation for houses and public buildings affected by noise in the same way as Sydney residents. I took the view that the curfew, as was the intent of the Adelaide curfew bill, only went part of the way and that if it was good enough for the residents of Sydney to have some noise abatement policies in place then we as a community should give the same opportunity to those living in the immediate vicinity of Adelaide airport. I cannot for the life of me understand why it is good enough for Sydney—almost as though we have a Sydney-centric government—but not good enough for the residents of Adelaide. That reminds me of the difficulties confronted by the coalition recently in Victoria, where rural and regional Victoria very much came to the conclusion that the coalition was Melbourne-centric. Perhaps on this occasion we have a Commonwealth government that is Sydney-centric when it comes to trying to look after the issue of noise abatement for people living around airports. I therefore call on the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Transport and Regional Services to not only explain the apparent anomalies with respect to the penalties for breach of the curfew at Sydney airport but to also bite the bullet and clearly prove that he is not Sydney-centric when it comes to issues of noise abatement and the difficulties encountered by people living in the immediate vicinity of airports.

I believe that in his response today he should also declare a commitment to join with the opposition and, hopefully, the member for Hindmarsh, who has given the green light. I understand from reports out of coalition meetings that at the moment there is very much an endeavour to put the muzzle on people with respect to a range of issues, including, unfortunately, the issue of mandatory imprisonment in the Northern Territory—yes, mandatory imprisonment, not mandatory sentencing. Despite that, I think on this occasion the coalition ought to at least front up to its responsibilities and basically say that it is prepared to join with the Labor opposition in a bipartisan way and try to overcome or address the anomalous situation which relates to the lack of support for those experiencing noise difficulties at Adelaide airport. As I have said, if it is good enough for Sydney, I believe it ought to be good enough for the residents of Adelaide.

An early indication of how much support the minister has for the new curfew at Adelaide airport does cause me some concern. While on his feet he should elaborate as to why he has not come to the party with respect to such noise abatement programs in Adelaide. I also refer to some immediate difficulties relating to the application of the new Adelaide Airport Curfew Bill. I am referring to a press report from the Adelaide Sunday Mail of 26 March this year. That article reported that the curfew was broken to assist Ansett—which is an organisation potentially to benefit from the bill before the House today—to juggle its schedules because of a stop-work meeting. To be honest with the House, I would not have thought that the relaxation of the curfew at Adelaide airport on this occasion fitted the criteria for emergencies agreed to by the House. If the minister could perhaps address this issue, we could all gain a better understanding as to why he—or the person he delegated responsibility to on this occasion—gave the exemption. I would very strongly argue that the exemption given with respect to the operation of Ansett in recent weeks was not an intended exemption in the terms in which the House approved the Adelaide Airport Curfew Bill.

In conclusion, with respect to schedule 2, I reiterate the opposition's support for these changes, albeit incomplete as they seem. That is not for me to tidy up. It is the government's responsibility. I also appreciate that there is some evidence provided to the courts that some airlines—and I stress that this is probably a few—have ignored, or may in the future see fit to ignore, the curfew as a cheaper option than delaying a take-off or arrival. It is unfortunate that some people lack such a commitment and consideration to residents that the House is now required to increase the fines relating to the application and implementation of the bill going to the curfew at Sydney airport. It is for those reasons that, because of a few, the Labor opposition stands in support of the increase in the penalties outlined and detailed in the bill before the House today.

I will now go to schedule 1, which is perhaps that part of the schedule which has attracted most attention, especially in the airline industry and, I might also say, in the media. The intent of this bill is basically to liberalise the foreign ownership rules for Australian airlines. The nub of the opposition's support for this bill is a conviction that Australian companies can and should be able to operate on the international stage and that competition can enhance the welfare and services to our community and economy. I also stress in making that commitment and statement at the outset that it is also important that, in dealing with this issue, we properly focus on an endeavour to ensure that airlines operating in Australia are sufficiently strong enough sellers to ensure that they have a capacity to continue to deliver a service of excellence to rural and regional Australia. That issue has weighed heavily in the minds of the opposition in considering how we should best handle the bill currently before the House.

The last thing we would want is the major operator in Australia hamstrung because of a lack of capital injection, which in the end could undermine their capacity to properly service rural and regional Australia. It is about ensuring that we have an airline policy in Australia that is not city-centric. It is about ensuring that we have airlines in Australia that are capable of obviously servicing major capital cities and our international commitments but also guaranteeing that in making those commitments, both domestically and internationally, they make the same commitment to rural and regional Australia. I therefore am of the firm understanding and belief that Australian companies can provide that competition. Our community can gain the greatest benefit from it if they are given the latitude to operate with the same advantages as their competitors. More and more, their competitors are operating in the international regime.

We have got to make sure that Australian airline operators that have historically been associated with us as a nation have a capacity to operate not only domestically but also internationally—because, as far as I am concerned, in this day and age you cannot separate those requirements. You cannot operate on the basis that we can maintain and prop up an operator which is basically domestically orientated. More and more, the number of operators internationally is declining. We are having a smaller number of huge operators with a capacity to service both domestic economies and international economies.

The amendments therefore seek to remove some of the current restrictions on foreign airline ownership and control of Australian international airlines other than Qantas. At present, the Air Navigation Act of 1920 limits ownership of shares in an Australian international airline to no more than 20 per cent for an individual foreign airline and no more than 35 per cent in total for all foreign airlines. The amendments clearly intend to remove these restrictions and replace them with a requirement that foreign persons can own no more than 49 per cent of an Australian international airline. This makes that provision more general and removes the distinction between restrictions on airlines and persons. It makes the provisions with respect to definitions consistent with the Qantas act.

I also note in passing, for the record, that these amendments do not apply to the restrictions on the level of foreign ownership of Qantas. Those restrictions are contained in a separate act, the Qantas Sale Act of 1992. There are no amendments to that act before the House this morning. I would also say that it is naive for us to think, and we would indeed be dishonest to attempt to infer, that these amendments have absolutely no bearing on Qantas.

As has been borne out in recent media reports, British Airways has a keen interest in the passage of these amendments. That foreign airline has made no secret of its desire to acquire a larger portion of Qantas. That decision is obviously not before the House today; that debate will occur should amendments to that act be put forward by the government. I personally have no doubt that the arguments put forward in relation to these changes to the Navigation Act will however be run against any future consideration of Qantas in the separate Qantas Sale Act 1992. The government has judged that it is not the time to consider such a change at the moment, and I agree with it on this occasion.

There has been, as we are all aware, a lot of focus on the recent negotiations between Air New Zealand and News Corporation on the sale of News Corporation's share in Ansett domestic. This would give Air New Zealand 100 per cent ownership and control of Ansett domestic. As Ansett domestic owns 49 per cent of Ansett International, an Australian international airline for the purposes of air service agreements, the amendments before the House are important for that deal. Soon after the announcement of that proposal, the public became aware of negotiations between Qantas and Air New Zealand—or at least their significant shareholder, Brierleys—and, simultaneously, new talks between Ansett and Singapore Airlines seeking to finalise long-term ownership arrangements. The latest seems to be a suspension of the talks between Qantas and Brierleys and an expectation that the announced deal between Air New Zealand and Ansett will be implemented.

The Labor opposition carries no candle for any of the proposed mergers. That is an issue to be determined by the Foreign Investment Review Board and the respective commercial interests. Our responsibility is to make sure that we have a legislative framework in Australia which guarantees all Australians, both regional and metropolitan based, the best possible service both domestically and internationally. However, the strong message for the last three weeks in airline politics is that it is a dynamic, vibrant, ever changing industry. It is also a crucial time in the history of Australian aviation. Decisions made today and through the passage of this bill cannot be, and are not, about one possible scenario. Before us is a bill that at some stage is highly likely to impact on Ansett. But we must not view it only through the Ansett window. In considering our support for the bill, the opposition considered the bill in a far broader context. In fact, there are 12 airlines that have, at one time or other, been designated and have received allocations from the International Air Services Commission. These airlines are: Ansett International, Ansett Australia Ltd, Asian Express, Australia Air, Flight West, National Airlines, National Jet, Pel Air, Qantas, Qwestair, Transair and Transpac. It is not an Ansett-centric bill; it ranges across the industry at large. Each of these airlines—with the exception of Qantas for previously stated reasons, and National Jet because it is no longer an Australian company—would be beneficiaries under the new provisions of the act. Not all of these airlines are currently operating, but it shows the potential broader application of what is before the House this morning. The limits on foreign ownership and control in the Navigation Act 1920 are derived from provisions in the bilateral air service arrangements. Those provisions allow either country party to the air service arrangements to refuse entry of the airlines of the other country into their market on the grounds that they are not substantially owned and effectively controlled by nationals of that country party.

The Productivity Commission inquiry report released in September 1998 provided a focus for considering and reassessing progress on Australia's approach to international air services. When the government announced its response to that report, the opposition welcomed the government's decision to reject the more extreme elements of the report. The opposition supported the choice of incremental liberalisation rather than the unilateral and unfettered liberalisation favoured by some. My colleague the then shadow minister, the member for Dickson, was right when she said that there is no sense giving away rights without getting something in return.

The changes before the House are part of an incremental approach to liberalisation of international air services. They liberalise ownership and investment arrangements whilst clearly staying within the bilateral air service arrangements. They build on the long and strong history of aviation reform by, I would contend, the previous Labor government. However, the challenge to any government at this time was always going to be how to keep the momentum of change while still delivering a benefit to the Australian community and Australian exporters, including tourism interests, airfreight users and Australian international airlines. Ownership and control provisions are a universal feature of an internationally applied framework of bilateral treaties. That is to ensure that they are not disadvantaged by overexposure and therefore disadvantaged by controls imposed by other countries on Australian airlines and persons that retain minimum restrictions. The changes as put before us in these amendments would assist in airlines' alliance plans, allow better access to capital markets and ensure Australia retains a healthy presence in the international market. At the same time, they send a message that Australia is continuing to reform and is not a closed country. My colleagues on this side share a view that our community is best served by competition, but in a sensible manner, ensuring that we all share in the benefits. We should not argue against foreign ownership per se; we should put an emphasis on what will help our community grow, create jobs and ensure we retain and improve services to all locations in our country.

And that brings me to our amendment to this second reading motion. The amendment suggests that, should the changes to the foreign ownership provisions in the Navigation Act 1920 proceed—as we very strongly support them doing—it is still up to the government to consider the national interest implications of each application for foreign purchase of Australian airlines. The government's foreign investment sectoral guidelines, that are applied through the Foreign Investment Review Board, will also be changed to reflect changes in this bill. Under those sectoral guidelines, the Foreign Investment Review Board presently can only permit approval, provided it is consistent with the national interest, of acquisition of up to: 25 per cent of an Australian domestic or international airline by an individual foreign airline flying to Australia; 40 per cent in aggregate of an Australian domestic airline by foreign airlines; and 35 per cent in aggregate of an Australian international airline by foreign airlines.

Other foreign investors, including foreign airlines who do not fly to Australia, can acquire up to 100 per cent of an Australian domestic airline. Although the government has been prepared to consider proposals in excess of these standards for domestic airlines in special circumstances, there is no similar exception for international airlines. So, to take advantage of changes arising from the bill before this House, the sectoral guidelines will also need to be changed.

The Foreign Investment Review Board is also, as I said, required to take account of the national interest. It is in that area that the government, through the Foreign Investment Review Board, has latitude to examine closely the plans and intentions of particular proposed amendments. The amendment I put forward relates to the proposed investment by Air New Zealand to take over Ansett. There exist legitimate and expected concerns from the employees and their representatives that the deal will not deliver on the expectations of our community.

As I said before, the opposition support globalisation of markets and opening our organisations to foreign ownership, provided there are benefits and provided those benefits are shared and enhance our community. These are very strong requirements from the Labor opposition's point of view and is the basis of the fundamental approach that we have taken in consideration of the bill before the House today.

I will turn now to the genuine fears of our community and the issue is whether or not they will come to be realised. They are as follows. Firstly, there is a concern that Air New Zealand is undercapitalised and that jobs will be cut to provide the injection of funds. Secondly, the Australian Services Union fears a loss of 2,000 positions in administration, information technology, engineering and maintenance, and reservations. Thirdly, there is also concern about loss of skills and expertise from Australia and that jobs will be transported to the purported lower wage market in New Zealand. Fourthly, the regional focus of Ansett and its subsidiaries Kendall, Aeropelican and Skywest must also be maintained for passenger and trade access to and from regional communities. Fifthly, and finally, there is also an issue of which badged airline—for example, Air New Zealand or Ansett International—will receive which share of future growth in international business. Obviously, the fear is that the growth will be through Air New Zealand and that Ansett will not receive its fair share with a flow-on to jobs and security.

While it has principally been Ansett employees and their union officials who have raised and campaigned around these issues, they are echoes of the broader community and many other competitive industries. The concerns fundamentally are jobs, skills, security, growth and access. In considering the fears of the Ansett employees, their families and their representatives, the government must also consider these fears with empathy in the same terms as other industries.

In considering the decision of the potentially effective takeover of Ansett by Air New Zealand, the Foreign Investment Review Board and the government must obtain commitments from Air New Zealand to address these concerns. Through this amendment we are calling on the government to pursue assurances from Air New Zealand that ensure that the benefits of the liberalisation of ownership and opening up of this airline will be shared. We are seeking to ensure that: (1) Ansett remains headquartered in Australia; (2) that a fair share of future growth in Air New Zealand's international routes be through Ansett International; (3) that high skilled, high value Ansett jobs remain in Australia; and (4) and (5) the retention of jobs, services and growth in services in regional and rural communities.

These points, as laid out in the second reading amendment that I will move at the conclusion of my contribution to this debate, are about ensuring that already locationally disadvantaged communities do not pay the price of cheaper fares on popular routes. My colleague the member for Bass will speak on these amendments and address the issues for her electorate and, in particular, the large call centre at Launceston. I also note in passing that, as a result of the recent discussions I have had with Ansett, they have reaffirmed their commitment to a call centre in Canberra. It is now the responsibility of the ACT Legislative Assembly to ensure that commitment is delivered as a matter of urgency. Other speakers on our side will also comment on the assurances we seek from the government.

In conclusion, the opposition will not decline to give this bill a second reading. There have been discussions between the opposition and the government on the nature of the second reading amendment. It is fair to say that it is only for technical reasons that the government will not be able to vote on the opposition's second reading amendment on this occasion. I welcome and accept the constructive nature with which the government has entered into those discussions with the Labor opposition on this occasion.

In relation to the announced deal between News Ltd and Air New Zealand, we are urging them in the strongest terms—it is a very strong call from the employees of Ansett, their families and the community at large—that those involved in these discussions exercise the powers they have in the process to ensure that Ansett Australia remains headquartered in Australia. That is important not only to Australia but also especially to the state of Victoria and Melbourne. Secondly, we are urging that a fair share of the future growth in Air New Zealand's international routes be through Ansett International. Ansett International wants not only to provide a quality service in Australia but also to grow internationally and, in doing so, create more employment opportunities internationally. That takes me to the third issue. We want to make sure that that delivers high skilled, high value Ansett jobs in Australia. Fourthly, Ansett jobs must be in regional and rural communities and they should not be jeopardised by the sale. Finally, services to regional and rural communities must be preserved at current levels or improved. I move:

motion.para: That all words after “That” be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

“this House, whilst supportive of the amendment to adjust foreign ownership rules under the Air Navigation Act 1920, and whilst not declining to give the bill a second reading, considers that in examining a proposal for the sale of shares in Ansett to foreign interests, the Government should take into consideration the view that:
(1) Ansett Australia should remain headquartered in Australia;
(2) a fair share of future growth in routes should be through Ansett International;
(3) high skilled, high value Ansett airlines jobs should remain in Australia;
(4) Ansett jobs in regional and rural communities not be jeopardised by the sale; and
(5) services to regional and rural communities should be preserved at current levels, or improved”.

talk.start.para: (Mr Jenkins)—Order! Is the amendment seconded?
—I second the amendment and reserve my right to speak.

—I rise today in support of the government's Aviation Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) 2000 and note with interest the comments of the member for Batman. I listened with interest to his speech and I agree with much of what he expressed. I will go through some of those comments on a seriatim basis. He spoke at some length regarding Adelaide Airport and the curfew and the need for noise insulation. I would say that Labor had plenty of opportunities when they were in government to make such a change but failed to do so. In relation to compensation and the question of noise insulation and the question also of whether the government is Sydney-centric, it is really a simple matter of where the majority of flights are. More than 50 per cent of the total take-offs and landings in the entire country are based on Sydney. That does not mean that we should ignore the problems that exist in other airports, but that is the simple reality.

speech.para: If we move to the other aspects of this legislation, I think it does bring us into a contemporary world, a world in which there is increasing globalisation, particularly as it relates to international air services. We have had the development of oneworld, in which one of the lead proponents is Qantas, along with British Airways and the other carriers which are part of that agreement. It was interesting to see Cathay Pacific actually became part of that agreement recently. There is also Star Alliance, in which Ansett and other operators such as Thai, Lufthansa, SAS and United Airlines, which is the biggest airline in the world, are involved. It is a very strong alliance. This context of increasing globalisation puts increasing pressure on Australian operators to be competitive. There are important aspects of it. There are moves to greater liberalisation of our air agreements in terms of open skies as they relate to airports other than Sydney, Melbourne, Brisbane and Perth and also questions of restrictions of flights in the curfew period.

This bill is in part in response to the Productivity Commission's 1998 report on its inquiry into the International Air Services Commission. Australia's aviation policy is now a liberalised aviation sector with regard to ownership and control, capacity, frequency and destination of flights. The government's international aviation policy focuses on reciprocal bilateral open skies arrangements with other countries. I believe that it is appropriate that we simply do not open up all of our ports on a totally open skies basis without reciprocal arrangements being provided by other countries. There are some countries where there are still difficulties in negotiating these arrangements. But the arrangements as proposed in the bill permit unrestricted access by foreign aircraft to all airports except, as I mentioned, Sydney, Melbourne, Brisbane and Perth and give foreign international airlines operating in regional Australia unlimited capacity, code share and owned stopover rights. These arrangements have been negotiated with a number of countries. But, by preventing access by private foreign aircraft to domestic routes, the government has ensured that foreign airlines cannot take jobs from country Australians.

The other aspect of policy changes relates to market share. The bill implements the government's decision to liberalise the foreign ownership of Australian international airlines, except Qantas. Australia has four airlines that would benefit from the bill—Ansett International, Flight West, Asian Express cargo and Transpac cargo. Under current foreign ownership rules in Australia no more than 35 per cent of an airline can be foreign owned and no single airline can own more than 35 per cent. This bill would allow for no more than 49 per cent foreign ownership and for no restriction within that 49 per cent cap.

In Cheryl Kernot's press release of June 1999, as the then shadow minister for regional development, infrastructure, transport and regional services, she described this liberalisation as a `reasonable outcome and one that goes down the sensible path of incremental liberalisation, rather than the unilateral and unfettered liberalisation favoured by some'. This bill would make it easier for Australian international carriers to obtain capital and negotiate an alliance. International aviation is expensive and risky, and airlines need as much flexibility as possible to obtain capital. The alternative is that Australian airlines would gradually become undercapitalised, lose market share and be unable to compete with well-funded foreign carriers. We see this as a great benefit to tourism.

It is important to recognise that today we have in this parliament the annual general meeting of the Inbound Tourism Operators Association of Australia. They are visiting Parliament House today. There is a lot of focus on this. There are a lot of calls within the tourism industry for greater liberalisation, more open skies—and of course there is a balance in getting liberalisation and greater foreign ownership and at the same time protecting Australian jobs and protecting the long-term future and viability of the Australian aviation industry. There is no doubt that competition brings down costs and enables more options to be developed for incoming tourists. The cheaper our fares, the more global and competitive our environment, the more tourists we are going to have visit us, if common economic principles work in terms of elasticity of demand.

This is something the government has sought to respect in its consideration and action in relation to the Productivity Commission inquiry into our air access arrangements. The recent announcement by the government which simply allows greater liberalisation to regional airports other than the main east coast airports is an especially good thing and is welcomed by the tourism industry. Freight has now been completely liberalised. This opens up all sorts of possibilities for those who want to develop freight operations at airports around the country and, of course, the opportunity to maximise the export of fresh fruit and vegetables and other commodities into particularly the Asian market but also into Europe and the USA.

At a regular meeting of the Friends of Tourism that was held yesterday a deregulated, liberalised industry was a key issue in a speech given by Tony Stuart of Sydney Airport Corporation. In the words of Mr Stuart:

quote.para: ... the tourism industry must ensure that all foreign carriers who wish to access Australia can do so provided that Australian carriers have some form of reciprocal benefit.

speech.para: The first cab off the rank was the United Arab Emirates, which have now accessed considerably more liberal arrangements in time for the Olympic Games. Last week they started their services to Sydney, and they will be flying to Sydney four times a week.

There are increased penalties for breaching the Sydney airport curfew. I noted the comments of the member for Batman on this and I, of course, have a strong interest in this whole issue on two fronts. First, more airline employees, according to the airlines, live in my electorate than in any other electorate in Australia and, second, my electorate experiences more aircraft noise than any other electorate in Australia, with 55 per cent of all take-offs and landings occurring over my electorate. So there is considerable interest in these particular provisions. They are about increasing the penalties that apply to those who continually break the curfew, or who break it at all. This is good news for the people of Kurnell, Bundeena and Cronulla.

While the movements of the air ambulance services are unrestricted and freight planes that are propeller driven are allowed to fly over the bay at all hours, there is no question of there being a strong need to restrict the activities of passenger carriers and stop them from breaking the law. On 28 February last year a Thai Airlines flight took off at 1 o'clock in the morning and at 1.45 a.m. over Kurnell it woke everybody up. I was told about this in no uncertain terms by the people of Kurnell. They rang me and said, `What is going on with the curfew situation when you have aircraft constantly breaking the curfew?' That is in fact happening because I actually overlook the airport from my apartment in Cronulla and I do see aircraft taking off at various times. If there is a special reason, such as a mechanical delay or difficulties in getting accommodation in peak times for people, on some occasions the appropriate authorities do give approval for these take-offs to take place. On this occasion the aircraft took off without receiving the necessary approvals and the result was considerable discomfort and annoyance for the community of Kurnell.

This flagrant breach of the curfew requirements cannot be tolerated. They simply calculate whether it is worth paying the penalties as opposed to having the aircraft sit overnight and providing accommodation for the passengers in Sydney hotels and motels, and the result is that airlines often make the decision that it is worth taking off. These amendments increase the penalties so significantly that it certainly does not provide them with any economic incentive to do that. The proposed amendments will increase the maximum fines by a factor of five. The maximum fine for operating an aircraft during the curfew period will now be $110,000 for an individual or $550,000 for a company. The maximum penalties in section 10 for taking off between 10.45 p.m. and 11.00 p.m. using a runway which is not permitted by the statute are also increased fivefold. I think that is very good news for not only my electorate but also the other electorates that surround the airport and the members who represent those electorates, such as the member for Grayndler and so on. So we welcome the changes that are included in this proposal.

There is much in the sentiment of the amendment sought by the member for Batman, in seeking to ensure the long-term future of Ansett in Australia, that can be applauded. Obviously there are questions about the way he has drafted his amendment. He talks about a fair share of future growth in routes through Ansett International, but he does not indicate how that fair share is to be determined. That is left on a fairly vague basis. It is true that the government intends to grow Ansett International in the future—that is the distinct plan the government has to encourage growth—but holding Ansett to the other aspects would create certain difficulties for their long-term future. Certainly I would be sympathetic to the sentiments outlined by the member for Batman, and obviously that matter needs to be worked through with the government.

I was part of the transport committee that was briefed by the senior management of Ansett, as well as by the senior management of Air New Zealand, and there were absolute assurances about the long-term future of Ansett operating domestically in Australia and about Ansett International in its operations on a global basis and that the two airlines would continue to remain separate entities. The provisions of part 3, which state that high skilled, high value Ansett airline jobs should remain in Australia, is really to put them in a straitjacket. I, for one, have been watching some of the developments with Qantas as they have moved some of their jobs offshore. I see that they have recruited Thai flight attendants and that some of their servicing of aircraft and maintenance work is being carried out in Asia. Those provisions provide a straitjacket in terms of a company that is trying to respond to international pressures and demands. I think that really needs to be thought through, even though the sentiments outlined by the member for Batman are important. As I mentioned before, as somebody who represents an area which has a high number of airline employees living within it, I am sensitive about trying to maximise the number of jobs that we have in Australia and of course the number of high skilled jobs.

I also point to the outstanding record in Australian aviation history of both Ansett and Qantas. It is therefore disappointing to note the attacks in recent days on the CEO of Qantas, James Strong. I refer particularly to the Miranda Devine article. She is a journalist that I agree with in the majority of cases, and she writes some excellent articles, but on the recent occasion when she wrote an opinion piece `Airline chief veers offcourse' I believe the attacks on James Strong were unwarranted. His track record has been quite outstanding. Under James Strong, Qantas has implemented a dramatic change in the culture of the airline from a government operation to a successful commercial business. He has guided change in the international relations climate from confrontation to a constructive partnership. He has achieved increased levels of efficiency and productivity while growing the size of the business and the number of job opportunities and has posted record profits each year since the business was listed on the Australian Stock Exchange in mid-1995, even though the Asian economic downturn occurred during this period.

Under James Strong, the airline has maintained a strong focus on air safety. Only on Monday, a report of the Joint Committee on Treaties was tabled in this place recommending—with the approval of Qantas and Ansett—that liability of the airlines be unlimited and set by the courts in line with the damage done and not limited to protect members of the industry. This speaks volumes about the organisation's confidence in safety and its sense of corporate responsibility. So the idea of chasing the jumbo and questioning whether it was in China or not—and I notice there was some egg on the face of the Herald reporter who chased the aircraft and announced to the world that they had found the Qantas jumbo only to find they had the wrong aircraft type; it was in fact a Cathay Pacific plane—is embarrassing. Instead of trying to cut down our tall poppies, it is time that we supported people like James Strong. He has done an outstanding job in lifting the viability of the business, expanding the route network, improving the business's profitability and improving the price of its shares—in terms of its shareholders, for one thing, and in terms of its international reputation. To focus on the incident in Bangkok, which undoubtedly was unfortunate, at the expense of his great track record at Qantas is not in the spirit of what we would want in this country.

As far as these amendments are concerned, I am glad to see the bipartisan approach that has come into the debate today from the member for Batman—recognising that it is important that we have an increasing globalisation of the aviation sector and recognising that it is appropriate that we also have foreign ownership in our airlines where it is to the benefit of the Australian community, to the viability of the airline and does not disadvantage local employees. That is what we saw in the previous government's proposals for the privatisation of Qantas. British Airways bought a substantial share in Qantas, and that has proved to be important to the overall competitive position of Qantas. There is no doubt that we would not be enjoying the type of competitive position we have now if it had not been for the special global alliance that occurs with British Airways. It results in cost cutting, code sharing and the sharing of sales activity and maintenance agreements. The residents of Australia are the beneficiaries of lowered costs, lowered fares and an increasingly globalised position. The ability with which Qantas is now able to offer services to Buenos Aires and to ports such as Paris has been brought about through this increased cooperation between the airlines.

Rod Eddington—another very fine chief executive, brought over from Cathay Pacific—has provided a significant turnaround in the fortunes of Ansett. They have now moved into a position of quite strong profitability. They are looking very confident. They are providing a very strong level of service. In order to get that competitive position, the infusion of funds from Air New Zealand will allow them to address many of the issues that have been raised today—providing a strong network of regional services, being competitive and providing a balance to the oneworld alliance of Qantas, British Airways and other members. That is to be applauded. As we work through this together, and I have noted the sentiments that are included in the member for Batman's comments, it is important that we see an honouring of the undertakings given by Ansett and Air New Zealand on continuing the long-term role of Ansett in Australia and ensuring that Australian employees of the airlines see a long-term future. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I am pleased to speak in support of the Aviation Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) 2000 and particularly to support my colleague the honourable member for Batman in the second reading amendment that he has moved, which I note the honourable member for Cook has a great deal of sympathy for, and well might he. The bill seeks to change the foreign ownership rules applying to Ansett. Well might we ask: how did we get ourselves into this position? It does not seem so long ago that, if you looked at the two domestic carriers, you saw that perhaps Ansett was the stronger of the two. The workers of Australia pay a very high price for poor management. One of the pressing problems that Ansett has is a lack of capital. It is certainly not the fault of the pilots, the hostesses, the ground crew or the Transport Workers Union staff that this situation has come into being. I know I risk being labelled yet again very old-fashioned, but I always have a point of regret when I see an Australian brand name, an Australian icon, effectively passing into foreign hands. A country of Australia's size will always require a great deal of foreign investment. But it is also the case that it does need some medium sized—and, hopefully, very large—businesses that are Australian owned, that actually see a commitment to this country as a priority.

speech.para: I am not suggesting that we can turn the clock back in this instance, but I think we ought to note that this really comes about because of a failure of management, not because of an unwillingness of workers to work hard, to commit to the business or to be dedicated. Both sides are supporting this legislation, which will allow a 50 per cent shareholding of Ansett at News Corp and will allow 100 per cent of the domestic operation and 49 per cent of the foreign operation to be owned by Air New Zealand.

I note that the member for Cook said that some of the airline servicing is going to be done in Australia. I often recall a meeting of the Transport and Communications Caucus Committee, as it then was, where Qantas boasted about capitalising on their outstanding reputation—Ansett also has an outstanding reputation, for that matter—on their engineering skills and on their safety record. They said that they saw a real growth industry in Australia, not only in servicing our own airlines from an engineering perspective but in actually attracting other airlines to come and have their servicing done in Australia. It is really a sad state of affairs that that is not happening today and that both airlines are having some of their aircraft serviced overseas. How ridiculous to have the world's safest airline, Qantas, not capitalising on that reputation and not being able to garner a market. Servicing overseas airlines is a big dollar, high skill market in Australia. As I say, Mr Deputy Speaker, you will no doubt feel that I am very old-fashioned in raising these issues, but I really feel very deeply about them.

I would also like to say that I am pleased to see the increased penalties for breaching Sydney's airport curfew. I am very proud to come from Western Sydney. I might say again that that region of Sydney will in 2016 comprise more than 50 per cent of Sydney's population. I stand up here very proud to be a member for Western Sydney, and I say to the House that I think the noise problem generated by Kingsford Smith is horrific. I absolutely welcome anything that we can do to ensure that the law is not broken and that there are hefty penalties. Of course, Mr Deputy Speaker, it is nothing new to you to learn that the big debate in Sydney is about Sydney's second airport.

I want to put on the record that I support the comment of the honourable member for Werriwa in this. He claimed that airport decisions in Sydney, the gateway to Australia, are not being made on a rational basis. I happen to agree with him. Although this problem has been going on year in, year out, and I am told that a decision is imminent, I really think we have the process wrong. I cannot honestly say to the House that a rational decision is about to be made. If anything, I would say that the government is going to announce a decision to be seen to be taking a decision—the very worst circumstance in which any decision can be taken.

But why isn't it rational? I could say a few things. Firstly, I think the thing that turned Western Sydney against the airport was the absolutely rorted EIS into the third runway. I do not think anyone in this House would stand up and say, `This was a triumph of the department of transport and demonstrates how an EIS ought to be run.' It was an absolute cock-up, a stuff-up. In fact, I believe some public servants should have been hung, drawn and quartered and the company conducting it driven out of town. That is what turned public opinion. We are told that the EIS for Western Sydney has been going on for some time. Indeed it has. I also need to say to the House that the then shadow minister for transport, Lindsay Tanner, and Duncan Kerr put out a press release stating quite clearly that they believed that the EIS process was fundamentally flawed and lacking in public confidence. Nothing that changes those circumstances has happened since that joint press release. The more we have gone into Badgerys Creek, the less convinced we are that we need it.

Who in this House can tell us what the capacity of Kingsford Smith airport is? A Robert Gottliebson article in the Australian entitled, `Spending $7bn on Badgerys Creek is plane silly', says that Sydney airport has the capacity for 350,000 air movements, is currently undertaking only 282,000 and therefore has a capacity yield which will make it last for another 25 years. I do not know what the capacity of Kingsford Smith airport is, but I think that before we make a $7 billion decision or a baby $5 billion decision we ought to know. By the way, let me just put on the record the question: how will baby Badgerys go? We have had a public opinion poll conducted by the Western Sydney Alliance just recently. The majority of the respondents, 62 per cent, opposed the big Badgerys concept, whilst 56 per cent of respondents opposed a smaller airport at Badgerys Creek. Public opinion is not in favour of Badgerys and, as Sandra Prout from Minchinbury says, babies have a habit of growing up.

Clearly, that is how that decision would be seen in Western Sydney. I understand to better test public opinion, to further refine the accuracy of polling and to gauge the likely impact of any government decision, the Western Sydney Alliance may be undertaking a poll in marginal seats in Western Sydney. The point that I am making is that the proposals of the Minister for Finance and Administration for baby Badgerys involve shifting aircraft from Kingsford Smith to Bankstown. Should we not have the empirical evidence of what this will do not only to the residents of Bankstown but also to Bankstown airport—what is the capacity of Bankstown airport, what is the commensurate infrastructure that needs to be spent to link up with a fast rail service to Kingsford Smith and will this solve this problem? No-one in this House can stand up and say, `Here is the evidence.'

In this debate about Badgerys a number of alternative sites, not originally considered, have been thrown into the melting pot. Goulburn believes it has a case. Canberra believes it has a case. There is an argument about Williamstown airport. None of these options have really ever been considered. That is why I suggested to the Western Sydney Alliance that we are really in a hiatus position. The government is about to make a decision to be seen to be making a decision, but the people of Western Sydney are probably exhausted having gone to huge public rallies, sent letters of support, signed petitions and filled in cards protesting about this airport. They are pretty exhausted by the whole process. What can we do?

I think there are tough decisions that need to be made. There are some rational decisions that have to be made about air transport in Western Sydney. But we have not yet had a process where the public can be confident that it is fair, that it is open, that it is transparent and that we do not have Dracula in charge of the blood bank—that is, the Department of Transport and Regional Services, perhaps one of the most ideological Public Service departments, running the show. What can we do? What I suggested we need to do is not put in a fix, not select people with a biased view, but select people with impeccable credentials to run a commission of inquiry and look at everything. Everything should be on the table—noise around KSA, flight paths of KSA, capacity of KSA, Bankstown, Badgerys, Goulburn, Canberra and Newcastle. We should have the commission conduct its inquiry in a public way so that everyone will have their day at the inquiry. But, at the end of day, we should ask the commission to make recommendations about what needs to be done.

If we were to have such a commission of inquiry and at the end of the day it recommended Badgerys, well, then I would say that we put up a good fight, but Badgerys it is. I do not think any sane, rational process will throw up Badgerys, but if it did the people of Western Sydney could say, `We have put up a good fight, but we have lost.' But, whatever the decisions, there must be a guarantee that they will not be fiddled, that they will not be rorted and that the government and the opposition would be prepared to rapidly implement those recommendations. This would give you a process that you are confident of. We can learn from the mistakes made in the past.

I also wanted to address the issue of potential employment that is always flung at us in Western Sydney. From the very beginning of my time as a federal member of parliament I supported Badgerys on the basis of the employment prospects that it might generate. Not so different from the bulk of my constituents and the people of Western Sydney, I started to have a change of heart when I saw the mayhem that the third runway caused in the inner city. In those early days we used figures of about 100,000. I notice that the honourable member for Werriwa currently uses a figure of 30,000. That is down from 60,000 that used to be talked about. I think the figure will be less than that.

How can a member from the western suburbs of Sydney deny job opportunities to his constituents or to a region where there is so much unemployment? Like any other member, I desperately want jobs for my people. But why do we in Western Sydney have to accept jobs with an environmental price tag? Why are we so different in Western Sydney that unquestioningly we should accept these jobs knowing the dislocation it will cause to our lifestyle, our environment, our health and the education of our kids? All these things are documented in the EIS. I have turned my back on those jobs.

I get into arguments with some of my constituents. A very good friend of mine is the parish priest at the Holy Family Church. He says to me, `Roger, we need to take these jobs.' But I say to him, `Why should we take these jobs which come at such a heavy price? Why can we not have a fair share of the long-term jobs, the high-tech jobs, the jobs with a future?' Other parts of Sydney may treat the people of Western Sydney as second-class citizens, but I want the House to know that we in no way consider ourselves as second-class citizens and we will not be treated as such. It is for those reasons that I reject that argument.

I believe that when you look at Western Sydney, with its exciting demographics and the fact that 50 per cent of Sydney people will reside there, we have ample opportunities to generate good jobs and clean jobs—jobs that will not degrade our environment, will not degrade our health and will not create greater educational barriers than currently exist in Western Sydney. I again want to say, along with other opposition members, that we are supporting this bill. I want to commend the shadow minister, who has moved an amendment, principally that:

quote.para: (1) Ansett Australia should remain headquartered in Australia;
(2) a fair share of future growth in routes should be through Ansett International;
(3) high skilled, high value Ansett airlines jobs should remain in Australia;
(4) Ansett jobs in regional and rural communities not be jeopardised by the sale; and
(5) services to regional and rural communities should be preserved at current levels, or improved”.

talk.start.para: —I always enjoy speaking on aviation bills because, for one thing, my electorate is close to the existing airport, Sydney (Kingsford Smith) Airport, and, secondly, this particular bill, the Aviation Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) 2000, deals with a favourite topic of mine, that is, foreign investment, or at least the liberalisation of foreign investment in our airlines.

speech.para: Let us be frank about this: foreign investment is a very good thing for Australia. There is a certain hesitation about it in parts of this parliament, certainly among opposition members. That sort of thing reflects a rather old-fashioned view of the damage that restrictions on the movement of capital can do. Some of our colleagues in this place and in other parts of the parliament really have a view of life that suggests that we ought to do as much as possible within our own economy, make as many possible things and provide as many possible services and that the parliament ought to have some prescriptive role in making sure that happens. That kind of autarchy is a death sentence for an economy. It only serves in the end to reduce people's incomes.

When you look around the world now, foreign investment is growing at a pace that it has perhaps never grown at before. Not many people would realise that the Chief Executive Officer of Nissan Motors—one of Japan's proud old brand names—is a Brazilian, because the management of that company performed so badly that the French company Renault took a large stake in Nissan and installed their own man to make sure it was run properly. Likewise, the American company General Motors has large stakes in other Japanese car makers, and Daimler-Benz has just taken a 30 per cent stake in Mitsubishi Motors. So the once unconquerable brand name motorcars from Japan are now being infused with fresh foreign capital, and they are going to do a lot better as a result of that.

Part of this bill allows the liberalisation of investment in Australian international airlines, with the exception of Qantas. This is all about welcoming Air New Zealand's proposed investment in Ansett. I do not know why people would have doubts about Air New Zealand. I think it is a good company. I have a lot of affection for New Zealand and New Zealanders generally, so I welcome their participation in Australian aviation. Australian capital needs the best possible return it can get. Throughout the eighties and the nineties, you might say there was a huge excess of capital washing through the stock, bond and real estate markets. This was caused, I suppose, by the development of silicon technology and historically low oil prices as a result of a lot of exploration for oil in the seventies. This I think, in a cyclical fashion, will soon change, and in the next 10 to 20 years people will likely start talking about a shortage of investment capital, which puts a premium on the return that Australian investment capital can seek.

From now on, we are going to have to confront huge unfunded needs in aged care and health for the so-called baby boomer generation. We are going to have to confront the need to spend a lot more money on defending ourselves, especially as the proliferation of missile technology becomes much more of a reality in North Asia. The only antidote to that as a defence strategy is what is called theatre missile defence—that is, smaller missiles guided by satellites that are able to shoot down a missile that is heading for a target. This is now slowly being undertaken between the United States and Japan as a result of a missile fired from North Korea in August 1998.

Given that we are a close ally of the United States, there is no doubt in my mind that we will have to take part in the development of these new systems. They will be very, very expensive, but they will also have a few other consequences. You will not really be able to participate in them without attracting much larger numbers of advanced software developers and, in order to do that, our current income tax rates, for a start, will have to fall. There is no way in the world we will attract enough people with those skills while we steal half of our high achievers' income at rates of 48 per cent or so. I think various jurisdictions will compete for this kind of human capital in the future, and they will do it by cutting their tax rates to attract them. Hence, you might say that you can foresee a diminution of tax receipts coming as these jurisdictions compete, and we will be one of them. So any restriction on Australian capital now preventing it from getting its best return—whether it is invested in airlines, agriculture or anything else—is pretty soon going to look very, very stupid.

The opposition have moved an amendment, not I notice of a prescriptive nature but which asks the government to take into consideration certain matters when it examines the proposal for the sale of shares in Ansett. They are things like:

quote.para: (1) Ansett Australia should remain headquartered in Australia;
(2) a fair share of future growth in routes should be through Ansett International—

speech.para: that is, with the Ansett livery on aircraft. Also:

quote.para: (4) Ansett jobs in regional and rural communities not be jeopardised by the sale; and
(5) services to regional and rural communities should be preserved at current levels, or improved”.

speech.para: I suppose that sort of rhetoric will deliver some feeling of security to some people. It would be nice if this kind of thing happens in the future, so we should not be too harsh perhaps. But they are not conditions on the sale—they are not prescriptive things that Air New Zealand will have to do. It is more a matter of moral suasion and any government has the right, I suppose, to do that.

All in all this is really a case of incremental liberalisation. Beyond this, the government's aviation policy generally has changed as a result of some recommendations made by the Productivity Commission largely inspired by a submission from a certain person a couple of years ago who served as the then minister for tourism—that was me. I put in a submission to the Productivity Commission at the time calling for open skies, for much more freedom for airlines to carry passengers within Australia, and for the abolition of the dreadful evil cabotage rule. This went to the cabinet. Some of it was accepted, and I welcome that. One day in the future maybe we will be even freer. We will not hurry towards that. It has to be done at a fairly reasonable pace.

The other part of this bill is the proposed increase in penalties for the breach of the curfew at Sydney airport. Obviously, on behalf of my constituents, I support that. It really gives rise to a discussion about the need for more capacity for aviation in the Sydney area. The member for Chifley, my friend Mr Price, spoke about that and some of the issues surrounding the expected development at Badgerys Creek. It is government policy of course, and I understand it is opposition policy too, that that be the location. I say: more steel to their spine and more strength to their hand in building that. There is no doubt that as the capacity constraints come into play at Kingsford Smith we will need a second airport. It is about time we started to walk the walk, not just talk the talk. People talk about a baby Badgerys. It is a cute kind of phrase. As the member for Chifley said, babies grow. You give them nutrition and they grow, and so they should. So, of course, will an airport at Badgerys Creek.

The biggest problem has been the lack of coordination between the tiers of government. I worked out there for a few years before I was elected to this place and I saw with some dismay the subdivisions creeping west of Liverpool and Fairfield out towards the site. I often thought that this was madness because the airport had to be built there, yet they were allowing all these subdivisions to creep ever closer. Although people might say, `Oh, well, the people who bought there knew very well the airport was coming,' inevitably it leads to fuss and protest: `We don't want it there.' We have to face up to that some time. I can only say that it is really not all that bad. An airport is something to be welcomed, not to be opposed. You would not have a baby economy or a baby income, would you? No. So why would you have a baby airport? It will grow.

The important thing to assure people is that it will grow slowly and steadily, and so it should. You should not necessarily throw huge amounts of capital at something that will not be needed in its full capacity for about 10 years. I think the government's participation in the funding of it, frankly, should be at a minimum and that as much as possible of private capital should be employed to build what you might call a baby Badgerys to start with but to develop it as it grows naturally as the air traffic grows. It is one thing for me to say that we should have the best possible return on Australian capital because we will desperately need it in the future. The same can be said for public capital. There is no point overcapitalising on an airport at Badgerys Creek if it is going to be half empty for the next 10 years. It can grow in that location incrementally, and I hope that is exactly what happens in the future.

I would like to conclude my remarks by reiterating that I welcome the participation of Air New Zealand in Australian aviation. I welcome foreign ownership of Australian companies just as I welcome Australian ownership of foreign companies. The less restrictions on the flow of capital the better the return on equity, and that is the best thing that Australian shareholders, citizens, taxpayers, whomever, can expect.

talk.start.para: —The Aviation Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) 2000 currently before the House seeks to amend both the Air Navigation Act 1920 and the Sydney Airport Curfew Act 1995. These amendments will have two major impacts on the operation of the aviation industry in Australia: to increase the allowable percentage of foreign ownership in Australian international carriers other than Qantas and to increase the penalty imposed for breaking curfew restrictions at Sydney airport. This follows a report released on 11 September 1998 by the Productivity Commission on its inquiry into international air services and the International Air Services Commission. I am pleased to say that the government has for the most part responded in a responsible manner to this report and the bill before the House will give legislative approval to its response.

speech.para: Sections of the report from the Productivity Commission have not been supported, and I am pleased that this is the case. Allowing for free and unfettered access to our domestic routes by international airlines would have had a real and, I believe, very negative impact on our domestic services. To have given international carriers the ability to pick and choose from our domestic routes, whereby the profitable ones in our current domestic market would have been lost, would have reduced the quality of service received in regional Australia. The very high volume and consequently profitable routes play a role in the cross-subsidisation of services to regional Australia. It is important to note that this action in maintaining domestic routes for Australian carriers is in line with the treatment that Qantas and Ansett receive from our major trading partners. Other than New Zealand, none of the major trading partners allow Ansett or Qantas access to their domestic markets.

This legislation will give effect to the government's formal response to the report from the Productivity Commission. I will confine my comments to the portion of this bill that relates to the increase in the allowable holdings in Australian international carriers by foreign nationals. The Australian aviation industry is important. It is important to those who work in it. It is important to those who for commercial or recreational reasons use it, and it is especially important to regional Australia. I can assure all members that, coming from Tasmania, I particularly appreciate the importance of air services.

The ownership of Australian international airlines has implications for the capacity of the Australian government to negotiate bilateral air service agreements with other countries. Bilateral air service agreements and the rights contained with them are the province of a country and not any particular airline. Accordingly, for an airline to exercise the rights granted to a country, it must be substantially owned or effectively controlled by nationals of the country to which the right was granted.

The bill before the House will alter the current arrangements such that 49 per cent of Australian international carriers will be able to be owned by any foreign person or company. Currently there is a limit on holdings of Australian international carriers, other than Qantas, by individual foreign airlines of 25 per cent and no more than 35 per cent for foreign airlines. Indeed, the current guidelines administered by the Foreign Investment Review Board allow for the following: 25 per cent of an Australian domestic airline or international airline by an individual airline which flies to Australia; 40 per cent total ownership of an Australian domestic airline by foreign airlines; 35 per cent total ownership of an Australian international airline by foreign airlines; and foreign investors, including airlines which do not fly to Australia, can hold up to 100 per cent of an Australian domestic airline. These ownership levels are, however, dependent upon an assessment that the level of foreign ownership is in the national interest. As I previously indicated, the bill before the House will increase these limits to allow for 49 per cent foreign ownership of Australian international carriers and will remove the distinction between foreign airlines and other investors when considering holdings in Australian airlines.

This brings me to the impact that this change will have directly on the industry. There are 10 Australian airlines which will be affected by this legislative change. I will, however, limit my remarks to the impact on Ansett and Ansett International. As honourable members are aware, Air New Zealand is proposing to acquire News Corp's share—50 per cent—in Ansett Holdings. This will give to Air New Zealand 100 per cent ownership of the domestic operations of Ansett and a 49 per cent holding in Ansett International. Mergers of this sort occur for many reasons, one of which is the efficiencies which can be gained through the streamlining of administrative and back office operations.

As Ansett is a significant employer, I have concerns that through any merger there are no job losses in Australia. In 1998-99, Ansett employed 14,876 people and had a net profit after tax of $156.8 million. By any reasonable measure, this is a significant company. The maintenance of the headquarters of Ansett in Australia is an essential ingredient to maintaining in the national interest employment with Ansett in Australia. Given the complexity of the aviation industry, many of the jobs within the industry are of a highly complex nature and provide a correspondingly high value, both to the employee and to Australia. Through all operations of an airline, highly skilled people are required to ensure that the operations are efficient, profitable and above all safe. Maintaining these highly skilled employees in Australia, working out of Australia and providing a benefit to Australia is essential.

I am not speaking solely of pilots. There are, just to name a few of them, ground crews, maintenance engineers, computer technicians and programmers, and people experienced in logistics and scheduling. These are examples of only some of the highly skilled and valuable employees who contribute to any successful airline and the loss of any of these highly skilled jobs from Australia would be a loss to Australia. Skilled people are a resource that we cannot risk. What needs to be ensured by the government, if this merger is to go ahead, is that the national interest is not counted in dollars and cents or strategic industry placement alone but in maintaining a work force which is employed in Australia. I would be amazed, and not a little disturbed, if any member in this House did not believe that highly skilled and often well paid jobs are not to be considered when assessing the national interest. It is important to remember that, even following the passage of this bill, if that is to occur, there will remain a national interest test which must be applied to any increase in the holding of an Australian airline by foreign nationals, and it is the responsibility of the government to ensure that the public interest is taken into account.

The development of a skilled work force is essential to Australia. A skilled population is not something which just appears overnight or simply when we require it. A skilled work force needs to be developed and nurtured. This development can only really occur under a government committed to real skill development. Since 1994-95 apprenticeships in the aviation industry have fallen significantly. In 1994-95, 226 apprenticeships commenced. In 1995-96, 232 apprenticeships commenced. In 1996-97, the number fell to 172, and in 1997-98, it was 94. In the first half of the 1998-99 year, just 12 new apprenticeships were commenced.

Australia's best interest is served when our work force is skilled and those skills are not only maintained but further developed.
