A commitment to maintaining skills in Australia must be threefold: a commitment to training, a commitment to retraining and a commitment to not exporting highly skilled jobs to another country. It is essential that not only highly skilled jobs are protected but these jobs are maintained in regional areas. In this context, I am speaking not only about Ansett but also about Kendall Airlines—which fly to Tasmania—Skywest Airlines and Aeropelican Air Services. These services provide what in many regional areas is an essential service, and maintaining the employment levels of staff in regional Australia is important. Already the gap between major mainland capital cities and the rest of Australia in relation to job opportunities has grown too large, and to see an increased flow of jobs from regional areas to capital cities would be a further blow to struggling communities. Were any merger to affect the employment opportunities of people in regional Australia, it is clear that no national interest would be served.

I am particularly concerned that the Ansett call centre within my electorate not only is maintained as an Australian based facility but remains in Launceston. Given the Prime Minister's much lauded commitment to regional Australia, I would expect no less than a direction to the Foreign Investment Review Board that, in assessing the national interest, the impact of possible reductions in employment in regional Australia must be taken into account. This is a real test because either regional Australia is important to Australia and our future as a nation or it is not. This should be a demonstrable commitment, if such a commitment exists, to the people of regional Australia.

This is another of the firm principled commitments that the government needs to make. It has failed to make it with regard to mandatory sentencing in the Northern Territory; let us hope it does not fail us in aviation. The corollary of maintaining jobs and skill enhancement opportunities in regional Australia is that this will give the best guarantee possible that services will be maintained. Airlines in regional Australia provide employment and infrastructure but, further, they provide access for those who do not live in major capital cities. This cuts both ways: airlines for many regional areas are the artery of our tourist industry. Tourism plays a huge role in Bass with one in nine Tasmanians employed in the tourism industry. Accordingly, it is essential that services are maintained for three reasons: that those people who live in regional Australia are not further isolated from many of the things our nation has to offer; that our tourist industries are not constricted; and that growth in employment is not contained by the inability of tourists to access holiday destinations outside capital cities.

In regional Australia the importance of air transport is paramount. Members from metropolitan electorates can rarely understand this importance. I will be supporting this legislation because it is a sensible response to the Productivity Commission's report. It behoves the government to ensure that the national interest is served. I believe that the national interest is broad. It is in the national interest to maintain employment in Australia. It is in the national interest to ensure that the skills of Australia's work force are developed. It is in the national interest to ensure that jobs are not lost from regional areas to capital cities. It is in the national interest to ensure that air services are not reduced in regional Australia. These are the tests by which the government must judge any mergers in the airline industry. These are also the issues that the government must address in its approach to the policy surrounding our aviation industry.

talk.start.para: —During my nearly 24 years in this place I suppose I have been involved in most of the major aviation debates, and yet this debate today probably comes up at one of the most significant times of Australian commercial aviation history. It is appropriate that this bill is being debated at this time when we see the tremendous changes going on in the aviation industry. I have been quite fascinated today to follow this debate and to see some of the lines that have been run. I would like to comment on a few of the contributions made by previous speakers, because I think we have seen a major change in attitude in this place to not only the present state of Australian aviation but indeed to the future of Australian aviation. As I say, I think this is a most significant time in the history of aviation, because now we are seeing a time when massive consolidation is about to take place with the two major carriers in which we have an opportunity to go out into the world and to put our stamp on international aviation facilities and indeed we have the opportunity, I think, of creating a strong and viable but an ever-expanding aviation facility here in Australia.

speech.para: I was interested to hear the member for Bass and her concern about what was happening in terms of the possibility of the loss of jobs in Australia and the necessity to maintain those jobs and to have certain protections written in in the future activities in terms of the takeover of Ansett. I was interested to hear of her concern that in her home state of Tasmania there could possibly be the loss of jobs. It is quite interesting that the fact that Ansett maintain their 24-hour call centre in Launceston and employs something like 340 people is a most significant part of the Tasmanian economy these days. I do not think there is any doubt that Ansett have made a commitment to maintain that. Indeed, I think it made a formal commitment to the Tasmanian government that they are not going to move the call centre. Also, I believe that there is an indication from Ansett that they are in fact looking at increasing the number of people who are employed in that facility in Launceston. So what I think is going to happen is that you are not going to see a loss of jobs but, as I said earlier, there is the possibility of a major expansion in the number of jobs in aviation.

I was also very interested in the comments of the member for Chifley and a number of the scenarios that he raised. I think the substance of the opening of his speech was the fact that he had some concern that an Australian icon—namely, Ansett Airlines—was moving into foreign hands. As a former employee of Ansett Transport Industries—not in the aviation sector but I did have 10 years with that division of the company before I entered parliament—I must say that I share that concern, although I probably lost that sympathy with the takeover by TNT and News Limited back in the early 1980s. That was where the real change came in terms of the administration of Ansett. What we are debating today really is going to see the survival of Ansett, because Ansett has been through some pretty tough times. It was under the administration of Sir Peter Abels and his crew that Ansett started going bad. If we cast our minds back 11 years now to that disastrous pilots dispute, the reality was that Ansett never really survived that. There have been times in recent years when Ansett went very close to the wind in terms of staying in business. I would like to particularly pay tribute to Rod Eddington, whom News Corporation had enough sense to buy from Cathay Pacific to try to turn that airline around. I think he has done a magnificent job, despite the fact that he arrived at an airline that really had some very bad vibes about it. Certainly, staff morale was down. He had a mixture of fleet that was really unheard of—I think they had about 16 different types of aircraft in the fleet. He had Qantas up and rampant, operating on two types of aircraft and ripping the market out of them to the point where they were almost 10 points ahead. He had ageing aircraft and needed to undertake fleet renewal. Despite all those disadvantages, he battled on and did a reorganisation of the airline which kept it going.

As a result of this legislation and as a result of what happened in New Zealand yesterday, Ansett certainly now has the opportunity to come back in a big way. Yesterday in New Zealand the shareholders of Air New Zealand approved the formal takeover of Ansett, and that now is likely to go ahead. While the game is not completely over and there is still an interesting sideshow going on in terms of the bids by Qantas and Singapore Airlines as to future ownership of Ansett, my feeling is that the situation will probably settle down and, if you hear what is happening out of the offices of Brierley in Singapore and indeed from New Zealand, it would appear that Air New Zealand would like to see Singapore Airlines take a share of Air New Zealand and consequently have that involvement with Ansett. From Ansett's point of view, obviously that is going to give them some access to tremendous capital and to some good fleet arrangements as well. So, in that respect, once this all settles down, we do have the chance of having a very viable Ansett once again, hopefully providing some real competition in the Australian domestic industry and ultimately an expansion in terms of their international routes.

I was also interested in the member for Chifley's summing up of the situation of Badgerys Creek airport. This has been an interest of mine for many years. In fact I was in negotiations with a number of the councils of Western Sydney—

talk.start.para: —That's true.

—I am very pleased to see Mr Latham in the chamber today, because 10 years ago there was a completely different attitude to the development of Badgerys Creek. But a couple of things have happened since then. There have been some tremendous advances in technology, and the member for Chifley raised the question of what the true capacity of Sydney (Kingsford Smith) Airport is. I do not know the ultimate answer to that. There have been various quotes that they can probably get another 70,000 movements within Kingsford Smith if they make some changes to the present technology and the present operating procedures. I think that is probably true. One of the difficulties that they may have at Kingsford Smith is that there is gong to be less and less terminal access and obviously there is going to have to be a great deal of slotting going on to maximise the gate facilities in the non-peak hours. That really still is one of the difficulties of Kingsford Smith—that the majority of the traffic arrives and takes off between six and nine in the morning and about four and seven at night. Quite often, the airport is semi-deserted during the day.

speech.para: Part of that difficulty is our position in the world. We are at the end of a long route and it is not always possible for operators to schedule their services out of Europe and beyond to arrive in Sydney in the middle of the day. But that in itself is going to be an interesting exercise. Our air traffic control procedures never cease to amaze me. When you go to the United States and look at a place like Chicago, where there is a 23-second separation of aircraft, or to Los Angeles, where the separation is about 32 seconds, while we may feel good about anything up to a three-minute separation in Australia, it certainly does restrict the flow of traffic. But that is not to pay some tribute to Kingsford Smith airport because, as anybody in this place who has to fly through Kingsford Smith knows, it can often be a trip from hell when you leave, as in my case, from Brisbane, you fly for an hour and then do a circuit around Mount McCord for about three quarters of an hour before you can get in—it drives you mad. Presently, the operations in Sydney (Kingsford Smith) Airport have improved and I understand that the most recent figures that are available indicate that the on-time performances are up into the high 80 per cent, so things are improving there; but we have got a long way to go.

One of the things that I think would be a fascinating exercise would be the privatisation of air traffic control services. This has happened in a number of overseas countries. In actual fact they have looked towards staff buyouts, and air traffic controllers have taken over a lot of the systems, particularly in the UK, I understand, and the United States. The improvement in performance has been absolutely magnificent, and air traffic control systems have proved to be a very lucrative business. I do not think that that is quite on the books here in Australia at this stage, but it would be interesting to see what the increase in the productivity of Sydney (Kingsford Smith) Airport might be if we went along that particular track.

In terms of Badgerys Creek, the member for Chifley probably hit the nail on the head when he pointed out that within a matter of years you are going to have more than 60 per cent of the population based in Western Sydney. Looking at the size of that population, the reality is that you can probably justify an airport there now and, despite what the airlines might say, there would certainly be enough traffic going in there for the major airlines to provide direct interstate services from other capital cities to serve that tremendous population in Western Sydney. I also noted my friend from Sydney who indicated that he had worked in that particular area and was fairly impressed with the capacity for the number of jobs that could be created if that airport went ahead; and I think that that is true. Airports are very great employers

My understanding is that there are about 29,000 people directly and indirectly employed with Sydney (Kingsford Smith) Airport and that some of the quotes on the possible jobs that would be available in the western suburbs would indicate that many thousands of jobs could be provided if Badgerys Creek went ahead. But we have got the same situation as we had with Tullamarine. Local governments allowed development to ease up closer and closer to the airports and, in the case of Tullamarine, there are now noise problems—not the fault of the federal government at all. We have a similar situation with Badgerys Creek. Obviously noise is always going to be a factor, although I think in all fairness that the efforts that have been made by this government and the previous government in terms of noise control in Sydney and the provision of silencing material in homes directly surrounding the airport have probably been good ones. In fact, I understand that we have been a world leader in terms of trying to provide some relief from aircraft noise with the work that has been done.

Badgerys Creek ultimately is going to be needed. It is the nature of Sydney. I would hope that, if a decision is made to go ahead, we are not going to completely rub out the possibility of a fully fledged major airport there—because we are going to need it. We are going to need it not only in terms of passenger traffic but also in terms of freight. The freight market to Australia is building quite well. I do not think we should ever close off that Badgerys Creek option. Sure, make all the provisions we can for noise protection and the rest of it, but the reality is that that facility is going to be needed.

When you talk to people from Sydney within the tourist industry and within the business community, they say, `Badgerys Creek is too far out.' The reality is that Badgerys Creek is about 54 kilometres from the middle of Sydney. If you need a comparison with a Badgerys development, I suggest that you have a look at the development at Stansted outside London, about 54 kilometres from the middle of town. It was not quite a greenfields site—the site had been a World War II airbase—but the work that was done there by the British Airports Authority, not only in the development of that but also in the way that they undertook consultation with the local community, maintained a liaison with the local community and established local community groups to advise them, was really a tremendous exercise in the way airport development should take place.

As I say, Badgerys Creek being similarly located from the heart of Sydney as Stansted is from London, the possibilities of providing direct links into the middle of Sydney are obviously going to be essential. In the case of Stansted there is a high speed train. It is 34 minutes from Stansted to Liverpool Street station—which is certainly a lot quicker than from Heathrow to the city via the underground and not terribly different in terms of the time taken from London Gatwick into the middle of town by the Gatwick express. I would certainly not write off the prospect of the future development of Badgerys Creek and all the advantages that it can provide.

My statement earlier that this is one of the most exciting times in terms of airline development is true. We are seeing now a major shift in international aviation, and Australia has got to be part of that game if we are going to survive and if we are going to be able to continue to provide full airline services to Australia and all the advantages they bring, not only in terms of business but in terms of the tourist industry as well. We have seen some interesting things happen because Australia is really in a very difficult position. Being at the end of these long routes—and they are quite often thin routes—it is easy for major carriers to forget us. Over the last couple of years we have seen indications of that. There was a downturn at the time of the Gulf War. A couple of carriers dropped out of Australia and included in those were Germany's Lufthansa and airlines like American Airlines and Continental. We have not seen them come back on the route yet.

In the Asian downturn we saw the cancellation of a number of services and a number of airlines operating into Australia. I still am in two minds, I think, about the airline alliances, but they probably are necessary—or a variation on a theme is necessary—if we are to maintain those services. Frankly, I am not sure exactly what the Star Alliance does for Air New Zealand and for Ansett in the physical traffic that they get from the major partners. My feeling is it is probably not much more than they would normally get, and I guess the same thing happens to the oneworld alliance. Qantas is one of the smaller operators in that group. But it does give you clout and helps you maintain your presence in some of those major markets of the world. I have got no doubt that those alliances are very good for American airlines and British Airways, who in actual fact set up oneworld primarily to make sure that they tied up the North Atlantic market; similarly with United Airlines and Lufthansa tying that up fairly tightly as well. The disadvantage, I think, from an Australian point of view of the alliances is that they tend to take away some of the competition. In actual fact—maybe this is a good thing—air fares internationally have increased quite dramatically if you are flying with alliance partners. There basically is a fixed fare; there is little room to negotiate. That is not saying that by searching the market you cannot find some good fares. I have just been on the Internet, Mr Deputy Speaker, and if you want to fly first class to London at the moment I can advise you where you can get a fare for $3,250. It is quite interesting that the market is still pretty free and fluid at the moment. It is a new airline that has just started operating out of Sydney. They have got some specials on. All that is going to be in the market. But the reality is that if you are looking at, in an international sense, selling Australia as part of an around the world ticket, the discounts are not there if you travel with the alliances. One of the concerns is that airlines that are not in the alliance—some of the smaller carriers—could in actual fact ultimately be squeezed out of business.

I want to talk about Brisbane before my time expires, and the comment of the member for Bass who was concerned about the loss of highly skilled and highly paid aviation jobs overseas. I would like to remind her that, when her particular political party was in government, there was a move to establish a major maintenance base in Brisbane by an overseas carrier. Unfortunately, the negotiations with the then Federal Airports Authority—and, I understand, with the Queensland state government at the time—resulted in that not being taken up. But there are some enormous opportunities for us to expand that section of the business. Obviously I may be a little biased, but ultimately I think we will see major maintenance bases established in places like Brisbane purely because of the facilities they have got there. They have got a huge tract of land. If you look at a place like Singapore, while Changi airport is regarded as the best in the world, in actual fact they have not got too much room to expand. Singapore Airlines is an expanding airline. They have been looking around places like Thailand for major maintenance bases. I think there probably is an opportunity for us, through some of these alliances, to try to make arrangements whereby they can put these major facilities within Australia.

We are going to have some major opportunities. If Virgin Atlantic, the Branson airline, comes in and is based in Brisbane, obviously it is going to need maintenance facilities there. We could build on that, particularly as there is some tie-in between Virgin Atlantic and Singapore Airlines at the moment. We are looking at the work that is being done by Impulse, which is the independent airline from New South Wales. They are going into jet equipment, and they will be looking around for local maintenance. I think that, as the whole industry expands, that is one area that we should concentrate on and one area where we should promote the concept of establishing these Australian facilities, because there is no doubt that some of our engineering is amongst the best in the world. We have a huge and ever growing aviation market with Asia, and there is an enormous opportunity for us to cash in on that.

But I certainly support the bill. As I say, it is quite a historic time for Australian aviation, and the passage of this bill will see a much stronger Ansett and the opportunity for Australia to take its place as one of the major players in international aviation.

talk.start.para: —I always enjoy listening to the member for Fadden in these debates. He is certainly a learned contributor in this parliament when it comes to aviation policy. On this occasion, however, I must correct him on two matters relating to Badgerys Creek airport. The first is his claim that there has been residential encroachment on the Badgerys Creek airport site. In fact, this is one of the myths of the Sydney airport debate. The EIS to establish the Badgerys Creek site was delivered and ticked off in the mid-1980s. By the end of that decade, the state planning department had instructed local government authorities in the region to establish an exclusion zone around Badgerys Creek airport. I know that, because I was one of the mayors at that time—at Liverpool Council—that had to enforce the exclusion zone surrounding Badgerys Creek airport, and to this day that exclusion zone has been maintained. There has been no residential release in the zone that was established around Badgerys Creek in the late 1980s. Some residents who bought into large homes on acreage properties, knowing that there will be an airport constructed at Badgerys Creek, then complained to their local members of parliament about this outrage. I am always surprised that those members have their ear captured by such residents and such complaints. People who moved in knowing that there would be an airport have got no legitimate complaint. They knew what they were getting into. We can proceed confident that there has been no suburban encroachment on the Badgerys Creek site. The exclusion zone has been protected; in fact it is enshrined in the laws of New South Wales, and local government authorities cannot break those laws.

speech.para: The second matter where I would draw a correction to the attention of the member for Fadden is his claim that the Badgerys Creek site is 54 kilometres from the centre of Sydney. That is true if you take the centre of Sydney to be the CBD. But from where I look at Sydney, the centre of it is, on demographic grounds, at Parramatta. The distance from the Badgerys Creek site to Parramatta would be probably half the 54 kilometres that the honourable member mentioned.

This is one of the reasons why the Liberal member for Parramatta—showing leadership for his side in the region— is supporting Badgerys Creek airport. He is one of those people who seems to act on principle instead of populism. His principles and conclusions support the Badgerys Creek airport. I welcome his support for this longstanding and important project for the region, and I support the principles that he brings to the debate.

Often members will stand up in this parliament and ask, `Why is democracy so sick? Why is there so little trust and support for representative democracy these days?' One of the reasons is that too few members act on principle. So many members blow with the wind on this question of Badgerys Creek airport. The member for Fadden pointed out, if you go back to the early 1990s when unemployment was exceptionally high in the region, every local government authority and every member of state and federal was supportive—if not supportive, then at least silent—on the question of the Badgerys Creek airport. Now the wind has changed direction and some of them have changed their views. That does not mean they are right. I would have thought it is a sure sign that they are wrong and they are acting on populist ideals instead of sound principle and fact.

This legislation addresses two questions: the first is competitive arrangements in the Australian aviation industry, and the second is the matter we have just been discussing, Sydney's aviation arrangements. I want to talk about both matters in further detail. On the question of competition I am a very strong supporter of the entry of a third domestic airline. It is great to see Virgin come into this industry. In Australia we have had the problem of having two airlines but just one set of prices. We have had the problem of having two airlines but just one timetable. There has been no effective competition between Ansett and Qantas. Virgin—which is a dynamic entrepreneurial company with deep pockets—is ideally suited to bust up that duopoly and bring Australian air consumers more effective competition and, hopefully, a better service and lower prices. I also note that Virgin has decided to locate its headquarters in Brisbane. It could not locate in Sydney because of the lack of airport capacity. If we had Badgerys Creek up and running, of course, there would have been further jobs for Western Sydney as our region would have been in the race for attracting the headquarters of this new entrant.

It is not just the third player that would bring improved competition to the Australian aviation industry. We must also look at some of the administrative arrangements. I was attracted recently to an article that appeared in the Australian Financial Review written by David Trebeck. The Australian Financial Review, particularly on the op ed page, is always reliable and he has made a very convincing argument about the ways in which competition might be improved in the aviation industry. He has written a piece relating to the computer reservation systems. We all know that a former government made the faulty decision to give Qantas and Ansett a lock-up in terminal space. It was one of the reasons why Compass found it very hard to break into the industry. Unfortunately, these lock-up arrangements also apply to computer reservation systems. There are just two systems of course, one dominated by Qantas and the other dominated by Ansett. Unfortunately, the ACCC has never comprehensively analysed the computer reservation system and brought to bear a report that might break up these duopoly arrangements.
Mr Trebeck then goes on to make some very good points about these arrangements and the need for improved access and competition. I will quote him at length:

quote.para: Independent airlines have had to negotiate a hosting arrangement with either the Ansett or Qantas CRS. But they are then virtually beholden to that CRS. If they lost hosting, they would be in financial strife within days, as a number of small regional airlines have found to their great cost. This inhibits their capacity to grow, much less to become a genuine competitive force.

Among other effects, the independent airline is not only denied access to its only data from the CRS but the major airline controlling the CRS can view and analyse its competitor's data. The opportunities for plunder can be readily imagined.

Even when an airline is hosted by one CRS, it is typically not listed in the other, with the result that consumers can be disadvantaged. For example, an inquiry to Qantas by a Canberra traveller seeking a flight to Albury, would result in the passenger being routed via Sydney. The Qantas CRS would not disclose Air Facilities' direct flight from Canberra to Albury because it is hosted on the Ansett CRS.

speech.para: This is a locked up system, not only locked up for the benefit of Ansett and Qantas, but a system where they can actually view the financial data and reservations of their competitors and plunder it accordingly. We need to declare it as part of an excess regime where all players in the aviation industry can have fair and equal access to reservation systems, and none of them would be disadvantaged by those arrangements. Mr Trebeck has made a valid point. Public policy and pro-competition policy in this country for the aviation industry does not only involve a third entrant, such as Virgin. It also involves breaking up the duopoly within the terminal spaces and also providing fair access arrangements on the computer reservation systems.

I turn to a matter you are quite passionate about and interested in, Madam Deputy Speaker. Sometimes we have differences of opinion, and I am afraid I will have to continue that pattern in my remarks about the Badgerys Creek airport. Let me address the recent comments made by a newcomer to this debate. Senator Payne from the Liberal Party has dropped out of one of those cocktail parties on the lower North Shore and set up an office in Parramatta, ostensibly as a representative for Western Sydney. Dropping out of a cocktail party one day and saying that you are a representative the next is, of course, not a good qualification in politics. Her ignorance about Western Sydney has been reflected in a press release she put out on 8 December last year entitled `Figures defy Badgerys argument'. This is what the good senator had to say:

quote.para: The latest employment figures for Greater Western Sydney nullify the argument that a second airport at Badgerys Creek will be a much-needed boon for local jobs ...

speech.para: That is such an illogical statement. Fancy saying that employment figures today disqualify an employment generator in the future. Western Sydney is a growing region with a big population increase. There is big growth in its labour force and there will be a big demand for jobs for the next 30 or 40 years. So it is an illogical statement to say that the airport is nullified by current employment figures. She then goes on to say, using figures produced by the Greater Western Sydney Economic Development Board:

quote.para: ... a further 87,000 people should be employed throughout the Greater West by 2005.
This growth defies any argument that Western Sydney needs the second airport for job creation.

speech.para: All I can ask is where does the Liberal Party get these people? Where do they find these ignorant fools? Where do they get these people who can make such comments? The creation of 87,000 jobs in Western Sydney over the next five years would, of course, be exceptionally welcome. But it does not solve the unemployment problem. It does not wipe out the job deficit currently experienced by every local government area in the region. I mentioned that Western Sydney will have enormous population growth. It will grow by hundreds of thousands of people in the next 10 to 15 years, and a good proportion of those people in the labour force in Western Sydney will be wanting jobs.

In addition, we already have 50,000 unemployed people in the region. So, if you take the population growth, the growth in the labour force plus the existing 50,000 people in Western Sydney unemployed, I am afraid that 87,000 jobs is not enough to wipe out the unemployment problem. So the senator has got it wrong. In fact, I think she is wasting her time in the Senate. She is denying a village somewhere the perfect idiot. She has displayed absolute ignorance about the needs of people in Western Sydney on the employment front. Not only that, she has drawn these figures from research work by the National Institute of Economic Research. This is the same institute that strongly supports the development of Badgerys Creek airport as a solution to unemployment. The senator knows nothing of the history of this issue and its research. She has drawn figures from the national institute that say, `Yes, it is welcome; 87,000 jobs coming up in Western Sydney. But you will do even better on our recommendation to build the second airport at Badgerys Creek.' The senator is damned by her own source. The national institute has recommended on employment grounds that Badgerys Creek must proceed. She is damned by her own source and damned by her own ignorance. Her statements only need to be thought about for five seconds to be dismissed as ignorant and inadequate.

I mentioned job deficits in the region. Have a go at these statistics. A place like Blacktown has 46,000 more residents in the labour force than jobs in the local area. The job deficits in Penrith, 36,000, Campbelltown, 34,000, and Fairfield, 31,000, are just as bad. So the 87,000 jobs that the senator talks about will not wipe out the unemployment problem, and they will not wipe out the job deficits. Those job deficits will remain if Western Sydney does not build the Badgerys Creek airport and generate the estimated 30,000 jobs over the next 20 years. We will still have big job deficits in every local government area—Fairfield, 31,000; Campbelltown, 34,000; Penrith 36,000; and Blacktown, 46,000.

What this means, for the information of honourable members, is two things: first, of course, residents find it a lot harder to get a job because they have got to travel a lot further—you have to travel well out of your local government area to get a job—and, second, if you do get a job you are normally in the car early in the day and late in the evening to and from work, and cars are the great air pollutants in Western Sydney. Moving the jobs closer to where the people live is the great environmental bonus for our region. That is why I say Badgerys Creek is good not only for the economy of Western Sydney but for the environment. Because, as people live closer to their place of work there are fewer cars, reduced travelling times, less air pollutants and greater environmental sustainability in the Greater Western Sydney region.

I have spoken in the past about my despair on this question, and I often vow that I will never again say anything about Badgerys Creek. The debate has been running for over a decade, and I have been involved, in local government and now in federal politics, for that period. But every now and then my blood boils again and I cannot hold back. Every now and then I read something or hear something that just confirms the stupidity of these delays, the hopelessness of the 15-year delay in building Badgerys Creek airport. Recently I was wading through some old papers and looking at some material from Robert Reich's book The Work of Nations. This is an internationally respected work on economic development. This is what Reich has had to say about regional development:

quote.para: The university offers a steady supply of bright and eager graduates delighted to labour at low initial wages for the opportunity to gain experience in the hope of greater rewards later on. The international airport provides direct access to the rest of the world.
A world-class university and an international airport combine the basic rudiments of economic growth—brains and quick access to the rest of the world.

speech.para: There is a leading authority saying that if you want to do something positive on regional development get a good university and get an international airport. They are your two foundation stones for regional success. So what have we done in Western Sydney? We had a debate in the 1980s about whether we should have the multifunction polis, which would have been a research centre and investment opportunity of note. There was a knee-jerk reaction in the region, and it was sent off to Adelaide where it has been a bad failure. We should have grabbed that opportunity in the mid-1980s and taken the multifunction polis along with the Badgerys Creek airport. There would have been in Western Sydney an airport and in the surrounding region not only the development of the University of Western Sydney as a centre of excellence but the development of research and investment opportunities out of the multifunction polis.

That was a lost opportunity from 15 years ago, a lost opportunity that has denied Western Sydney access to export markets through the international airport and denied Western Sydney the research and investment arm that would have been such a magnificent complement for the University of Western Sydney. The region ignored the Reich recommendation to take those two foundation stones and make good use of them. It was an act of folly to knock back the multifunction polis in the mid-1980s. Then, since the mid-1990s, it has been an act of folly to mount campaigns and hysteria trying to reject the Badgerys Creek airport site.

The other night I was debating the Darwin to Alice Springs rail line—which I think the member for Dobell referred to as the `Darwin to Campbelltown rail line'; that would give it a better feasibility, there's no doubt about that, but it will never extend that far—and I said that in Western Sydney we have got a project that is ready for big capital funding. It has passed not one but two environmental impact statements. It has complied with the job generation forecasts of not one, two or three but four employment studies. Four employment studies have said you will get more than 30,000 jobs out of this over a 20-year period. The project is just waiting to go. It could not have received closer or more extensive scrutiny over a long period. But still it has not been built. In fact, this government is paralysed. It dare not make a decision about this, for the political reasons I mentioned earlier on.

Still the story gets worse. Again, I saw a publication—I read these things just for recreation—from the Australian Industry Group, which produced their regional breakdown, a survey of leading industry houses in Western Sydney. They had to give their view about the infrastructure and business opportunities in our region and they stated:

quote.para: Firms cite the Western Sydney infrastructure and distance to major centres as the only main disadvantage.

speech.para: So infrastructure and distance are seen by industry houses as disadvantages in our region. What is the one thing that would correct the problem of inadequate infrastructure and long distances? An international airport. It gives immediate access to export markets and of course would be a wonderful catalyst for other transport projects such as the orbital highway. The business houses then went on to report that the air transport infrastructure is inadequate—51 per cent of the businesses in Western Sydney said that. Again, this is further confirmation of the sound economic reasons for the development of this airport site.

I mentioned some related projects, and I will conclude on this matter. Earlier I pointed to the ignorance of Senator Payne. That is matched fully by the ignorance of Charlie Lynn MLC, who parades himself around as a shadow minister for Western Sydney. He was talking about one of the related projects—that is, the further improvement of the M5 Freeway. In that very reliable journal the Macarthur Advertiser on 1 March he said:

quote.para: It is ridiculous that the only set of traffic lights on a dual carriage freeway between Canberra and the end of the M5 in Sydney is at Moorebank Avenue ... “It is an unnecessary peak hour traffic obstacle for Macarthur motorists who have long distances to travel to and from work in the Sydney area. The Carr Government cannot blame anybody else for its ineptitude in addressing the chronic traffic problems on the M5.”

speech.para: Mr Lynn is trying to blame the Carr government for the traffic lights at Moorebank Avenue which lead to a traffic build-up on the M5. In fact they were the result of a decision by the Greiner and Fahey governments in the late 1980s. They signed faulty tollway contracts that left those traffic lights and missing links in place so that the M5 would not be a functional road. So I say to Charlie Lynn, `Grab a Gregorys and grab a guide to Western Sydney'—just as Senator Payne needs those items—`and take them to the now member for Cook, Bruce Baird, who was the transport minister, and shoot the blame home to him.' He was the person who signed the foolish contract to make the M5 less functional than it should be. There is a lot more work to do on these issues. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Today I rise to support the Aviation Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) 2000. This bill comprises two elements. The first element is the implementation of the government's decision to liberalise foreign ownership of Australian international airlines, except for Qantas. The second component of the bill would increase the maximum fine, as we have heard before, for breaching the Sydney Airport curfew from $110,000 to $550,000. The benefits of international air travel both for passengers and cargo are increasingly important to the Australian economy. Australia's largest single export industry is tourism, with export earnings of $16.3 billion in 1998-99. An overwhelming majority of our visitors arrive and depart on aircraft. International air services also carried over $53 billion worth of freight to and from Australia to the year ending December 1999.

speech.para: With the emergence in September 1993 of a second Australian based international airline, Ansett International, the Australian international aviation industry as a whole was strengthened. Six years on, the international market has grown by some 37 per cent, while the Australian market share has remained at 40 per cent. The tourism export industries in Australia have seen rapid growth, as we know, in the last few years. This has been made possible by the success of government efforts to negotiate passenger and freight capacity well ahead of market demand. The global market that the Australian industries operate in is regulated by a unique arrangement of bilaterally traded rights.

As far as the Anderson-Howard government is concerned, if there are going to be restrictions they must not impede competition and innovation—this is in not only the airline industry but obviously other industries as well—to the greatest extent practicable consistent with our national interests. Since March 1996, the National-Liberal government has increased capacity available for passenger services to and from Australia by the equivalent of no less than 338 Boeing 747s per week. In addition the government has negotiated air service arrangements where freight capacity between Australia and 20 of our bilateral partners is not constrained by government regulation. The government has also increased the capacity available for freight services in our other air service arrangements by the equivalent of 129 Boeing 747s per week.

The Anderson-Howard government believes that airlines should be given the best opportunity to get on with what they do best—that is, developing an attractive product for consumers based on their assessment of commercial demand. However, the system of bilateral arrangements between countries that govern international aviation acts is a serious impediment to this objective. Among other restrictions it imposes national ownership and control restrictions to regulate entry to the international aviation market. In principle at least an airline can be unilaterally barred from a route if either of the two countries that are parties to a bilateral agreement is not satisfied that the airline is substantially owned and effectively controlled by citizens of the other party to the agreement. To meet these international obligations Australian law contains statutory limits on ownership and control of our airlines. Necessarily, while most of the world's aviation is regulated in this way, Australia will keep the essential element of such a policy—that is, a 49 per cent limit on foreign ownership.

For countries like Australia, this type of policy comes at a cost. This is due to the fact that Australia has a relatively small domestic capital market, and we have heard other speakers speak on that in this morning's debate. The ownership and control rules mean that expansion by our international airlines can be assisted by drawing on foreign investment to a limited degree only. In this most cyclical of industries, the bilateral rules encourage using high levels of debt, rather than obtaining equity, to fund long-term expansion. As a result, the Anderson-Howard government decided last year to liberalise access to foreign equity for Australian airlines. The 49 per cent ownership and control limit is, of necessity, something we will retain. The bilateral rules require it, and we prefer that Australian international airlines remain demonstrably Australian. But the subsidiary restrictions that exist currently in the Air Navigation Act 1920 are an unnecessary impediment to maintaining as large an Australian owned presence as possible in the international market.

The current rules mean that no more than 35 per cent, in aggregate, of equity in an Australian international airline can be held by foreign airlines, with a limit of 25 per cent of equity to be held by an individual foreign airline. The Aviation Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) 2000 therefore simplifies the ownership restrictions in Australia's international airlines. Let me emphasise that, as far as ownership is concerned, the simple requirement will be that no more than 49 per cent foreign ownership in an international carrier will be permitted, with no distinction between foreign airlines and other foreign investors.

The clear objective overall is that our international airlines remain clearly Australian. The government will still require them to be headquartered here and to retain the core elements of the international aviation business here in Australia. But the need for sustainable ownership structures, rather than ramshackle mechanisms designed to suit regulations from a different era, will be at the heart of these reforms. If we want to retain our substantial presence in international aviation, we are going to have to give our airlines every chance to attract long-term investors and partners. As I stated previously, the bill will not include Qantas. The reason for this is that, at the time Qantas was fully privatised in 1995, undertakings were provided to the Australian people by the previous Labor government that determined how the privatised entity would be owned. Accordingly, the National-Liberal government does not propose to change the ownership and control rules for Qantas without separate public consideration.

The second function of this amendment bill is to amend the Sydney Airport Curfew Act. The Sydney Airport Curfew Act is fundamental to the management of the airport's noise. Sydney is Australia's busiest jet airport, and the surrounding suburbs are overflown by large numbers of aircraft during the day. However, the night-time is the most sensitive time for noise, and the government is committed to ensuring that the community is protected as far as possible from disturbance during this period. This side of the House is proud of its record on the Sydney airport curfew. Some members of the opposition may recall that the Sydney Airport Curfew Act 1995 came into existence only because of a private member's bill introduced in June 1995 by the present Prime Minister, when he was Leader of the Opposition, who forced the then Labor government to take some action. This act has proved very successful in controlling night-time aircraft movements over the suburbs. Due to this, we are not prepared to see these gains eroded by international airlines breaching the curfew laws.

Last year, for the first time since the act came into effect, a company was prosecuted for breaching the curfew, and there have been three alleged curfew breaches since then. Evidence produced before the court indicated that the fines currently imposed by the act are not acting as a sufficient deterrent. It has become clear that, in some cases, it would be cheaper for an airline to break the curfew and pay the fine than to hold an aircraft on the ground overnight. For example, assume that an airline's daily 747-400 service from Sydney was not ready to leave until after the start of the curfew at 11 p.m. because the operating aircraft arrived late. The airline would have to find accommodation and meals for over 500 passengers, which could cost more than $125,000. The airline would also suffer the considerable cost of holding the aircraft on the ground overnight. In contrast, the maximum fine is only $110,000. The Anderson-Howard government is therefore proposing in the bill to increase the fine fivefold. The increase in the maximum penalty for Sydney airport curfew breaches would ensure that the penalty continues to deter airlines from breaking the law. This will bring the maximum fine for a curfew breach, at the current value of penalty units, to $550,000.

I believe this will indicate to aviation operators the seriousness with which the government treats breaches of the curfew. The rules of the curfew are clear: if an aircraft does not have approval to undertake an operation during the curfew, it must not take place. We are committed to maintaining peace for Sydney residents at night. It should also be noted that the bill has no financial implications. The increase in the maximum fine for breaching the Sydney airport curfew is a deterrent, not a revenue raiser.

Madam Deputy Speaker Crosio, as you can understand, air travel in this vast country is imperative for travel both in and around Australia and internationally. I come from a rural and regional area of New South Wales, the New England. The gateway to the rest of Australia and the world by air is via Sydney. As I mentioned before, tourism is now Australia's largest single export industry, with export earnings of $16.3 billion. The overwhelming majority of our visitors arrive and depart on aircraft, and international air services also carried over $53 billion worth of freight to and from Australia last year. Of that, Sydney accounted for 49 per cent of total passenger traffic and for 52.7 per cent of total freight traffic in and out of Australia during the years 1998 and 1999. Madam Deputy Speaker, as you would be more than aware, at the moment there is much debate on the issue of regional airlines and their access to Kingsford Smith airport. I would like to make it very clear that the people of New England require easy access to the Sydney CBD, which is provided through Kingsford Smith airport base services. Businessmen, businesswomen and travellers need to be able to catch their connecting flights without having to catch a bus, train or cab from one airport to another. I notice that the Minister for Trade has entered the chamber. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

talk.start.para: —by leave—I table the government's fourth annual Trade Outcomes and Objectives Statement, or TOOS as it is commonly known. TOOS is a practical demonstration of the coalition government's determination to lift our trade performance and to keep the Australian people fully informed of trade developments.

speech.para: This year's statement paints a promising picture for Australian exporters. Exports recovered through 1999 from the effects of the East Asian economic crisis with total exports rising, in trend terms, in each of the last eight months of the year. The February 2000 trade figures released last Thursday confirmed what is now a 10-month trend, with exports 15 per cent above their level of February 1999. One of the things that helped us through a tough trading environment last year was the diversified base of Australian exports. As the TOOS outlines, Australian exports are now divided fairly equally across agriculture, minerals, manufactures and services. And while low commodity prices and a stronger Australian dollar took the edge off our traditional commodity exports in 1999, exports of services and manufactures were each up by six per cent.

The international economic outlook described in this year's statement is the best we have seen since the start of the East Asian economic crisis. Forecasters expect a more balanced level of growth among the major economic regions, and a global economic growth rate exceeding three per cent. Growth in world trade is forecast to strengthen to over six per cent in 2000, up by more than two percentage points on the previous two years. All this is very good news for Australian exporters, particularly the boost from increasing demand in East Asia and recovery in the region's exports. Australia's exports to East Asia are now growing strongly, up 37 per cent on their level of a year ago. But to take advantage of these developments, Australia must maintain its competitive edge.

The very fact that Australia was able to outperform almost every other OECD country during the Asian economic crisis shows just how far the government has moved our country towards the cutting edge of global competitiveness. The government will be looking to make Australia's competitive position even stronger through the introduction of the new tax system on 1 July. Our total reform package, including the GST and reforms to the business tax system, will stimulate stronger investment and boost growth in key export sectors. The abolition of the old wholesale sales tax and state taxes, as well as reform of fuel excises, will lift a $3.5 billion burden from the shoulders of Australian exporters.

Our political opponents still have no policy alternative. For example, they have no alternative to offer the owner of Malibu Boats in Albury, who told me in February that, with the implementation of the GST on 1 July 2000, he will be able to sell his boats at 1997 prices.
TOOS 2000 outlines how the coalition government will continue our highly successful, multipronged strategy of boosting the sales of Australian goods and services on world markets.

The World Trade Organisation remains the primary vehicle for Australia to advance its broadly based and geographically diverse trade interests. The government remains committed to launching a new market access focused round of multilateral trade negotiations at the earliest opportunity. In the meantime, we are pushing ahead on the mandated WTO negotiations on services and agriculture and will be working towards the incorporation of these negotiations in a broader WTO round. Our WTO agenda also involves improvement of our capacity to utilise the dispute settlement process and our negotiations on bringing new members into the WTO.

Australia continues to actively pursue its rights and defend its interests in WTO dispute settlement processes. In 1999, complaints were initiated by Australia against US safeguard measures on lamb and Korean restrictions on imported beef. We now have a WTO panel established in the lamb case, and next month we will receive the panel report on the Korea beef case. We continue to work for mutually satisfactory outcomes on cases relating to automotive leather and salmon.

Australia stands to reap big gains from the expanded membership of the WTO. Late last week, Australia reached an in-principle agreement on market access for Saudi Arabia's joining of the WTO. This deal provides the basis for export growth beyond the $1 billion per year mark achieved for the first time in 1999. It builds on our success in concluding market access negotiations with nine trading partners last year, most importantly China.

Regionally, we also have a busy calendar in the coming year. APEC offers opportunities for rebuilding political momentum for a WTO round, and for advancing our business oriented agenda on such issues as reducing compliance costs, improving the ease of business travel, improving access to information and developing sensible and transparent regulatory environments. Australia will have an important opportunity to advance our Asia-Pacific trade agenda this year when I host the APEC trade ministers meeting in Darwin in June.

The proposal for a free trade area by 2010 between the ASEAN countries and the closer economic relations, CER, partners—Australia and New Zealand—is a key priority this year. My predecessor, the Hon. Tim Fischer, is doing an excellent job as Australia's representative on the AFTA-CER task force, which will report its recommendations in October this year. I also welcome the enthusiastic endorsement this proposal has received from Australian business groups.

This year we will continue the bilateral strategies to increase Australian exports that have been the hallmark of our government's trade policies. I have already led a successful visit by an Australian trade delegation to Bahrain, Kuwait, Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates in the Middle East, and visits to other key markets are planned for later this year. The Market Development Task Forcewill continue to coordinate a whole of government approach to areas of significant export potential for Australia and market access teams in the automotive, textile, clothing and footwear, information industries, processed foods and agriculture sectors will pursue new opportunities in 2000.

Austrade continues to play a major role in promoting Australian products abroad, and in helping Australian companies identify and take advantage of international opportunities. In particular, Austrade has broadened its operations into rural and regional Australia through the innovative Tradestartand ExportAccessprograms, giving those outside metropolitan areas the chance to move their businesses into international markets. Austrade is also helping Australian firms position themselves for the growth of e-commerce. The Export Finance and Insurance Corporation, EFIC, will continue to complement activities of the commercial market by providing exporters with a range of internationally competitive insurance and finance products.

The importance of international trade to regional Australia and of exporters in regional Australia to our national trade effort are key messages from this year's TOOS. Regional Australia has around one-third of Australia's work force, and generates more than half of our exports. One in four jobs in regional Australia depend on exports, compared to a figure of around one in five jobs nationally. To make this important information more widely known in our community, my department will be issuing a series of brochures for individual regions across Australia this year, which will highlight a number of successful exporters in each region. They illustrate the importance of exporters in local economies, as well as how the government's efforts to open up overseas markets can benefit individual regions.

The 2000 Trade Outcomes and Objectives Statement strongly reaffirms the government's commitment to an outward looking and internationally competitive trading position for Australia. The effort put in by our exporters, in the cities and in the bush, demands the recognition and enthusiastic support of all Australians. TOOS 2000 shows how our government aims to boost export opportunities for Australia, and to win greater market access at every level—multilaterally, regionally and bilaterally. The statement is an indispensable tool for anyone who wants to learn more about Australia's present and future trade environment. I commend it to the House, and I present the following paper:

quote.para: Trade Outcomes and Objectives Statement 2000—Ministerial Statement, 5 April 2000.

talk.start.para: —by leave—I would like to be able to stand up today and say that all is well with Australia's trade. I would like to be able to note that the thousands of businesses that export and the 1.7 million workers whose jobs depend on exports had been well looked after by this government. But I cannot. Australia's trade today is in a parlous state. Figures released earlier this year show that we actually exported less in 1998-99 than in 1997-98. The Trade Outcomes and Objectives Statement says something similar. Exports dropped by three per cent or more than $2 million. This was the first fall in exports for at least 20 years—that is, the first fall in exports since the days when Malcolm Fraser was Prime Minister and John Howard was his Treasurer.

speech.para: The result is a record trade deficit. In 1999, Australia recorded its biggest ever trade deficit by a substantial margin. The gap between our imports of goods and services and our exports has now grown to $16 billion. We currently have a trade minister who, last Thursday, put out a press release headed `Good trade figures' just because the monthly deficit had snuck below $1 billion. This is a government which prides itself on good economic management so-called, yet when it comes to trade its record is so woeful that it has to resort to moving the goalposts. Under the Howard government, apparently, good trade figures mean anything less an a $1 billion monthly trade deficit.

When we look at the detail the problem becomes even more disturbing. In the case of our agricultural exports, processed food fell faster than unprocessed food. In manufactures, elaborately transformed manufactures fell faster than simply transformed manufacturers. Under the Howard government, our exports are being dumbed down. We are moving from the fastest growing areas of world trade, the elaborately transformed manufactures, to the more slowly growing areas of world trade, the simplify transformed and unprocessed areas. The fall in Australia's clever exports is hardly surprising when two other statistics are taken into account. Under this government, total Commonwealth spending on education has decreased by more than $500 million, down from 1.99 per cent to 1.9 per cent of GDP. Government and business expenditure on R&D, research and development, has fallen in absolute terms since the Howard government came to power. Australia's chief scientist predicts that, without a change of policy, our overall expenditure on research and development will fall further, from 1.7 per cent of GDP in 1998 to 1.4 per cent of GDP in 2002, whilst that of Korea, Finland and the United States will remain at 3.2, 3 and 2.8 per cent respectively. With diminishing spending on education, training, research and development, is it really any surprise that our smart exports are falling the fastest?

Turning to the current account, the figures only get worse. Our current account deficit for 1999 was $34.6 billion—another record. Our current account deficit is not just a national record; this time the Howard government goes one better. Each week, as we all know, the Economist publishes a table on its second last page listing, amongst other things, the current account deficits for 15 developed countries. Australia's current account deficit puts us in last place. The Economist also includes a poll of its forecasters for 2001. Again, we are placed dead last. Our current account deficit is officially the worst in the developed world.

I want to turn now to say something about APEC because we have a serious problem in this country, which is the Howard government's declining interest in APEC. It seems to have occurred largely because the government takes APEC for granted. A decade ago, it took a bold initiative by the previous government to create APEC, and the Howard government seems to have forgotten that, without APEC, Australia's economic and strategic future in the Asia-Pacific would be profoundly different. APEC demonstrates our commitment to our closest neighbours. It brings the region's leaders together each year, building the personal relationships that are so critical to creating a safer, more prosperous world. Perhaps most importantly of all, it commits APEC members to the path of openness.

A critical step for APEC was the 1994 Bogor declaration, in which members committed to achieving free trade and investment. Under Labor the countries of the Asia-Pacific committed to economic integration, not isolation. But it is always important to reiterate that integration is not inevitable. It was a choice that our region made six years ago and one that can still be reversed. The Bogor declaration itself and the annual leaders meetings that drove that and that drive APEC are now in jeopardy. Australia used to be one of the key driving forces behind APEC; now we find the Prime Minister and the Minister for Trade seem content to let it languish. Without new impetus from the nation that pushed for APEC's creation, the next few years may see member countries start to find excuses for not meeting the Bogor targets.

Inaction could also lead to the cessation of the annual leaders meetings. After the failures of recent years, leaders may soon ask themselves, `Why bother?' A key question for Australia is: will the next US President—whichever of the two candidates is successful, George W. Bush or Al Gore—continue to devote two days every year to a forum that seems to have lost its way? It is vitally important to Australia that the answer to that question is yes.

The other body of critical importance to Australia is the World Trade Organisation, and in the time available I want to focus now on that. It is worth noting how little this government did in the lead-up to last November's Seattle WTO meeting. Despite our key position as a permanent chair of the Cairns Group, Mr Howard rebuffed calls from President Clinton to travel to Seattle to help make the meeting a success. Mr Howard was so disengaged from the process that he did not publicly mention the WTO once in the whole week leading up to the Seattle meeting. Let us make it clear: this government, the Prime Minister and the trade minister are not responsible for the failure of Seattle to launch a new round—that is obvious—but they certainly did not do much to help it succeed. If it had succeeded, not much of the credit would have flowed to Australia.

Following the shambles at Seattle, negotiations on agriculture and services began in early February 2000, but any substantial boost for our exporters will clearly have to wait until a new WTO round commences. Labor is again detecting a real sense of pessimism in the Howard government. In public, they proclaim that they are doing everything they can to initiate new negotiations, but it seems in private they are saying that there is no point in doing anything until after the presidential election in November. As much is clear from today's Trade Outcomes and Objectives Statement, which provides commentary on Seattle but no plan for the future.

This is a fundamental mistake. Whatever the complexion of the new president and the administration, they are likely to be favourably disposed to a new round. In reality, the biggest hurdle standing before a new round is coming to grips with the needs of the developing countries. They comprise around two-thirds of the WTO's 135 members, and their message at Seattle was clear: `No round until we are satisfied it will be on terms that provide us with a greater expectation of growth than did the Uruguay Round.'

The Howard government needs to start urgently coming to terms with the developing country agenda if a new round is to be launched. This requires listening to leaders from Africa, Asia and Latin America. It means promoting plans like the one proposed in UNCTAD in February to remove all tariffs on exports from the world's 48 least developed countries. It means taking some serious steps, whether it is that step or some other, to build the capacity of developing countries to participate and conduct trade negotiations to see that there is benefit for them from a new global round.

The other specific aspect of the WTO that is of importance to Australia is the question of China's entry. The government should be doing more to speed up China's entry into the WTO. Anybody who has studied it, including the minister and his department, knows that China's accession will bring direct economic benefits—perhaps as much as $10 billion per year—to Australia. Industrial tariffs will come down from an average of 24 per cent in 1997 to 10 per cent in 2004. Agricultural tariffs will fall from 31 per cent to 14 per cent. There will be better access in areas like banking, law, accounting, construction and telecommunications, and there will be intangible benefits as we integrate China with the rest of the world, strengthen the hands of the economic reformers and open up opportunities for more democracy and more freedom.

Today's statement suggests that Australia's responsibility for bringing China into the WTO ended when we concluded our bilateral negotiations. This is utterly myopic. At a Chatham House meeting in London last Friday, my colleague Senator Cook said that the Howard government should be doing more to bring negotiations between the European Union and China back on track. The government needs to send this clear message to Europe through our diplomatic channels: bringing China into the WTO is too important to be left solely to the trade negotiators. We should be sensitive to the severe internal strains that China's domestic reforms are causing and do all we can to bring the world's most populous nation into the WTO as speedily as possible.

In conclusion, the Labor Party and the opposition welcome this year's Trade Outcomes and Objectives Statement. We hope that this will be the year when the government gets serious about turning around our record trade deficit and our current account deficit. The best place to start would be with the key multilateral bodies, APEC and the WTO. Let us hope that 2000 will be the year when APEC is brought out of the doldrums and new WTO talks are launched with China at the table. Perhaps then Australia will not break too many more records before next year's Trade Outcomes and Objectives Statement.

talk.start.para: —In support of the Aviation Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) 2000, I say that businessmen and businesswomen and travellers need to be able to catch their connecting flights without having to catch a bus, train or cab from one airport to another. The people of regional New South Wales deserve to have the same access to Sydney as domestic and international travellers have. It is unfair to force them to bear the additional costs and inconvenience of using another airport, such as Bankstown. Rural and regional Australia is resentful of the withdrawal of services from their communities, particularly by state governments and others. Earlier this year the Prime Minister made a promise not to withdraw any more services from regional Australia. If regional airlines are pushed out of Kingsford Smith airport, then the communities of rural and regional New South Wales would consider this a breach of promise.

speech.para: However, this government has made rural and regional New South Wales a series of promises about retaining regional access to Sydney airport. In the 1996 campaign, there was a promise that special slots at Kingsford Smith airport would be set aside for regional airlines, to guarantee that the residents of country New South Wales would continue to have convenient access to Sydney airport. Again, in the 1998 election campaign we gave the commitment, and the coalition has ensured, that regional airlines would have access to Sydney airport. Only the coalition, through the legislated slot system, has guaranteed access to Sydney airport for regional operators, a pledge that Labor was never prepared to make, let alone deliver.

It is interesting to note that the original suggestion that the regional airlines should move out to Bankstown did not come from this government but from the New South Wales Tourism Taskforce, a body of the New South Wales state Labor government. The Sydney Airport Corporation Ltd is the other body that suggested that regional airlines should be at Bankstown airport and not at KSA. They claimed that `regional communities have a genuine opportunity to turn a regional airport at Bankstown into a successful aeronautical and business facility that they can call their own.' My response is that we already have an airport that we call our own. It is Kingsford Smith airport. We have as much right to use it as anyone else has. Forcing regional airlines to Bankstown can have a disastrous impact on some air services. For example, Hazelton has pointed out that its routes are stagnant. The airline is concerned that a move to Bankstown would damage its passenger flows, that it would not be able to sustain the level of services that it currently provides.

My view is that Badgerys Creek has to be built, and the sooner the better. I take comfort from the words of the member for Werriwa, who also stated that this has gone on for long enough. It is over a decade since Badgerys Creek was first talked about. The National Party is again leading the way on this very important issue for regionally based people. In conclusion, the aviation industry in Australia is growing at a rapid rate. It is imperative that we allow it to grow and encourage Sydney airport to become the gateway to the Asia-Pacific. However, in doing so, it is important that we do not push regional airlines out of Kingsford Smith airport and that the curfew at Kingsford Smith airport should remain in force.

talk.start.para: —It is not often that I stand up in this parliament and agree with members of the National Party, but I found a lot of sense in what the member for New England said in some of his remarks on the Aviation Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) 2000, in particular his remarks about Sydney (Kingsford Smith) Airport and the curfew there. We are reaching now a very important phase of decision making on airports in Sydney and there is no doubt that, if the Badgerys Creek airport is not built, Sydney airport will become very constrained in its operations, that there will be problems for people from regional areas and the curfew will be put at risk. Those things would be most unacceptable. I will come back to that later on in my remarks.

speech.para: The bill that is before us today makes some sensible changes to Australia's international aviation policy. It will simplify the ownership rules applying to Australia's international airlines—that is, other than Qantas, which of course has its own legislation. The simple requirement will be that 49 per cent of an Australian international airline can be owned by foreign persons. Currently the law limits ownership to no more than 25 per cent for an individual foreign airline and no more than 35 per cent in total for all foreign airlines owning part of an Australian airline.

The minister and the government claim that liberalising the foreign ownership restrictions will increase the freedom of Australian international airlines to expand and compete in international markets. We all hope that this happens, but it will also mean that there is a real possibility that up to 49 per cent of an Australian international airline will be owned by one or more foreign airlines. So, for those Australians who would like to see these businesses as Australian, there will be some disappointment. But, realistically, to compete internationally our airlines need to be able to access global equity capital, and even though the capacity for foreign ownership is being increased the minister has stated that the overall objective is that our international airlines remain clearly Australian. The minister has said that they still will be required to have their headquarters here and retain the core elements of the international aviation business here. We would all hope that that happens. Indeed, the opposition's second reading amendment expresses our concern about this aspect of the government's plans. We do not want jobs and services in Australia to be lost as a result of this legislation.

I must say I am concerned about my own position in particular because a lot of my constituents work at Sydney airport and a lot of them work for Qantas's maintenance operation at Sydney airport. I well remember a meeting that I had some years ago with Qantas executives about the building of Badgerys Creek airport. The Qantas people expressed a strong desire that they should not have to go to Badgerys Creek and, indeed, that if they had to do that they might think about taking some of their maintenance work offshore. It struck me as rather bizarre that one of the strong arguments they were putting to me was that the reason that the government—and it was a Labor government at the time—should be supportive of them and not make them go to Badgerys Creek if the airport was built was that they were good Australians. But then they had the little blackmail trick: `If you do make us do that, maybe we'll have to take our maintenance work offshore.' So much for being good Australians.

One of the concerns that we as the opposition have is that if the government does allow foreign airlines to own a larger slice of Australian international airlines there will be pressure for this to happen. Qantas and Ansett will be the two main targets—Ansett through Air New Zealand and Qantas through British Airways. We would be very concerned if, by giving airlines access to greater capital, we saw the movement of Australian jobs offshore. I think that goes a long way to ensuring that Australian airlines have a good safety record because the staff that we have here—the skilled technicians and tradesmen who maintain aircraft in Australia—maintain them to that very high international level. Except for Qantas's recent problem, they have maintained probably the best record of the flag carriers of any country in the world.

Under this legislation Australian international airlines will be at least 51 per cent owned by Australians, so there is a balance to be struck between the desire to have our own industry and the industry's future viability. To be sustained into the future, airlines need the opportunity to attract long-term investors and partners from overseas.
