Let us hope that by increasing the percentage that foreign persons or corporations can own we will get the balance right, but with that strong interest in ensuring that the trade-off for the increase in foreign capital and equity is not that we export Australian jobs. There is a pressing reason for this legislation at the moment, and that is Air New Zealand's recently announced purchase of the News Ltd equity in Ansett. If the changes to the legislation are not made and Air New Zealand proceeded with its purchase, Ansett Holdings would have to divest itself of 24 per cent of its equity in Ansett International.

The bill also proposes amendments to the Sydney Airport Curfew Act, which is a matter that is very close to my heart and, I was pleased to hear, the heart of the member for New England as well. It is obvious to anyone who represents an electorate around Sydney airport that for some time the maximum fines imposed by the curfew act were not much of a deterrent to airline operators. Airlines were happy to breach the curfew and pay a fine rather than be forced to meet the other expenses incurred by delaying flights, such as paying for overnight accommodation for passengers. It was obviously cheaper for them to break the curfew and pay the fine, so the imposition of a curfew was becoming useless. Those living under or near the flight paths still had to suffer the disturbance of noise, and there was a deliberate flouting of the rules by many of the airlines.

I think we would all agree that it is pretty obvious that something needed to be done to give the imposition of the curfew rules some teeth; otherwise there is no point in having a curfew. Of course, the airlines would hope that we did not have a curfew. One of the problems with not building Badgerys Creek airport will be that Sydney will saturate and there will be a lot of pressure to bust the curfew. What makes living around the airport at least somewhat sane is the fact that we do have a curfew. If the curfew goes, life for people who live around Sydney airport—about 20 per cent of the Sydney population live in close proximity to Sydney airport—would become unbearable. If Boeing 747s are able to land at Sydney airport at two and three in the morning, hundreds of thousands of people will be greatly disturbed because, as members probably know, night-time noise is a lot more disturbing for people than daytime noise; the level of ambient noise in the daytime blocks out a lot of the noise. There is the well-known phenomenon that, if you live anywhere near a railway, you hear the trains in the night and wonder where they have gone in the daytime. They are there in the daytime but you do not hear them because of the ambient noise that is around. But you hear them a lot in the night-time. The landing of aircraft—particularly one that hits reverse thrust—late in the night or early in the morning will make life unbearable, so the curfew is one of the most important tools for the people who live around the airport.

In relation to increasing the penalty, under the act a corporate operator of an aircraft which takes off or lands during the curfew without permission will now be subject to a fine of up to $550,000, which I hope will dissuade airlines from breaking the curfew. Only those who choose to breach the curfew will be affected by this measure. It will not be about safety. This will require a conscious decision on the part of operators; they will know the consequences of their actions in advance—and the persistent breaking of a curfew is not only a problem with Sydney airport. Sydney is our busiest jet airport. As I said earlier, it is going to become a lot busier. Can honourable members imagine what it will be like living around Sydney airport as we get closer to the Olympics? The strains on the airport will be immense and the strains on the people living around it will be even greater.

It is timely that we consider the topic of Sydney airport and of another airport for Sydney. According to the reports in the media, cabinet is continuing to struggle with this issue. We have seen some outflow of that here today in that there seems to be quite considerable argument within the government among members of the National Party and also rural Liberals, those who want to see rural people have access to Sydney airport and those who have electorates around Badgerys Creek. What we should do about a second airport for Sydney and where it should be located are issues that have been around for 30 years. Any time I talk about the issue of Sydney airport, I am reminded of my first foray into public life, which was in 1971—nearly 30 years ago—when I was elected a councillor of Marrickville Council. One of the arguments in that local government campaign at that time was the reduction of aircraft noise from Sydney airport. This matter has been around nearly all my life. One of my colleagues once said to me, `There is always another election in Sydney airport.' Ten years ago I thought he was wrong. I am starting to think that there may always be another election in Sydney airport and that the only real constant of my public life will be the speeches that I have made about Sydney airport.

However, it is reaching the point of scandal that we have put this off for so long. During the Fraser government years, the MANS committee report—on the major airport needs of Sydney—identified sites. The sites were jigged, rejigged, moved around and there were all sorts of arguments. Finally, a Labor government bit the bullet and purchased land out at Badgerys Creek. Interestingly, some of the people who are now opposed to that were the main proponents of that airport. I am very mindful of the argument put forward earlier by the member for Werriwa, who said that the important thing about another airport for Sydney out in the western suburbs is to provide employment. I have always had a view about Sydney airport which is a little bit different from those of some of the community activists out there. I want to bring Sydney airport under control. I most certainly do not want to have it closed. The bizarre idea that was floated a few years ago—that we should close Sydney airport and build some mega-airport somewhere else in New South Wales—was an absolutely ridiculous proposal. A great number of the people in my electorate work at Sydney airport. The jobs that a lot of those people have are such that, if the airport moved or closed, they would not transport themselves with the jobs. The greatest job magnet that the western suburbs of Sydney can have is an airport. The 30,000 jobs estimated to be generated by the Badgerys Creek airport is something that the people of the western suburbs certainly need because there is a high level of unemployment there.

When we also consider the number of people who will be affected by the Badgerys Creek airport versus the number of people who are severely affected by aircraft noise at Sydney already, those numbers are minuscule. There will be very few people severely affected by noise at the Badgerys Creek airport. There are—not `there will be'—tens of thousands of people severely affected by aircraft noise at Sydney airport. It is also not reasonable to say that the people near Sydney airport knew this airport was there when they bought their houses. The week before last I received a phone call at my office from a pensioner in Bexley. She had lived in Bexley for about 60 years. When she and her husband bought their house, Sydney airport was nothing like the airport it is now and aircraft certainly were not flying what appear to be only 100 metres above her house. She is right at the end of the east-west runway.

When I grew up in Marrickville, my wife and her family lived in Hanks Street in Ashfield, which is just at the top of the street from where we live now. She and my sister went to school together, so I used to see a lot of her before we even started going out together. Aircraft never flew over her place when she was a girl. But we live 300 metres from where she grew up and aircraft fly over our place all the time now. So it is an unfair proposition to say, as some people are saying, `The only people who are whingeing about Sydney airport are those who bought properties there recently.' There have been dramatic changes in the way Sydney airport has worked and there have been dramatic changes for the people who have been there for a long while.

There is another dramatic change on the horizon—the precision radar monitoring system. If the Federal Airports Corporation gets the chance to install that equipment at Sydney airport—and that is still a little bit up in the air because there is an inquiry going on into that at present—and that system is implemented, it will have a twofold effect. It will allow a greater throughput of aircraft into Sydney airport but it will also reinstall what was claimed to be a very bad system, introduced by the previous Labor government, of flying on direct tracks into Sydney airport. Those people who want to look at the situation have to understand that you cannot share the noise and have a precision landing system; they are mutually inconsistent. I have been interested in this issue long enough to understand that the aviation industry and the aviation bureaucracy probably had their policies set in concrete when we had the precursor to the old Department of Civil Aviation. The one experience I have had with them is that, if you give them an inch, they will take a mile. They might say that this precision radar system will allow safer landings in bad weather, and that is true, but the other side of the coin is that it will allow more landings and it will direct those landings on a particular, narrow bandwidth. I have no doubt that, if the aviation industry is allowed this leg in the door, it will not be too long before the system that the current government put in place—sharing the noise—reverts to the old system of flying along the train tracks north and south of Sydney airport. People should take a lot of care about that.

The two things that make living around Sydney airport bearable are the movements cap on Sydney airport and the curfew. The precision radar monitoring mechanism is one which will go some way towards busting the movements cap. There is no doubt that the increase in fines for busting the curfew might at least make operators think twice before breaking the curfew. But the only real solution to the aircraft needs of Sydney—and the aircraft needs of Sydney are very much the air transport needs of Australia—is another airport. Bankstown is not the solution—I have no doubt my colleague the member for Blaxland will talk about that at some length—and kicking the regional operators out of Sydney is also not the solution. The people from the bush have as much right of access to the CBD as do people from Melbourne and Brisbane. We need the government to bite the bullet and do it now. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I think that we need to recognise the benefits of this Aviation Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) 2000. Sure, we are increasing the level of foreign ownership to 49 per cent and there will be no restrictions on airline ownership within the 49 per cent cap, but this bill will also increase the maximum fine for breaching the Sydney airport curfew from $110,000 to $550,000. This bill will ultimately benefit Australian international carriers by enabling them to gain capital and negotiate alliances. This means that Australian airlines will not be in danger of becoming undercapitalised or losing market share. It means that Qantas is still protected by the Qantas Sale Act, and so it should be.

speech.para: My extensive involvement within the New South Wales tourism industry puts me in a position of recognising the massive benefits that tourism brings to Australia, with an export value of in excess of $16.3 billion. Our economy-contributing visitors overwhelmingly arrive here by aircraft and then depart by aircraft. It is this arrival and departure routine that requires this legislation. It is in the interests of an airline to break curfews. This is why we must increase the maximum fine for breaching the Sydney airport curfew from $110,000 to $550,000. This breach also applies to regional airlines that might think about breaking the curfew, even though their propeller aircraft really have no impact on the noise limits and levels. However, in order to provide a vital and critical service to rural and regional areas, our smaller regional craft comply with the curfew on which they really do not have any impact. It is no secret that there are those who would force our regional airlines out of Kingsford Smith airport in order to make way for more jet aircraft. It may be that they use the carrot of additional tourism dollars to substantiate these moves. However, to move our regional craft out of KSA would serve only to substantially reduce investment in Australia's tourism industry. It must have access to regional carriers to ensure long-term domestic tourism growth. In fact, most reports on the issue of curfews and caps at KSA have been compiled by those with vested interests. There has been little contribution from independent informants.

Having looked at this legislation and at the increases in fines for breaches of the airport curfew contained within it, I have complete faith that in years to come noise levels at KSA will reduce substantially, given that with better technology we will have quieter aircraft and better climb rates. That is a better outlook than that for the regionals, who will be pushed out of KSA and will face a vastly reduced economic future—not to mention the impact on the lives of rural and regional people, particularly in New South Wales.

Perhaps the opposition's acceptance of this Aviation Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) would be assisted by the installation of a parallel runway monitor. This would certainly assist by giving incentives to airlines not to break curfews. This in turn would assist the regionals in their fight to retain their slots at KSA as against being moved to Bankstown or any other option. The irony of this move is that we would have a substantial curfew fine applying not only to the suburbs around KSA; we would also need one around Bankstown. Quite clearly, regional airlines in the main do not want to lose their slots and be forced out to Bankstown. Bankstown residents do not want regionals at their airport. More jets will not be the ultimate benefit to KSA, as the curfew and the cap will prevent any additional noise, and we should remember that regionals and propellers do not create a significant noise factor at KSA.

The future of regional New South Wales's economic development hinges on reliable and frequent access to KSA. Regeneration of rural and regional areas will not occur if this access to the KSA curfew is denied. There may very well be some carriers that choose to operate additional flights in and out of Bankstown that are not related to their current access. This is certainly an option open to them. Perhaps our legislation should be looking at gaining more efficiencies at KSA in order to relieve some of the financial burdens related to aviation that the government is currently grappling with.

Convincing the passengers from rural and regional Australia that they should be relegated to a second-level airport in favour of metropolitan and international travellers is going to be enormously difficult, particularly when regional tourism is on the increase and its relationship with the domestic tourism dollar is undeniable. Just as this legislation is looking to protect the people of Sydney from excess noise levels, with the proposed maximum fine for breaching the curfew, others would look to increase this burden of noise on Sydney's people by relegating regionals to Bankstown, thereby opening the skies for heavier jets and much more noise. The simple fact is that more aeroplanes cannot be put into the Sydney basin without an increase in noise and without a greater risk of the curfew being broken.

There has also been no consultation with the community and suburbs of Kurnell and others to the south of KSA as to the moving of regional airlines out of their living areas to allow even noisier aircraft to replace them. A recent survey that was conducted at the Wagga Wagga airport has concluded that at least 48 per cent of travellers would be disadvantaged by a move to Bankstown as they would then need to join another flight. Without some massive expenditure on ground travel infrastructure, the 62 per cent of travellers going to the city and eastern suburbs would have their travel time increased significantly, thereby again impacting on rural and regional people.

The previous speaker spoke in significant terms of the curfew and the incentives to break the curfew. At the end of the day, there is a simple answer to Sydney's airport problems and curfew problems for the next 10 years to 15 years, and that is to allow the airport to operate at the capacity it is capable of handling and not to artificially constrain Australia's most significant national aviation asset. For the longer term, a new airport must be built and it needs all three areas of international, domestic trunk and regional services to be viable. I reiterate that there are no facts or proposals that are independent. We have studies paid for by vested interest parties; we have media leaks; and we have speculation, but never any facts. To ensure that our aviation industry maintains a strong presence, we must ensure that our airlines remain as competitive as possible.

talk.start.para: —This government are red in tooth and claw on social policy but when it comes to matters that can be easily addressed, as are in the Aviation Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) 2000, they are found extremely wanting. They are red in claw and tooth on social policy because they have attempted to make it their focus when speaking to the Australian people. Yet what is really important to them is effectively an American Republican agenda of social issues in which the Commonwealth parliament essentially plays no part; it is essentially state law and order issues. In the last few days of the parliament we have seen how the coalition have attempted to grapple with these issues and push these issues as if they were the main part of their agenda. Certainly, that has diverted their attention from what are critical matters of decision for the government. In relation to transport policy, and aviation policy in particular, the dilatoriness of this government is simply extraordinary. In the bill before us today, there are two key features. One is the ramping up of the penalties for breaking the curfew. That ramping up is almost five times—up to $550,000—for an airline that breaks the curfew. Since the original act came into place in relation to aircraft noise and the curfew, we have seen one transgression of the curfew. What came out of that was that $110,000 was not enough money to impose upon an airline to stop it breaking the curfew, because the airline took into account what it would cost it in accommodation for passengers, crew and so on.

speech.para: In September 1998, the Productivity Commission brought down a report which dealt with the matters that are germane to this bill. We have reached the year 2000 and we are well over 15 months from when that report was brought down. All we have seen with this legislation on aircraft noise—surely a simple decision for the Minister for Transport and Regional Services to make and a simple bill to write up to put before this parliament—is more than 15 months of delay. That is not unusual with this government when it comes to aviation policy. In fact, it is almost four years since the then Minister for Transport and Regional Development, the former member for Hume, raised the whole question of trying to avoid building the second airport in Sydney's west by putting Holsworthy in as a proposition. Some 12 to 18 months later—I think it was 18 months all up—after community consultations and an EIS that cost the Commonwealth more than $12 million, the absurdity of that proposal was blindingly exposed.

We on the Labor side had no difficulty with that outcome whatsoever. After I had been preselected for Blaxland, and almost the very day after that happened, there was the great announcement from the then minister that the government was going to look at Holsworthy despite the fact that it had been knocked out in 1985. For 18 months he followed a complete furphy, something that had no basis in fact. That proposition had been formed by a series of groups who were aviation junkies, who thought that they could come up with a way which meant the government would not have to spend significant amounts of money on a second Sydney airport. That finally folded when the minister had to walk into the Prime Minister's office and effectively say, `Prime Minister, the game's up. This thing can't go any further because it has been so comprehensively condemned by the EIS process.' That was a delay of 18 months, one that we did not need to have, in the determination of what should happen with aviation services in the Sydney basin.

This government is now struggling—absolutely struggling, step by step—to come to a final determination in relation to what should happen with Sydney's second airport. In this debate today we have heard members of the National Party attempt one by one to put forward the arguments as to why there should actually be a decision on this issue, and they have argued that it is timely. They have picked up Labor's argument that we have been running for four years. They have also argued that the latest diversion we have had on these issues—the question of whether Bankstown airport should be expanded or not—is not really a good idea. But it shows us just where the National Party comes in this government's pecking order. The very last people to get access to cabinet to put an argument on these issues are members of the National Party. Liberal Party members in Sydney had their go some time ago. All of the vested interest groups have had the ear of the minister for transport for some considerable time.

The minister for transport has been extremely slow to get this legislation, as simple as it is, before us today. On the one hand, the legislation increases the amount of curfew payments that have to be made by an airline breaching the curfew and argues quite rightly that it is extremely important to protect Sydney at night from the noise of jet aircraft coming in between 11 p.m. and 6 a.m. and, on the other hand, deals with an issue that simply has to be dealt with now and which has to come forward in legislation: the question of what is to happen to Ansett Airlines in terms of its ownership. Instead of the 35 per cent cap on foreign ownership of Ansett Airlines and instead of a 25 per cent cap on another international airline owning it, the proposed legislation, based on the Productivity Commission report, says, `What we need to look at now is a redefinition from foreign airlines to foreign persons so that a foreign person or persons may own up to 49 per cent of an Australian international carrier.'

What else has been put in train in this bill? What has been left out? Our shadow minister has indicated that the Labor Party, although we generally support the bill, consider that there are a number of things that the government has left out and that it should concentrate on what any good and responsible government applying itself directly to the tasks before it should concentrate on. In his amendment, the shadow minister asks that the government take into consideration the following:

quote.para: (1) Ansett Australia should remain headquartered in Australia—

speech.para: that is, if you sell up to 49 per cent of it off, you do not have it headquartered in New Zealand or Singapore or anywhere else—

quote.para: (2) a fair share of future growth in routes should be through Ansett International—

speech.para: so you do not lose the value of that—

quote.para: (3) high skilled, high value Ansett airlines jobs should remain in Australia—

speech.para: this is very important so that those jobs are not bleached out and taken to New Zealand—

quote.para: (4) Ansett jobs in regional and rural communities are not jeopardised by the sale; and—

speech.para: this bears on issues not really attacked by National Party members today in debate on the bill—

quote.para: (5) services to regional and rural communities should be preserved at current levels or improved.

speech.para: Having looked at the second reading speech by the minister, I find it passing strange that there is such a conjunction of jostling antipathies in the speech. What he is trying to do on the one hand is give bent to the essential ideology of the coalition that the whole of Australian aviation should be opened up to total, open competition. That is what it would prefer. That is what it would choose to do. In the international arena, if the Productivity Commission and this government had their way, there would be a wholesale dismantling of the present system of bilateral agreements. This is a government that is red in tooth and claw when it comes to the word `treaty'. The government does not like the word `treaty'. It does not like the word `treaty' when it comes to the International Convention on the Rights of the Child. It does not like the word `treaty' when it has anything to do with mandatory sentencing in the Northern Territory. It does not want to entertain any argument in relation to that. It is a government that, when in opposition, time after time attacked the Labor government for entering into treaties.

This minister said, `We want to open the whole thing up, but the bad international aviation community simply won't let us do this because it has a series of regulations.' Those regulations essentially say that for an airline to be a national carrier it has to have at least 51 per cent national ownership. So if Qantas and Ansett as Australian national carriers do not have 51 per cent ownership, other countries can refuse to allow them to land. These are a series of binding international agreements. Why are these international agreements binding? We have not been able to get into the United States domestic market or any other domestic market around the world because those markets are regulated against an outside entrant such as Qantas. Equally, despite the clear thought that this government would actually like to do something different in its open skies approach, it has not yet allowed other airlines free entry into our domestic market, and I hope that it never does. However, the minister did say:

quote.para: However, the system of bilateral arrangements between countries that govern international aviation acts as a serious impediment to this objective. Amongst other restrictions it imposes national ownership and control restrictions to regulate entry to the international aviation market. In principle at least, an airline can be unilaterally barred from a route if either of the two countries that are parties to a bilateral agreement is not satisfied that the airline is substantially owned and effectively controlled by citizens of the other party to the agreement.

speech.para: I actually find nothing wrong with binding, bilateral or multilateral agreements with regard to the aviation industry. It is a set of constraints under which we have to work, and it has worked reasonably well in the past. It is open to modification and change but not to this government unilaterally selling Australia down the tube—and even it has not gone that far in relation to this—by simply saying that there can be open slather in the ownership of Australian international airlines, because under the system that is there we would not have entry to another single country in the world for our national airlines because they would no longer be national airlines.

One of the key things that comes out of this, of course, is the impact on our domestic services, particularly in New South Wales. The minister is aware that there is a problem with the approach of this government. There is a problem with regard to regional services in Australia. Throughout a vast area of regional Australia Ansett provides services that Qantas does not. They are extremely important. The Labor opposition does not want to see those regional services imperilled. It is those very kinds of services that have brought people in the National Party into this parliament today to argue against the dopey idea the government has had of just loading up all regional services in New South Wales and whacking them into Bankstown. It is a dopey idea that has been used by the government, which has surreptitiously had the Sydney Airports Corporation and the Tourism Task Force and every odd bod it can find come up with arguments to say that Bankstown should be established as the regional airport for Sydney. This is an extremely stupid idea. This is as dopey as making Holsworthy the second airport for Sydney. That idea should have been knocked over in the first instance.

It was only about a month ago in the parliament that I, together with the members for Grayndler and Watson, essentially knocked over the Sydney Airports Corporation and got it pulled back into line by this minister. It was actually trying to run aviation policy. With some assistance from members of the coalition who were directly affected by this and had some knowledge of it, we actually got him to confirm the 80-an-hour cap at Kingsford Smith airport, we got him to confirm the importance of the curfew and we got him to belt the Sydney Airports Corporation around the ears for more than a week because it had completely stepped out of line. The problem was that it had been caught out publicly. It had actually been doing the government's silly work.

Conjoined with this the government, behind its hand, actually went out to the people who want to run a fast train from Sydney to Canberra. It went to that consortium and said, `You are working on this. What the government is essentially interested in here is not spending very much money on transport in Australia. While you are at it, will you please give us a study which shows how many more years it would be before we would need to build a second international airport in Sydney if the train ran between Melbourne, Canberra and Sydney, then added Brisbane in later on and all the configurations of that?' This is a dopey approach. It is entirely crazy and silly. A government that is red in tooth and claw on social policy has not been able to focus on sane and sensible solutions to Sydney's aviation problems.

This is a crazy idea, as vigorously, clearly and concisely argued by the environmental impact statement brought down for Sydney's second airport. An airport with 12 million passengers a year cannot be serviced by a fast train system, which is not fast enough anyway and which would be based outside Sydney. That volume cannot be serviced, except with a train every 12 minutes. At the maximum of 30 million passenger movements per year there would need to be a double-decker fast train operating once every three minutes from Goulburn, Newcastle or wherever. There would need to be a service once every three minutes to pull those people out of the airport and then bring them up to Sydney or take them off to somewhere else.

This government has been sucked in by the fast train group. First the group said that it did not want any public money. Then it said that $70 million would do, just to provide the corridors. It has now come to the government and said, `We will have to change things a bit. We actually need about $1 billion.' At least that is down on the $5 billion to $10 billion that another group thought it would need about a decade ago, but this government has been sucked in. The government has actually asked that group to provide it with the ammunition to say that there is no real need to build a second airport in Sydney. Every one of the National Party people belatedly speaking in this House on this issue, every one of those National Party people who were at the end of the queue to get the cabinet's ear on this, has been able to take their part in the debate directly from the arguments that the Labor Party has been putting forward for more than four years.

Sydney needs a second airport. That second airport has to be where the people are. If we do not build infrastructure where people are and where it can be used, we end up throwing our money right down the drain. It is as simple as that. It is not just a question of providing jobs in Sydney's west and south-west; it is about actually putting the facilities where the demand is. What the government has been inexorably dragged back to—it has been diverted in its approach to social policy—is that, if we are going to spend a lot of money on infrastructure, whether it be $4 billion or more, we actually have to finally make a decision. Four years on from being elected, finally, screaming and kicking and trying to divert itself by all the noises it has made about everything else, the government actually had to come close to making a decision on this.

One would hope that the infrastructure realities of Sydney have finally been hammered home to this transport minister and this reluctant government. It costs money to build a second Sydney airport. There is no use putting it where the people are not. There is no use in the government coming up with the Dodgy Brothers idea of off-loading all of the regional passengers that currently go to KSA, dumping them into Bankstown and hoping it can bodgie up the roads and install a bit of a rail connection, thinking that that will do the job.

This bill comes more than 15 months after the Productivity Commission's report. It is well over time—years over time—for this government to stop looking for corners to hide in, for it to stop utilising the diversions of being red in tooth and claw on social policy and actually deal with the fundamentals of Australian aviation policy, make a decision about Sydney's second airport and make the appropriate decision that will be right for the future of Australia, right for the people of Sydney and right for the country as a whole. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —An internationally competitive and environmentally sensitive civil aviation industry is central to this country's future economic development. It is equally central to the legitimate needs of that large number of Australian communities who live in areas adjacent to the nation's airports. Both of those sets of interests are the subject of the legislation currently before the House, the Aviation Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) 2000. It is for those reasons that I rise to speak in this debate and, in addition, because I represent in this place a community that is directly affected by the operations of the Brisbane airport and is, therefore, a community that has to deal with this daily balance between the broader economic requirements of the region and the state on the one hand and the direct impact on their social and environmental amenity on the other.

speech.para: This debate on the effect of airports on communities and on the future of the civil aviation industry in general is not unique to Australia; it is a global debate. It takes place in every large city in the world—in London, in Amsterdam and in San Francisco. That is because those local communities that feel the impact of airports are now exercising their legal rights and political power through the ballot box to maximise influence on governments to represent their interests in the `battle of interests' with the civil aviation industry. In such debates about the impact of airports on communities, often we are told—particularly those of us who represent constituencies who live in aircraft noise affected areas of the country—that anyone moving into such an area should employ the principle of buyer beware; that is, `Don't move there because it is aircraft noise affected and if you do so and you suffer some consequence in terms of social, environmental or financial amenity then tough! That is something that you brought on your own head. You cannot seek redress for that from government.' That is the overall logic of buyer beware.

I suggest an alternative approach, which is not buyer beware but airlines beware. I say that in consideration of the history of the evolution of the major cities of this nation. For example, I represent a community that is affected by Brisbane airport. A large number of the suburbs that are affected by Brisbane airport were constructed, settled and developed quite some years before the Wright brothers ever took off in the first place. In fact, that development occurred not a large number of years after the Montpellier brothers actually went aloft in their balloon. So this whole argument about historical precedent and who was there first needs to be born in mind.

For example, in my part of Brisbane the suburb of Bulimba was settled in 1850-60. The school at Bulimba has a shingle on it which says that the first class was attended there in 1861. Most of the other suburbs on the south side of Brisbane were settled some time before World War I, well before Qantas was even thought of. Practically all of the electorate I represent was well in place, well established and well developed before a decision was taken during World War II to establish Brisbane's principal airport facility at Eagle Farm. I think these questions of who was there first and the residual right of residents to express a legitimate view based on their long-term residence—and often that of their parents—is as relevant and germane to the debate as are the arguments advanced by the civil aviation industry about the impact of their operations on the broader economy.

For the information of the House, I point out that Brisbane airport is this nation's second largest airport. In terms of the annual number of movements through that airport, it is already larger than that of Melbourne and is somewhat larger than half the size of Sydney (Kingsford Smith) Airport. Based on current growth projections, in seven to 10 years time Brisbane airport will probably have the same number of flight movements each year as occur today at Sydney airport. However, unlike Sydney airport, Brisbane airport does not have a curfew. For that reason, it becomes doubly important to ensure that we have a proper approach to noise management through the Brisbane Airport Corporation, the Department of Transport and Regional Services and Airservices Australia. At present, noise management at Brisbane airport is coming a poor second.

Part of having a decent input from the community on these questions lies in having an effective mechanism through which the community's views can be obtained, through which the community can be consulted. When we look at the usual measures of aircraft noise which are used in the professional literature on aircraft noise and its impact on communities, we are invariably told that there is only one robust and reliable scientific measure, and that is the ANEF, the Australian noise exposure forecast. In terms of its measurement of actual noise impact on the ground, my advice to the House is that the ANEF is not worth a pinch of salt. The bottom line is that it might provide some annual average indication of where concentrations of aircraft noise and aircraft movements might occur, but as to its actual predictive ability to identify those houses, those streets, those suburbs, those localities, those schools, those churches, those nursing homes and those hospitals which are affected in a real way by aircraft noise, the ANEF system of measurement is next to useless.

I draw to the attention of the House the professional literature on this subject under the name of Professor Ted Duhs, from the Queensland University of Technology, who has made a professional study of the scientific reliability of the ANEF system and its predictive capacity vis-a-vis the actual noise impact on the ground. In fact, in this country the civil aviation industry—or, shall I say, community—is equally alert to the deficiencies of the ANEF measurement system. Only last week I was advised that Airservices Australia has now circulated for public discussion a new technical paper on the question of a possible replacement to the ANEF system for how better to measure noise and its real impact on communities in the future.

The fact that we have such an imperfect and fundamentally flawed system of measurement as the ANEF underlines the importance of having effective community input to the deliberations of government on noise impact on local communities—the real impact of standard instrument departures, the real impact of STARS, the real impact of ICOA A and B departure procedures and which particular areas are most affected at what times of day by the aggregate operations of an airport. In Brisbane, we have had a long history of establishing an appropriate mechanism through which the community's views can be obtained. This goes back some 10 years. Broadly, the convention has been this: at Brisbane, either side of the river, three elected members from the three levels of government—federal, state and local—each nominate their representative to be a member of the Brisbane Airport Environment Committee. That body brings together the views of local residents on how noise is affecting them as well as providing a recommendatory body which can provide advice to the government on what specific noise management measures need to be introduced.

This is not a recent innovation. This body has existed virtually since 1991. In that year, a report was prepared on `A Task Force to Review the Operations and Planning of Brisbane Airport and to Minimise the Impact of Aircraft Noise on Surrounding Communities'. That was its formal title. In fact, its formal title was so long it was never capable of yielding itself an acronym. So we simply refer to it as the 1991 noise report. Had an acronym been invented, it would probably have been somewhat longer than the average length of the name of a Welsh rural village. The 1991 noise report noted that `Community representatives were nominated by their respective members of parliament'—that is, community members participating in the task force which put together that report, the report in turn making fundamental recommendations about future noise management at Brisbane airport.

The 1991 report also recommended the re-establishment of the Brisbane Airport Consultative Committee subcommittee, called the Brisbane Airport Environment Committee, which was to take on board specifically this mandate of future noise management at the airport. Again, the recommendation of the 1991 noise task force was that the membership of the Brisbane Airport Environment Committee should be similar to that of the 1991 task force—that is, representatives from the three spheres of government. This resulted in the formal establishment in 1993 of the Brisbane Airport Environment Committee, which has a current membership of six and in respect of which the three relevant members from the south side and the north side of the river have put forward their nominations. Mr Don Coulam has been the representative for the federal division of Griffith. He was nominated firstly by one of my eminent predecessors, Mr Ben Humphreys, and was retained as that electorate's representative during the period Mr Graeme McDougall, from the other side of politics, represented the electorate.

The practice of federal, state and local government members nominating their representatives on this committee has been well recognised, well established and, until recently, well respected. Since this government has been in office, this practice has been reconsidered by the Brisbane Airport Consultative Committee, which confirmed the 1991 practice most recently in 1998. The minutes of a 1998 subcommittee meeting noted:

quote.para: On the issue of method of appointment, it was concluded that the best equipped people to make the selection of community representatives were the local members of parliament/council, who after all, have been elected by their communities to represent them.

speech.para: Those minutes reflect the meeting of the Brisbane Airport Consultative Committee in the period following the election of this government in March 1996. As I noted before, my representative on that body has been Mr Don Coulam. However, recently I notified the Brisbane Airport Corporation that Mr Coulam was interested in stepping down from that position, having served on the committee for four years, and I put forward the nomination of Ms Jackie Cann to replace him. However, when I advised the Brisbane Airport Corporation that this was my intention it did not accept Ms Cann's nomination and, instead, said that this was now a matter for the federal minister, not the federal member.

This position is not only curiously inconsistent with the previous practice going back over some seven, eight or nine years now but also demonstrably inconsistent with professional deliberations by this airport noise body in the period since this government has been in office. It is also strikingly inconsistent with correspondence between the Chairman of the Brisbane Airport Environment Committee and the previous Minister for Transport and Regional Services, Mark Vaile, dated 16 February 1998, in which Mr Vaile was advised of changes to the terms of reference of the Brisbane Airport Environment Committee. In that letter of February 1998 to Mr Vaile, the Chairman of the Brisbane Airport Environment Committee stated:

quote.para: The essential elements of the revised Terms of Reference include ... that community members continue to be appointed by the local, state and federal members.

speech.para: The chairman's letter also stated in paragraph 3 that these revised terms of reference `have been reviewed and agreed by all members of the Brisbane Airport Environment Committee'. Given that the Brisbane Airport Environment Committee includes representatives of the Brisbane Airport Corporation, it is even more curious that they should in late 1999 or early 2000 seek to dispute the local member's right to appoint a community representative to the environment committee. It should also be noted for the record that the Chairman of the Brisbane Airport Environment Committee is an employee of the Brisbane Airport Corporation. Therefore, in this correspondence with the then transport minister, Mark Vaile, we have the stated view of the Brisbane Airport Corporation that the previous system of appointment whereby local elected representatives appointed community representatives to this paramount consultation body should be continued.

The next development in this saga occurred when, as a consequence of having received a letter back from the Brisbane Airport Corporation that my nomination of Ms Jackie Cann was unacceptable, I chose to correspond with Minister Anderson in about the middle of last year on this question. Minister Anderson replied eventually in a letter dated 20 September 1999:

quote.para: Thank you for your letter of 23 August 1999 regarding the membership of the Brisbane Airport Environment Committee.
The Brisbane Airport Corporation is reviewing the structure and operations of the environment committee. The review is likely to result in significant changes to the committee.

speech.para: He went on to make some other observations about the individual whom I had nominated. The important point, though, arising from this correspondence is that suddenly we have emerging out of left field—or dare I say from right field—the sweeping away of the conventions adopted in the past decade when, in 1991, a broad based community task force recommended that the principal consultative body between the community, the airport corporation and the government should have six representatives put on it by the local community. The government is saying, `That is no longer our responsibility,' and that the Brisbane Airport Corporation now has the responsibility to bring about a fundamental change in the way in which this consultative mechanism is to work in the future. I question why my nominee to this body was so reprehensible. Ms Jackie Cann is from the local P&C of the Bulimba State School—a school which is directly affected by current and future levels of aircraft noise in my part of Brisbane. She is not exactly a representative of the Hezbollah. She has a degree of community support through her activism and knowledge of the issues associated with not just the airport but also its direct impact on significant local schools. So I could not see why her nomination would be unacceptable.

This then evolved into a meeting at the end of November or early December last year at which the then members of the Brisbane Airport Environment Committee—Mr Don Coulam, as he then was, Mr Arthur Pearce and Sue Pook—were told unilaterally that they no longer had their jobs. They were told, `The committee is finito—the end. Thank you for your service for the last six or seven years. It's all over, red rover. We are designing a new set of consultative arrangements. We don't know what it's going to be and we don't know who is going to be on it, but bye-bye.' Apart from being summary in its method of execution, it was also just downright rude in the way in which it treated people who had given their best for their community over a long period.

The fundamental public policy issue which arises is: who is now accountable to whom? The Brisbane Airport Corporation has now unilaterally gone to the Commonwealth and said, `We need a new set of arrangements.' I thought it was a responsibility of government to determine what those consultative arrangements should be, because it is the government's responsibility—not a private company's responsibility—for gathering public input into public decision making.

We now arrive at a situation where we do not know—at least until today—what this new arrangement is going to be. While I gather correspondence has now taken place between the minister's office and the Brisbane Airport Corporation, I have not been provided with a copy of it. However, I have been advised what its content is likely to be. I am told that, whereas in the past we have had six representatives taken from the community, in the future there will be five community representatives. The community representatives will be appointed for periods of two years. The minister and the federal department are of the view that it is important, however, that these individuals be refreshed from time to time so that no-one gets stale in the job—I presume by that they mean become too activist and problematic. I am told that the public selection process which would be established for the appointment of these individuals would comprise an independent chair and panel and that, for this current term, four rather than five individuals are going to be called to become members of this committee.

On the selection process itself, the independent chair is to be nominated by the Brisbane Airport Corporation—wait for it—to the minister, who would then have the right to say yes or no as to who this independent chair will be. It will be interesting to see who is on the panel. As for those members, the Brisbane Airport Corporation is currently writing to the city council and the state government asking them to nominate a person, but it is the expectation of the Department of Transport and Regional Services and the BAC that these folk will be—wait for it—bureaucrats and not representatives from the local community.

What we have had, therefore, is an exercise which substitutes a process that for the last nearly 10 years in Brisbane has been one of community democracy, whereby local residents get to argue the case, with a bureaucratic process appointed by the Brisbane Airport Corporation and ratified by the department of transport and, as a consequence, denying local people of their say. This represents jackboot tactics. The minister has said that for a short period, for an interregnum, I am entitled to have a continuing nominee, but that does not answer the fundamental charge that what we have now is not a local democratic body but, instead, a body which denies local communities of their opportunity to select their people and have them arguing their case on this important community issue in Brisbane.

talker.name: Stone, Dr Sharman, MP
Dr STONE
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Heritage

talk.start.para: —I rise to support this very important bill, the Aviation Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) 2000. It is of great significance to Australia.

—Order! It being 2 p.m., the debate is interrupted in accordance with standing order 101A. The debate may be resumed at a later hour. The parliamentary secretary will have leave to continue speaking when the debate is resumed.
—My question is to the Prime Minister. Given today's decision to raise interest rates—the third rate rise in six months—do you agree with the Treasurer, who said last Thursday:

quote.para: We've had interest rates moving up, but it's not an altogether bad thing.

talk.start.para: —As always, comments made by us on this side are taken out of context. I have read the Treasurer's comment. What he was referring to as being no bad thing was the growing strength of the world economy, and the idea that that is a bad thing could only be generated in the mind of an economic spokesman for the Australian Labor Party, because you people were the kings of the depressed Australian economy. I want to make one other observation on the interest rate issue and to remind the parliament—and in particular remind those who sit opposite—of the level of interest rates that obtained under the former government. The combined effect of interest rate movements since this government came to office means that the average Australian homebuyer is now $250 a month better off than that homebuyer would have been if the interest rate regime that we inherited from you incompetent lot had continued.
—Mr Speaker, I seek leave to table the transcript in which the Treasurer said interest rates going up is not an altogether bad thing.

—My question is addressed to the Treasurer. Has the Treasurer seen claims that today's interest rate rise is a consequence of the goods and services tax? What is the source of such claims, and how do they explain interest rate increases in the United States, Europe, the United Kingdom and New Zealand?

—I thank the honourable member for Menzies for his question. As the Prime Minister said, the Reserve Bank today increased official interest rates by 0.25 per cent to 5¾ per cent, which is a full one per cent tightening; as has been the case in Europe where there was a full one per cent tightening, in New Zealand where there has been a full one per cent tightening, in the United Kingdom where there has been a full one per cent tightening, and in the United States where interest rates have been tightened by 1.25 per cent. The Australian official cash rate stands lower than that of the United Kingdom and the United States.

answer.para: As the Prime Minister said, when this government was elected home variable mortgage interest rates were at 10.5 per cent. Even after today's movement, they would be at 7.55 per cent, meaning that on the standard Australian interest only loan you are saving today $250 a month on your interest bill, compared with the interest rates which applied when this government came into office, which is a $3,000 a year saving for the average Australian family over the course of the last four years since March 1996. In addition, unemployment has come down to 6.7 per cent, inflation has been low, Australia has survived the Asian financial crisis, and over the last 11 quarters the economy has grown at four per cent per annum, something that we had not done for 30 years.

As the Prime Minister said, one of the consequences of a stronger world environment—which will be good for Australia—is that interest rates are going up in all countries around the world. As I said before, the main ones are the European Central Bank and the English speaking economies of New Zealand, the US and the UK. I have seen a claim made—and it was not a claim made by the Governor of the Reserve Bank, but I have seen a claim made by a much lesser economic authority—that this is all a consequence of the Australian GST. Presumably, the US Fed is moving interest rates because of the Australian GST; presumably, Eddie George at the Bank of England is moving rates because of the GST; presumably, Mr Duisenberg of the European Central Bank is moving interest rates because of the Australian GST; and presumably, Don Brash sits down there in New Zealand and moves New Zealand's interest rates because of the GST. No, the Reserve Bank Governor said that the central bank in Australia was tightening, as was happening around the world. There is only one so-called economic authority, fired up by his pollster, who went out today to make the rather extraordinary claim that interest rates—which are rising around the world—are being caused by the Australian GST. I fully expect that, if there is an earthquake in Ecuador, according to the Leader of the Opposition it is the Australian GST and if there is a flood in Nicaragua, according to the Leader of the Opposition it is the Australian GST.

He made inter alia this particular claim today, that a further impact was a substantial slash on the budget. Apparently he is also against that, because he believes that that will be bad for interest rates. What he calls a substantial slash on the budget is an income tax cut. That is what it is; an income tax cut. Here we have the Leader of the Opposition going out campaigning against income tax cuts, campaigning against the GST—which he is so against that, if he ever becomes Prime Minister, he wants to keep it—and adding to the net sum of economic wisdom around the world by saying that interest rates, which have risen in the United Kingdom, the United States, New Zealand and Europe, are all caused by the Australian GST. It is totally poll driven and totally lacking in any economic credibility.

The good news, to finish the quote that the Deputy Leader of the Opposition so wilfully tried to misrepresent, of a growing world economy is that a growing world economy will be good for Australia. It will give us additional export volumes, and it will give us additional export values. The consequence of that is that you will see growth moving out of consumer demand and into exports, something that was shown up by recent figures and we would expect to be shown up by figures on the trade front over the course of the next two years.

talk.start.para: —My question again is to the Prime Minister. Can you confirm a report in the Australian on 24 March that you want the Reserve Bank to explain itself every time interest rates go up because:

quote.para: ... it is the RBA and not the federal Government that is responsible for hiking interest rates ...

question.para: Did you not also say on 26 May 1997:

quote.para: ... we have cut interest rates a lot further than we said we would at the time of the election ...

question.para: Prime Minister, if it was good enough to take credit when rates go down, why will you not you take responsibility when they go up?

talk.start.para: —The elements of economic policy that the government put in place when it came to office included not only the concept but the practice of independence for the Reserve Bank. The Reserve Bank of Australia has a much greater level of independence to set monetary policy today than it had under any previous government in Australia. In that sense, it has followed the practice of other governments around the world. One of the first acts of Gordon Brown, I think, when he became Chancellor in Tony Blair's government was to hand over the control of monetary policy to the Bank of England. But one thing I can be certain of is this: no Treasurer in any government I lead, no member of any government I lead, will make the claim made by the former member for Blaxland—I do not know whether he was Prime Minister then or Treasurer—when he said that he had the Reserve Bank in his pocket. Nothing did more damage to the concept that there was some integrity in the conduct of monetary policy than making a statement like that.

answer.para: Can I say for the record that I believe that the current Governor of the Reserve Bank, Mr Ian Macfarlane, is doing a first-rate job. I think one of the things that has contributed to the economic strength and the great economic prosperity of this country over the last few years has been the skilful conduct of monetary policy by the Reserve Bank. I notice today that the Governor issued a statement. It was quite a lengthy statement, and I think it provides a very good explanation for the rationale of the decision taken by the Reserve Bank of Australia. Monetary policy is an important element of economic prosperity and economic stability, and it is inevitable that adjustments in monetary policy will take account of national and international financial circumstances. What the Governor has done today, very usefully, has been to put into full context the decision taken by the Reserve Bank of Australia. I congratulate the Governor on the contribution that he has made in that very senior and important position to the stability and the strength of the Australian financial system.

Australia was able to stare down the Asian economic downturn, and the frantic prediction of the Leader of the Opposition on the AM program on 3 September 1998 was not realised. When the Leader of the Opposition criticised some growth figures, he said:

quote.para: These are not a beautiful set of numbers ... they're an indication of a substantial problem ...

answer.para: Then he went on to say, characteristically:

quote.para: And remember, we haven't really been hit by the Asian crisis yet. We don't get hit by the Asian crisis until these next two or three years.

answer.para: In other words, the Leader of the Opposition was desperately hoping that Australia might be hit by the Asian economic crisis, once again hoping for some bad economic luck for Australia. One of the reasons that this country was not hit by the Asian economic crisis was that we had a very strong, well-supervised, prudentially regulated, transparent banking system. The contribution that successive Reserve Bank governors—and particularly the current one—have made to the stability of the Australian financial system is something that deserves credit on both sides of this House.

talk.start.para: —My question is addressed to the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Transport and Regional Services. What is the government doing to ensure that rural, regional and remote communities in Barker and other electorates are able to secure the benefits of the telecommunications revolution? Is the minister aware of any alternative proposals?

—I thank the honourable member for his question, and I am delighted to answer it. In short, the $1 billion social bonus that the coalition has put together out of the partial sale of Telstra is now delivering some extraordinarily valuable initiatives in rural and regional Australia. A very large part of that is, of course, the $464 million Networking the Nation program. That is part of the Regional Telecommunications Infrastructure Fund, and it has funded now no less than 235 projects across Australia. A vast array of rural communities really can benefit from more innovative approaches to telecommunications of a sort that were never possible under Labor and would not have been impossible without this initiative.

answer.para: I had the great pleasure of launching one of them the other day, Growzone. Growzone covers an area of 28 per cent of Queensland, much of it in the electorates of Groom and of Maranoa. It runs from Toowoomba right out to the Birdsville corner. There are no less than 37 towns there that will now have access to the Internet at reasonable rates. It raises the prospect, extraordinary as it may sound, of the producers of organically grown beef in the Channel Country—one of the most remote parts of Australia; indeed, of the world—being able to communicate instantly and on the spot with their customers in Japan, the sort of thing that would not have been thought possible at all a few short years ago and would never have been possible with the ALP's approach to telecommunications innovation in regional areas, with their constant obstruction of the machinery that we have put in place to allow these things to happen.

The $2.6 million grant has been very well used by those who put together this program. They are already directly employing 15 people but, with the 37 towns across southern and south-west Queensland—including Charleville, Dirranbandi, Quilpie, Chinchilla, Roma, Cunnamulla, Goondiwindi and eventually places like Birdsville—that will now have such things as public access terminals, the employment prospects are really very serious indeed. These are the sorts of innovative approaches which are going to revolutionise the future for people living in rural and regional Australia. The member for Barker also asked whether I was aware of any alternative approaches. Yes, I am. The ALP have made it quite plain that they regard this as a hotchpotch approach which they would wind back or obliterate in government. They stand condemned. There is no doubt about them. If they see a good service delivery out there—whether, for example, it is Networking the Nation or closing down 270 post offices—they will roll it back.

talk.start.para: —I inform the House that we have present in the gallery this afternoon members of a parliamentary delegation from the Republic of Estonia, led by the President of the Estonian Parliament, His Excellency Mr Savi. Seated next to Mr Savi we have two former prime ministers from the Estonian parliament. I would like to extend to all members of the delegation a very warm welcome to the Australian parliament.

—My question is to the Deputy Prime Minister. Can you confirm a report in this week's edition of Inside Canberra that you received a letter from Doug McMillan, President of the National Association of Road Freight Operators?

—I asked the Deputy Prime Minister whether he could confirm receipt of a letter from the President of the National Association of Road Freight Operators? It is no laughing matter for them, Prime Minister. Is it true that Mr McMillan rejected as tenuous claims by the government that the new tax system will generate significant freight decreases after July 2000? Did he go on to say:

quote.para: The plight of operators will ... be compounded by ... prospective increases in interest rates and in the CPI.

question.para: Deputy Prime Minister, isn't Mr McMillan right?

talk.start.para: —The proposition that the reduction in fuel costs of around 23c a litre that we will be putting in place from 1 July and the proposition that the abolition of the wholesale sales tax on trucks, parts and tyres and all the equipment that goes with that will not deliver substantial benefits is absolutely absurd. It is just a total absurdity. I note, and I am sure that all members would note this, that regrettably the rise we are seeing in crude oil prices—which the government has absolutely no control over—is something that we hope will not last indefinitely. We look forward to an easing of those crude oil prices, which I acknowledge are putting pressure on transport operators at the moment. But to somehow extrapolate from that that the benefits from our tax reforms for transport will not be huge is absolutely extraordinary.

answer.para: It is interesting that the member for Hotham asked this particular question, because we now know what the opposition's attitude is towards reductions in fuel excise. We have, of course, had previous indications from the member for Dickson, who described them as nothing more than a multibillion dollar boost to pollution, a view not repudiated by the new spokesman for regional areas. But more recently we had—and I cannot help reading this into the Hansard—an interviewer asking Mr Crean about fuel excise. `What about fuel excise, Mr Crean?' the interviewer asked. `That causes a lot of problems, too. What sort of commitment can Labor make regarding fuel excise?' The response from Mr Crean was, `Basically our position has been that there needs to be this mix between indirect and direct taxes. We always had fuel excise in that mix'—and here is the cut-through line—`and we were not proposing to make any changes to the fuel excise regime. That wasn't the issue.'

talk.start.para: —Mr Speaker, I seek leave to table the letter from Mr McMillan, which says that your claims are tenuous, Mr Deputy Prime Minister.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Finance and Administration. Is the minister aware of the Federal Court's recent judgment and order that the Commonwealth pay costs for legal proceedings involving the member for Fremantle relating to her term as Western Australian Premier? Minister, in respect of that order, what action is the government taking?

—I can inform the honourable member for Sturt that on 25 February the Federal Court delivered a final judgment requiring the Commonwealth to pay some $761,594.13 for legal costs incurred by the member for Fremantle in connection with the Marks royal commission and her related court challenges in respect of that royal commission. The judgment makes it clear that staff members of the then Prime Minister and the then health minister had bound the Commonwealth contractually to payment of such legal costs. In fact those commitments by such staff members were subsequently ratified by the then Labor cabinet on 8 June in 1995.

answer.para: A number of members of this House, past and present, have served at various levels in state governments prior to entering this parliament, and I am indeed one those. I would believe the majority of us, while serving in this House, would not have the slightest expectation that, should proceedings be instituted in respect of our former administration in a state government, the Commonwealth budget would be required to pay the legal costs in respect of those proceedings. The role of any minister in this parliament has absolutely no relevance to the previous responsibilities of a minister in a state parliament.

A few weeks ago, the Attorney-General called upon the trustees of the Carmen Lawrence defence fund to provide approximately $100,000 that was collected in that cause towards the payment of legal costs. The Attorney-General has received a response dated 22 March from Mr Gray, indicating that no contribution would be made. This whole episode, which now requires the Commonwealth taxpayers to pick up the tab, is new territory. It is not only unprecedented; it is also a shameful step in public administration. But I can inform the honourable member for Sturt and members of the House that I will shortly introduce a special appropriation bill into the House to meet the Commonwealth's liability under the Federal Court judgment. In other words, the Australian taxpayers will pick up the bill. I repeat: this is a shameful episode in public administration. It demonstrates to the Australian people once again that Labor operates under the principle of whatever it takes. Of course, Labor has nothing but contempt for the Australian taxpayers.

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Prime Minister. I refer the Prime Minister to his admission yesterday that the assessment `there was never a generation of stolen children' was prepared in his department and cleared by his office. Do you stand by this assessment, Prime Minister, in the light of the view of Michael Long of the Essendon Football Club that the separation of indigenous children was:

quote.para: ... like dropping a rock in a pool of water and it has a rippling effect, so don't tell me it affects only 10 per cent.

question.para: Prime Minister, do you still assert that there was never a generation of stolen children?

talk.start.para: —I have already, in the course of the past few days, answered a number of questions and made a number of comments about this issue, both in the parliament and elsewhere. If the Leader of the Opposition seeks to further pursue the argument, I would simply say to him that what I have said represents my attitude. It acknowledges gross injustices having been practised in the past against indigenous Australians. It also recognises that the overwhelming desire of the Australian community now is to see all Australians working together on a basis of equality of opportunity and a recognition of the particular place of the indigenous people within our community. The Leader of the Opposition may, for his own purposes, seek to pursue the issue in particular. He is welcome to do that. I can do no more than draw his attention, which I do, to the remarks I have made in the parliament over the past few days and the remarks I have made elsewhere.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business. Would the minister advise the House of the success of the Australian workplace agreements? Is the minister aware of policies which threaten the existence of this initiative?

talker.name: Reith, Peter, MP
Mr REITH
talker.role: Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business

talk.start.para: —I thank the member for Forde for her question. The Australian workplace agreements, which can be either individual or collective, were introduced in the Workplace Relations Act in 1996 and started in early 1997. As of the end of March, 98,699 have been approved. We are well on the way to reaching a milestone in the development of this new option for people, with the approval of 100,000 in the next week or so. They have been a very successful option for people. They have allowed for new productivity flexibility, they have allowed for family friendly work practices, they have allowed for rostering flexibility and they have allowed for performance pay, just to mention some of the new features which are part and parcel of this new form of agreement.

answer.para: They are under threat—there is no doubt about that—even though the concept is well entrenched now and is being taken up right across the Australian community. They are under threat from the former trade union officials who sit opposite. I have read a report in the last few days that the issue of Australian workplace agreements and individual contracts would be up before the federal executive of the Labor Party on Friday this week. The report was to the effect that Labor's attitude to individual agreements is in the balance. We know it is a question mark as a policy issue.

talk.start.para: —AWAs are out!

—Thank you. This is exactly the point I am making. I was going to quote Doug Cameron saying the other day that you cannot have AWAs. It must be that the Leader of the Opposition read it, because he has announced his policy already—no AWAs. So you are going to deny tens of thousands of Australian workers the right to have an agreement that suits them. This is ideology at its worst, taking Australia back into the sixties and the seventies. You already have the unions giving you your public marching instructions. When you go down to your federal executive on Friday, as soon as you walk in, the first bloke you will meet will be Joe de Bruyn. He is from the shoppies.

—Mr Speaker, on a point of order: in defiance of your consistent previous rulings, the minister has today used the pronoun `you' repeatedly and continually and this practice shows no signs of abating.
—The member for Griffith may well be right. I am not disputing that. The response on both sides of the House has left something to be desired.
—When the Leader of the Opposition fronts up on Friday to the ALP executive, he will be met by Joe de Bruyn from the shoppies union.

answer.para: Opposition members interjecting—

talk.start.para: —These are the members of your executive. These are the people who tell you what your policy is. These are the people who dictate policy to you.
—The minister is, as he knows, obliged to refrain from using the term `you' because it is of course an unintended reflection on the chair.

—You, Mr Speaker, will not be at this meeting, I can assure you of that. He will meet Janice Mayes from the Australian Services Union, Margaret Sexton from the CPSU and Greg Sword from the National Union of Workers. Out of the 21 people on that executive, two-thirds are from the unions. You are going to the unions to ask them what their policy is on AWAs.

—We have now flushed out a policy from the Leader of the Opposition. He is opposed to allowing people to have Australian workplace agreements. I appreciate that we now have a clear difference. We are prepared to give people an option. The opposition are going to say that for the 100,000 people who have AWAs, they are out. They are going to deny them the option that any Australian ought to have.
—My question without notice is addressed to the Prime Minister. Prime Minister, do you recall saying the following at the launch of the National Indigenous Literacy and Numeracy Strategy:

quote.para: I see today's strategy, which represents a firm commitment of resources from the Federal Government, as well as a commitment to better direct existing resources ... as a very important element in the reconciliation process.

question.para: Were you aware that all of the money for this strategy will come from the existing pool of funding available for indigenous students? Why did you seek to portray this launch as a new announcement of new money when not one extra dollar is being allocated over and above existing allocations for indigenous students?

talk.start.para: —The member for Parramatta!
—Finally, Prime Minister, why should Australians trust your commitment to practical reconciliation when you have been prepared to mislead indigenous Australians in this way?
—The member for Parramatta is warned.

—Regarding the remarks that I made at the launch, that is certainly not my understanding. It was not the advice I had. I stand completely by the remarks I made because there was absolutely no intention on my part to mislead. The program represented, on my understanding and on my advice, the commitment out of the overall literacy and numeracy program of specific resources to lift the standards of indigenous literacy and numeracy within the Australian community. That was the advice that I had from both my own department—

answer.para: Opposition members interjecting—

talk.start.para: —I have already said that the money came out of the overall literacy and numeracy allocation. There was absolutely no deception at all.

—My question is addressed to the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Transport and Regional Services. Would the Deputy Prime Minister outline to the House the benefits of the government's approach to aviation reform?

—I thank the honourable member for his question and acknowledge his very real interest and considerable background in aviation. We are pressing ahead with modernising Australia's air safety systems in a measured and sensible way.
