I would in particular like to draw the House's attention to the fact that the airspace reform program is scheduled to be completed in June 2001. The government, having learnt various lessons, including those that could be drawn out of the G airspace demonstration, are continuing to modernise Australia's airspace—it is an important part of our national transport infrastructure—and we are doing so in a staged way to ensure that industry can handle appropriately the changes as they are made. Airservices has phased out the manual traffic information or DTI arrangements that we used in the low level airspace between Bass Strait and Ballina. It has replaced, too, the 1950s vintage procedures with air traffic controllers using the award winning system, TAAATS. TAAATS is now fully operational. I have drawn the attention of the House to this matter before, and I reiterate that we all ought to be very proud that this is quite simply and without any doubt the most advanced air traffic control system in the world. That is something that we can all be very proud of.

answer.para: The new arrangements increase the safety of air travel in regional Victoria and New South Wales. Under the procedural arrangements in times gone by, the flight service officers did not use radar to provide information to pilots, even in areas where there was radar coverage. In contrast, the air traffic controllers now use radar where it is available to provide better and more accurate traffic information. Airservices will phase out the last of the manual traffic information systems used in Australia by December of this year. The final stage of the airspace reform program is scheduled to be completed by June 2001.

There are other important reforms going on. I have recently appointed a new consultative body, the Aviation Safety Forum, and it will provide strategic advice direct to CASA. It will, I believe, act as a useful and, I have to say, needed bridge between CASA and the industry. We are pushing ahead with regulatory reform. For example, we have announced the new rating for private pilots—the private instrument flight rules rating—which will reduce accidents caused by light aircraft attempting to dodge around clouds. AOPA, the Aircraft Owners and Pilots Association, has actually commented that `the whole concept is quite revolutionary and the development team have done a great job'.

Of interest to people in rural and regional areas is the fact that we have reduced the duty on fuel used in small planes by 85 per cent since we came to power in 1996. Under Labor, the duty on Avgas was 18½c a litre. It is now 2.8c a litre, a reduction of 15.7c a litre. We slashed the duty in 1998. We made a modest increase of 9.77c last year to ensure a very important service delivery objective—that was that Airservices Australia could maintain affordable tower service provisions at 15 regional and general aviation airports, including centres like Tamworth, where, if we had not taken that action, the landing fees would have increased from under $7 a tonne to nearly $40 a tonne. We are pressing ahead in a sensible way with aviation reforms that will benefit the travelling public in this country in a very real way.

talk.start.para: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Aged Care. Is it not a fact that the Productivity Commission has noticed that people from Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander backgrounds are significantly under-represented in nursing homes? Can you confirm that while making up 2.3 per cent of a target population for nursing home care only 0.8 per cent of people from Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander backgrounds are in nursing homes? Do these figures not represent the discrepancy between this government's policy on indigenous issues—you are happy to have Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders over-represented in our prisons, but you do nothing to ensure they have equal access to our nursing homes?
—When the House has come to order, I will call the minister.
—The member has asked a detailed question. I will examine the contents of the question and report back to the House at an appropriate time.

answer.para: Honourable members interjecting—

talk.start.para: —This cross-chamber chat is not tolerated.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Trade. Would the minister inform the House how the government's tax reform package stands to benefit Australian export industries? How does this build onto the government's overall strategy for export growth? Are you aware of any alternative policies in this area?

—I thank the honourable member for his question and acknowledge the importance that the honourable member places on the prosperity of the exporters from has electorate and the one in five jobs that Australia's export effort provides to rural and regional Australians. I know this is a message that the honourable member, as well as all members of the government, is going to continue to provide. Today I presented to the parliament and released publicly the government's Trade Outcomes and Objectives Statement—the fourth in the series. Since we have been in office we have continued to release details of what has been achieved in trade in the previous 12 months and the objectives for the upcoming 12 months. An integral part of what we are doing as far as our export effort is concerned in the year 2000 is improving Australia's taxation system—improvements that all Australians, particularly the business community, have been calling for. Changes in the taxation system will see more than $3.5 billion a year worth of indirect and embedded taxes carved away and taken off the backs of Australia's exporters. It is a policy that has been continually opposed by the Labor Party. They have continually opposed and talked down the benefits of tax reform as far as Australia's exporters are concerned.

—Everybody except the member for Fraser. The member for Fraser is the only member of the ALP who has acknowledged the benefits for exporters of the GST. He said, `Well, the GST overall should be good for exporters.' He was being quite honest when he went on to say, `I'm not a fan of the GST, as you might imagine, but if there is one thing that is a plus for it, it should help our exporters.' Indeed it will. I agree with the member for Fraser—it will help our exporters. Over the last couple of years we have managed the economy of Australia through very difficult international circumstances, such as the economic downturn in South-East Asia and East Asia, and our exporters maintained a level last year of $114 billion in exports. They have done that carrying the burden of the embedded taxes that the Labor Party wants to keep and that the Labor Party kept on increasing. We all remember the budget of 1993. We want to remove that burden, and we are going to do that on 1 July. The manufacturer of Malibu boats in Albury indicated to me in February this year that, as of 1 July, because of the GST, he is going to be selling his product at 1997 prices. He is going to get a net reduction in the cost of producing that product. He cannot wait for 1 July to arrive. He is asking the question, `Why is the Australian Labor Party opposing a policy that is going to see that happen?'

answer.para: Where is the policy from the Labor Party? All Australian exporters are asking, `Where is the Labor Party policy?' At the moment the shadow spokesman for trade is on a five-week tour through Europe. While he is in Europe, he is announcing policies on China as far as Australia's trade circumstance is concerned. I suppose he will go to China and announce their policy on Europe, but he will not announce any policies back here in Australia and we have not heard from the Leader of the Opposition how the ALP propose to improve the circumstance for Australian exporters and make them more competitive, as we will as of 1 July.

talk.start.para: —I inform the House that we have present in the gallery this afternoon members of a parliamentary delegation from the National Assembly of Vietnam. On behalf of the House, I extend to our guests a very warm welcome.

—My question without notice is addressed to the Prime Minister. How does the Prime Minister explain that, according to the report tabled by the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs on Monday, of the $11.25 million committed in 1997 to the government's flagship program to assist separated Aboriginal families to reunite, only $3.7 million has been spent? How does he explain that, of the $16 million committed in 1997 to fund specialist indigenous counsellors, only $1.7 million has been spent? Do the same excuses for these abysmal underperformances apply to the government's record on the emotional and social wellbeing regional training centres, for which program the minister's report reveals an expenditure over the past two years of only $865,000 of a total commitment of $17 million?

—Given the detailed nature of the question, I would have to take on notice the specifics raised, but it gives me an opportunity to remind the House that there was a commitment of $63 million made I think towards the end of 1997 within about six or seven months of the publication of the HREOC report. I do not think under any circumstances that could be seen as unreasonable or unfair, given the character of the report and the particular recommendations that were made. The honourable member knows, as do all people in this House who have sat in government, that there are reasons why, after a commitment of money is made, you do not expend every last dollar of it within the first few weeks. It does take time. As to the particular reasons, I do not have them in mind. I will find out, and as appropriate I will come back to the House.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Health and Aged Care. Would the minister outline the government's initiatives to promote mental health and wellbeing amongst young people, particularly school children?

talker.name: Wooldridge, Dr Michael, MP
Dr WOOLDRIDGE
talker.role: Minister for Health and Aged Care

talk.start.para: —I thank the honourable member for his question, and I commend him for the leadership he has shown in his local area on this issue. We have had a concerted effort to address mental health matters over the last four years and Australia has had very significant international credit for it. Last week I launched a program that we have called MindMatters that we use amongst secondary school children in Australia. It came out of a national schools audit in 1996 that showed there were very significant barriers to dealing with mental health problems in Australian schools. This is an innovative resource for teachers to address and promote in the classroom mental health and suicide prevention. It is a sad reality that up to 20 per cent of Australian children may experience a mental illness in their teenage years; the most common of these is depression. It affects people particularly up to 18 years of age. Students may feel that there is no way out, that there is no light at the end of the tunnel.

answer.para: The materials that I am talking about were developed by a consortium. We tested them in 24 Australian schools in 1998 and 1999, and they have tested extraordinarily well. They relate to a range of materials for teachers and schools and are particularly designed to help increase the resilience of children and to give them skills to cope with challenges, change and stress. They also show how a school may take a whole of school approach to issues of harassment, understanding mental illness and helping students with loss and grief. It is a truly national project that is being coordinated by the Australian Principals Association and the Curriculum Corporation.

There is no easy solution to the issue of suicide. The member has raised with me the issue of a summit in Frankston in May, and I hope materials such as these that have been thoroughly tested do give people at that summit some hope for the future.

talk.start.para: —My question without notice is to the Prime Minister. Prime Minister, do you recall your Minister for Employment Services saying that Australia risks breeding a generation of job snobs? How do you respond to recent criticism of this low-grade labelling by at least two of your senior Liberal Party colleagues? Given that Senator Newman was prepared to distance herself from the minister's label, are you prepared to do the same thing? If the member for Adelaide was prepared to attack the minister for his appalling comments, do you have the courage to repudiate the minister and demand that he call off his divisive campaign against the unemployed?

—I would have thought the worth of a Minister for Employment Services to his government would be the contribution that minister makes to reducing unemployment. In the end what this minister as a member of this government and what all of the men and women who sit in this parliament behind me are about is generating jobs for Australians. You can play your funny word games as often as you like, but in the end what really matters—
—6.7 per cent is what counts.

—You know what really counts? It is not your funny word games but, as the Treasurer said, the 6.7 per cent level of unemployment. What counts is that the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business and the Minister for Employment Services have presided over generating the best job figures this country has seen for a decade. They have introduced a world first as far as a modern competitive approach to labour exchange policy is concerned. The Job Network has been an unqualified success. The Job Network has outpaced the Commonwealth Employment Service.
—Order! The honourable member for Grayndler!

—I want to thank the member for Chifley for asking me this question. I cannot delay the House for all the time that I would really want to to extol the virtues of the job that this government has done in reducing unemployment. In the end, a judgment will be made about the performance of this government in relation to the unemployed by what we achieve. And we have the runs on the board. We have the jobs available to Australians of all generations. We have 653,000 more jobs as a result of the policies of this government over the last four years.
—That's absolute rubbish.
—The Deputy Leader of the Opposition!

—We have a strong labour market. We have a flexible, competitive, compassionate Job Network. We have opportunities available in this Job Network which were undreamt of under the old Commonwealth Employment Service. I want to congratulate the minister.
—The member for Wills is warned.
—I want to congratulate the other minister. I want to congratulate everybody on this side of the House for the contribution that they have made to reducing unemployment in Australia.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry. Would the minister inform the House of the progress being made by the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service in negotiating market access for Australian farmers to key regional markets? Further, in particular, would the minister advise of any recent market openings for our important horticultural exports?

talker.name: Truss, Warren, MP
Mr TRUSS
talker.role: Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry

talk.start.para: —I thank the member for Hinkler. Honourable members would know that the member for Hinkler represents one of Australia's foremost horticultural regions. Indeed, I was happy to join him for a dinner last Saturday night near Bundaberg to celebrate the achievements of the horticultural industry.
—Was it is a fundraiser, was it?
—I warn the member for Banks. That sort of outburst will not be tolerated.

—Indeed, the horticultural industry has a lot to celebrate, Mr Speaker, as you would well know. It has been one of the real success stories of Australian agriculture, with tremendous boosts in exports and considerable growth in employment in the industry. The Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service has put a lot of effort into opening up new markets, and the rewards for its science based quarantine system have been significant. The House would be interested to know that since 1993-94 AQIS has succeeded in having technical barriers to our exports removed in 275 commodity market combinations. That represents significant new marketing opportunities. AQIS has improved conditions for export access in 96 cases and in a further 257 cases where our exports have been put at risk because of threats from other countries they have been able to negotiate continuing access. So there have been some really significant breakthroughs, which have helped our horticultural industry in electorates like Hinkler and right around Australia to expand their exports and to develop job opportunities and build regional economies.

answer.para: I am particularly pleased to report to the House today that Australia is at the point of a major breakthrough in relation to exports of citrus. Mr Speaker, this would interest you particularly because the citrus growers of the Riverland have the potential to be major beneficiaries of a likely agreement with South Korea to allow access for Australian citrus into that very important market. This will be the first time that fresh Australian fruit has been allowed into Korea. The citrus industry has also been one of the great successes of the horticultural sector. Their exports have tripled since 1994-95 and are now worth almost $150 million. Soon I expect the people of South Korea will have the benefit of being able to enjoy citrus produced in the Riverland—and hopefully my own electorate, because we do produce some of the very best citrus in the world. It is great to have these new market opportunities available to our producers.

subdebateinfo.title: Welfare Reform: Reference Group Interim Report

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. Prime Minister, why have you compromised the independence of the Welfare Review Committee by arranging for the chair, Mr Patrick McClure, to attend a Liberal Party national convention later this month? Also, Prime Minister, who was responsible for the hiring of Jackson, Wells and Morris to handle the public relations for the launch of the welfare committee's interim report?
—The member for Grayndler is warned.

—Perhaps I could answer the question in two ways. The first way I can answer the question is in five words: Rod Cameron and Bill Hunter. The second way I can answer the question is in a slightly more detailed fashion, and that is to refer to the question of who hired that particular firm—
—What review did they head up?
—The Deputy Leader of the Opposition!

—which is made up of three principals—one of whom, Mr Jackson, was the Labor candidate for the seat of Mackellar in 1983, and in fact at the show down the road he was accompanied by his good friend Kerry Sibraa, regardless of stories of meetings of the Narrabeen branch of the Australian Labor Party. The other two principals of course are well known. If that firm gets some contracts on a proper basis, like any other firm it has a right to.
—I warn the Deputy Leader of the Opposition. He has persistently interjected today.

—I do not run away from my association with Graham Morris and I never will. I never run away from associations with people who have demonstrated a loyalty and commitment to me on a personal basis over the years. I make it very plain that—

answer.para: Opposition members interjecting—

talk.start.para: —I do not quite know where the opposition believes this fascinating line of questioning is going. I think, like somebody said, this is character assassination. This idea that somebody, because they have worked for, and had an association with, a Prime Minister, is denied the opportunity of making a living—
—Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order going to relevance: I asked him who was responsible for hiring them, not the composition.
—The member for Lilley will resume his seat. The Prime Minister is being relevant to the question asked.

—The member for Lilley asked me about how a particular firm was engaged and he named that particular firm. The whole purpose of naming it was to invoke the association between me and Graham Morris. That is why he asked the question. He sought to smear Graham Morris—a decent person who has a right to make a living. As far as I am concerned, I am proud of my friendship with Graham Morris.
—The member for Lilley is warned.

—I warned the member for Lilley that there was a short answer and a long answer. On the engagement of the firm, I know nothing of the processes whereby the firm was engaged—nothing at all. As to the question of whether Mr McClure can come along and address a Liberal Party conference, I do not think that in any way compromises his independence. I am quite certain he would be happy to go along and address the Labor caucus. I do not think anybody has suggested that, for example, Stuart McIntyre's independence as an Australian historian of note was compromised by the fact that he gave some kind of centenary address to a meeting of the federal conference of the Australian Labor Party. This idea that somebody cannot preserve their independence just because they address a committee is absolutely ridiculous.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Community Services. Would the minister inform the House how the government is expanding Centrelink services in rural and regional areas such as my electorate of Robertson? How does this expansion of services help deliver the government's new Family Assistance Office? What alternative policies exist that aim to improve delivery of services to families in rural and regional Australia?

—I am pleased to advise the member for Robertson that an additional 767 Centrelink call centre staff, both permanent and temporary, will be recruited up until July as part of the government's new tax system. These people will be placed in Centrelink call centres and Family Assistance Offices right across urban and regional Australia. They will provide a vital service to Australians who are seeking more information about the new taxation system. The changes to income assistance will help families and people receiving pensions, other payments and allowances. The changes to family assistance payments will provide more help with the cost of raising children. Twelve complex payments now will be reduced to a simplified three new payments. Not only is the coalition government increasing income support payments, but it is introducing more generous income tests for more families. Families now will be able to choose to receive their payment either as a lump sum or as a reduction in their tax instalments.
—Just table it.
—The member for Denison is warned.

—Retired Australians will also benefit under the new tax system with the one-off savings bonuses. On 1 July, the age pension savings bonus will provide up to $1,000 to Australians over the age of 60. For self-funded retirees aged 55 and over, the supplementary bonus of $2,000 will also be provided. Importantly for pensioners and low income retirees, until they start paying tax, the tax thresholds will be $14,500 for single people or $24,500 for couples, and this is extremely significant. These are real benefits under the taxation reform system. The government is committed to protecting the living standards and the financial security of all Australians.

answer.para: Let us look at the record of our opponents over here. In the good old days when Labor was in government, when wholesale sales taxes were jacked up consistently, of course there were no compensation payments to pensioners or retirees. The ALP still has no plan. Where is the ALP's plan? Their only plan—aside from rolling out ex-ACTU boys club members—is a scaremongering campaign with no policy.

But there is one question I would like to ask the member for Lilley: will you keep all these generous compensation payments to families and pensioners or will you support a repeal, just as you said in your newsletter:

quote.para: It could be repealed today. We will support a repeal.

talk.start.para: —On a point of order, Mr Speaker, I would like to ask the minister to table the script from which he has just read so that we can see the stage directions.
—The member for Kingston will resume his seat. Was the minister quoting from a confidential document? The minister has indicated that he was.

subdebateinfo.title: Rural and Regional Australia: Australia Post

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Prime Minister. Prime Minister, why is no red light flashing in your office over the government's proposal to deregulate Australia Post when you cannot guarantee, in breach of your own Nyngan declaration, that Australia Post services to rural, regional and remote Australia will not fall as a consequence of deregulation?
—The Prime Minister does not have the call, and he is being denied it by the behaviour of the member for Lyons who, as an occupier of this chair, should know better.

—I am reminded, as I get up to answer this question, of the enormous number of post offices that were closed during the time that the Labor Party was in office. Let me assure the House that the government's policy in relation to Australia Post will not result in a reduction of services to the bush. That remains our policy, and nothing the member for Perth says can alter that.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs. Minister, what action is the government taking to reduce the queue of aged parents of migrants who want to migrate to Australia themselves? Would the minister inform the House what the government is doing to reduce this queue without placing undue burden on the taxpayer?

talker.name: Ruddock, Philip, MP
Mr RUDDOCK
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Reconciliation

talk.start.para: —I thank the honourable member for Hindmarsh for her question. It is a proper question to ask, because there is a significant degree of interest among some sections of the Australian community about the possibilities of having parents join them in Australia if they have come to Australia as migrants themselves. The fact is that we do have a limited program of 500 places for aged parents and we have a considerable queue of people who seek to access those places. It is in response to that that during the consultations I had recently in relation to the migration program I took the opportunity of discussing at public meetings and in more informal meetings with particular interest groups their view about the way in which we should proceed to address this particular dilemma—and that is the dilemma of how you can bring people to Australia in their more mature years and not impose a significant financial burden upon the whole of the Australian community for their support.

answer.para: I spoke to many people at those public meetings, but I can remember only one occasion when somebody said they had an expectation that if their parents were allowed in they should be supported by being able to access benefits almost immediately after entering Australia. Most people said to me that if they were given the opportunity to bring their parents to Australia they would be more than happy to support them, to ensure that they did not claim benefits in Australia and to meet a reasonable cost of providing for private health insurance.

talk.start.para: —The member for Gellibrand!

—Knowing that the health costs for people over the age of 65 years are around $6,000 per year or, for an estimated life span of 20 years, $120,000 and that welfare costs for special benefits and age pensions are of the order of $160,000 over a remaining life span of 20 years—that is a total lifetime cost of $280,000—the government has proposed a contingency reserve measure of 4,000 additional places for aged parents on the basis that there be private health insurance for a 10-year period taken out on behalf of the aged parents before their arrival or that, if they cannot arrange such health insurance, they meet an up-front health services charge of $25,000 per person. That represents about 20 per cent of the potential cost. There would also be an increased bond of $10,000 for the main applicant and $4,000 for other people, and it may be refundable after 10 years if no benefits are accessed during that time. That is not an unreasonable request and, if people were coming to Australia and disposing of property interests, very easily obtainable. The comments that came to me at public meetings—
—In marginal Liberal seats.
—They were not in Liberal seats; they were in a cross-section of seats across Australia.
—The member for Gellibrand is warned.
—People said that if the opportunity was there many people would seek to access those places.

answer.para: I note that the opposition seems to object to that measure, and that suggests that the comments of the member for Bowman, when I see them reported in the Sydney Morning Herald, may have some validity because he is out there saying that Labor is opposed to a scheme which would favour those with money. That is what he is saying: `We are opposed to a scheme that would favour those people with money.' He is really saying, `We are opposed to those people who have the funds to support their parents using those funds and taking their parents out of the queue for the places that are available on a fully subsidised basis.'

Five hundred places would move a significant number of people off the queue, if that measure were to be supported. I suspect that is why the Australian Democrats are saying that they will seriously look at this proposal. But let me make the point that, if the opposition is saying that 20,000 parents should be allowed into Australia on the basis of those costs being fully met, in the context of the charter for budget honesty, they ought to be prepared to go out and argue that case and put it to the Australian taxpayers that their responsibility should be to support those sponsored parents where families were saying that they have no intention of asking the taxpayer to pay.

talk.start.para: —Mr Speaker, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper

—To add to an answer, during question time earlier this week the member for Perth asked me whether I was aware that Ms Jane Bennett, a panel member of the government's Telstra inquiry, currently features in paid government television advertisements promoting the goods and services tax. I am advised that Ms Bennett is participating in a rural GST start-up assistance campaign being conducted by the Department of Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry. The advertisement is aimed at encouraging farmers to take steps to prepare for the GST by attending a free GST workshop, consulting their accountant, applying for an ABN and reviewing their financial and business systems.

speech.para: The person in question, a Tasmanian farmer and the ABC radio Australian Rural Woman of the Year in 1997, was one of 10 farmers auditioned by the department, after consultation with the Tasmanian Farmers and Graziers Association. She received a $200 audition fee and, as she was selected, a talent fee of $1,000. Payments were consistent with those to other participants. The advertisements were filmed about a month ago. There is nothing in her involvement in the advertising campaign that conflicts in any way with her role in the telecommunications service inquiry. She will bring to that inquiry the benefits of her extensive public and community experience and her understanding of the needs of rural communities. This is just another cheap attempt to smear a decent person.

talk.start.para: —Very briefly, during question time I answered a question in relation to aviation reform. I made the comment that the duty under Labor on avgas was 18.5c per litre. It is now 2.85c per litre—a reduction of 15.7c per litre. I made the comment that we slashed it in 1998 and then modestly increased it in 1999. I wanted to clarify this because I understand from someone who made a comment that I may not have clearly pronounced it. The modest increase was 0.977c, not 9.77c.

subdebateinfo.title: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs

talk.start.para: —Mr Speaker, I refer to the fact that the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs continues to wear an Amnesty International lapel badge in the chamber.
—I will hear the member for Grayndler, but I have difficulty seeing what business it is of mine at this stage.
—Mr Speaker, you might not be aware that the minister has been formally requested by Amnesty to remove his Amnesty International lapel badge when speaking in his capacity as federal minister.

—The member for Grayndler will resume his seat. The member for Grayndler must be aware that the badges worn by members in this place are no business of the chair. There is no standing order that suggests that they should be worn on a particular lapel or in a particular way. I do not intend to take any action on a matter which is entirely the business of the minister for immigration.

—Mr Speaker, in accordance with standing order 150, I ask that you write to the Treasurer concerning question on notice No. 955 concerning his promise to not introduce new taxes or increase existing taxes and whether he kept that promise—a question he has not been able to answer even after six months.
—The Deputy Leader of the Opposition will resume his seat. I will take up the matter, as I would normally do in the usual course of events.
—Mr Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.
—Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?
—Yes, I do.
—Please proceed.

—During question time, the Prime Minister said that I said that the firm Jackson, Wells and Morris should not have been hired because Mr Morris, the principal of the firm, was a former staff member of his. That is simply not the case. I have the highest regard for Mr Morris, as indeed I do for other members of the Prime Minister's staff. The point that I was making was very simple: who hired the firm—
—The member for Lilley will resume his seat. He has made the point where he believes he was misrepresented.
—Mr Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.
—Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?
—I do.
—Please proceed.

—During question time, the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business claimed that the government had discovered a new Labor Party policy which is to abolish Australian workplace agreements. This significantly misrepresents the policy which I took to the last election which quite explicitly stated that we would abolish Australian workplace agreements.
—The Manager of Opposition Business will resume his seat.
—The member for Brisbane! The Manager of Opposition Business knows that he must indicate where he was personally misrepresented.
—The member for Brisbane is warned!
—What about standing order 55, one might remind the member for Prospect?
—The member for Prospect is warned!
—Papers are tabled as listed in the schedule circulated to honourable members. Details of the papers will be recorded in the Votes and Proceedings.
—I have received a letter from the honourable member for Brand proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

quote.para: The social and economic consequences of the Prime Minister's failure of leadership and the resultant divisions within the government.

interjection.para: I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.

para.inline: More than the number of members required by the standing orders having risen in their places—

talk.start.para: —Those who witnessed question time today will have seen an interesting psychological study on the part of the Prime Minister, the psychological phenomenon called `projection', that followed a question that I asked him—and we have asked him quite a few this week—related to the issue of the stolen generation and specifically the comments by our Essendon footballer friend. The point about it was that he wanted to say, `Why are you keeping this issue going? Aren't you playing wedge politics?' The simple fact of the matter is this: this government, to protect itself from the consequences of its policy and the impact that that is having on most Australians now, decided to play wedge politics. They have had out there the principal culprits: the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs is out there with every conceivable immigration issue he can raise, but most of it targeted to feed or tweak the tails of any concerns, any worries or any upsets in the community about either the race or the origins of immigration to this country. The second one is the Minister for Employment Services, who is out there with comments like `job snobs', who is out there attacking the unemployed. Then we have the minister for social security out there putting forward propositions in relation to supporting parents and those on disabilities. The point of all this activity being the erection of a smokescreen in general political debate and the driving of wedges into the community.

speech.para: The Australian public is to some extent now being educated by the debate in this chamber about what wedge politics means. There is always a danger that they will not comprehend what is essentially a cliché that circulates amongst those who spend their life in the profession of politics and those who comment on it. But it is quite a simple phenomenon, really. It is a product of a special campaigning technique developed by the far right in the United States during the course of the 1980s and entails this: when confronted with a majority of the community badly affected by one of your policies, and the consequences of your policies benefiting a small section—generally speaking, the wealthy—the best way to deal with that problem is to drive a wedge by coming in on top of what were generally class issues with a set of propositions to attempt to force the majority of the population to look downwards for their grief and not upwards to you, the true source of it. That was the point of wedge politics. That is what wedge politics means. On other occasions, however, those who are perpetrators of it get either a guilty conscience about it or get shot by their own design. I read in an article by one of our correspondents, Laurie Oakes, today about the last-minute contrition of the inventor of wedge politics, Lee Atwater, at the time he was dying of a brain tumour. He expressed regret about some of the things he had done in the name of wedge politics. The correspondent goes on to say, `There is a lesson there for others.' That `lesson for others' the Prime Minister has begun to learn.

The effect that he has had in playing wedge politics in this place this week has not been to weaken the target—which happens to be us—it has been to divide his own party, who are through and through fed up with this; through and through fed up with the way in which this Prime Minister is choosing to play politics in this country now. That reached fever pitch yesterday in what clearly was a revolt in his party ranks; a revolt against what ought to be absolutely fundamental to Liberal principle, that is, the separation of the activities of the judiciary and the state or the government. It is important to those of us who are social democrats that that should be observed. But if the Liberal Party does not support that sort of proposition they have no reason for existence, because that is their fundamental ideological commitment.

One or two of their number—at least in their party room, though not in here—had sufficient courage to stand up and draw attention to the hypocrisy and the damage that they were doing to ordinary people in this country. Indeed, the Prime Minister was tumbled as far as that was concerned. He has also now recognised, as he has faced rotten headline after rotten headline, that there are an awful lot of people out there who feel that the government ought to address this issue and move on. While people may be sick of hearing about issues related to the stolen generation and issues related to reconciliation, they are not sick of hearing about it because they object to the Aboriginal community; they are sick of hearing about it because they think the government should by now have dealt with the issue and moved on. That is what they think. The Australian people crave a government that will address these issues, which now have been on our agenda for some considerable time, and finish them. That is what people want—and so, apparently, do one or two members of the backbench on the other side of the House, at least in private. The Prime Minister has, nevertheless, persisted in that, and he himself is now paying some penalty for it.

It is evident, too, that, while one would expect to see in the Liberal Party—given their ideology—some concern in that regard, we also see that they are objecting to one or two other things as well. They are actually objecting to the targeting of other weak sectors in our community. One of their number got up to object to the notion of job snobs that has been put forward as yet another characterisation of the unemployed: yet another piece of demeaning—another piece of wedge politics. To those who are concerned about their level of income, those who are concerned about what is going to happen to them in the new tax regime that has been put in place as families carry all the burden of tax in this country—those people with a genuine concern—the Minister for Employment Services is trying to say `Look, don't think about what is happening to you and your family. Think about how unfair it is that your taxes are going to these people whom we characterise as job snobs.' That was the point of what is continually being engaged in by that particular minister, who has a burgeoning record of failure. It was laughable to hear those employment services defended by the Prime Minister so resolutely in this place, but there will be opportunities to deal with that in future question times.

But that is not the employment services minister's role. His role in this government is not to develop employment services that get the long-term unemployed into work. His role in this government is not to get into the work force people who are on disability benefits or who are out of the work force because they are supporting children at home. It is not his job to get them into the work force. That would actually cost some money. That would actually require some attention by government. His job is to characterise them, categorise them, demonise them and use them as the wedge by which families in this country cease to focus on what the government is doing to them when they seek to put their aged parents into nursing homes; when they confront the price rises on all their goods and services; and when they confront the consequences, if they happen to be in regional Australia, of a loss of services with the full privatisation of Telstra. `Do not think about that', says that particular minister, following his Prime Minister's direction, `Think about what may be happening to a bunch of people whom your taxes are being spent upon.'

That is what this government are doing, and the result of that is social collapse and the destruction of decent social policy. It is necessary for them to do that because community concern about the botched taxation system that they are putting in place is beginning to reach fever pitch. People in voluntary organisations, people in small business and people in families are trying to get answers as to what all this means for them, and getting instead propaganda—$100 million worth of propaganda—but no answers; plenty of argument, but no answers. More and more they are putting pressure on this government for those answers and when they get those answers, more and more they are putting pressure on for different ones. `If that was the answer, I want to rephrase the question, and if he could not possibly develop for us a different answer, we would be very grateful if you tried.'

We see another consequence of what the government has done in the interest rate rise today—duck shoved over to the Reserve Bank neatly by the Prime Minister. But, make no mistake about it, while the RBA did not mention the GST, in the form of not mentioning the war, they said this:

quote.para: The RBA clearly indicated that the interest rate rise is because the balance of risk in the economy is now on inflation.

speech.para: Of course, what is happening is that the price of money globally impacts upon the price of money in Australia. That is obviously the case. But every treasurer and every finance minister knows that the fundamental issue in movement in interest rates is inflation domestically. That is the fundamental issue, and we have a threat to inflation emerging domestically from one source and one source only—the goods and services tax. So that that limited compensation for families, that generous compensation for the wealthy, is being clawed back by the impact of the goods and services tax on the rate of inflation.

What the Reserve Bank knows is what every Australian family knows, and that is that the government's inflation estimates are ludicrous. As a result of that, psychologically there is an anticipation in the community of rates of inflation which are driving themselves now into community behaviour and, what the Reserve Bank will fear, driving themselves into wages as a result of that. It is in anticipation of that that the Reserve Bank is now acting. It has other problems to deal with as well, but it is acting primarily because of what they are anticipating in that regard. They do it in an environment in which they know two other things. Private savings in this country—in part, at least, courtesy of this government—have collapsed. That is the first thing that they comprehend about that, and the second thing that they also comprehend is the impact on the budget. Mr Costello was saying here, after one of the remarks I made earlier today about the impact of the budget, that he is opposed to income tax cuts. That is what has dented the surplus. No, not income tax cuts; the total compensation package for the GST is what has whacked into the surplus. It is the total compensation package related to the GST which is obliging the government to make decisions in relation to the budget, which, in the circumstances that they now face in the economy overall, they would not normally make. But, because the government are making that decision, because they have botched financial administration in this country, the Reserve Bank is acting to deal with it. But, just as the ordinary family carries the burden of their botched GST, so, too, does the ordinary family carry the burden of what is happening in regard to interest rates.

That is why wedge politics are becoming vital to this government, because the one mantra that they have chanted since they came into office—`We know how to manage the economy'—is the mantra most under threat from the experience now in the administration of this economy, from the situation now in the budget, from the reputation that this government is building for a botched implementation of this tax, and from the damage that they have done with small business and others by what are now revealed to be lies about both the simplicity of this tax and its impact overall on prices including, effectively thereby, the cost of doing business in this country.

So in these sets of circumstances somebody has to be out there to blame. And I do believe the reason it has blown up so monumentally in the face of this government—in the party room of this government as well as in the community generally—is that so overwhelming is this damage that no wedge can provide the smokescreen to overcome it. So overwhelming is this damage that they cannot do that. The second reason is there is an assumption there about the decency of the ordinary Australian which is misplaced, an assumption there about the willingness of the ordinary Australian to see the weak demonised. You have got to remember that if you asked the average Australian what they felt most summed up his or her idea of life, they would use an expression like `fair go'. There is virtually no other country on earth where you would elicit that response. And that fair go attitude will often subsume a whole range of prejudices that in the end people will be prepared to dismiss. This government has been tumbled, and we have tumbled them. (Time expired)

talker.name: McGauran, Peter, MP
Mr McGAURAN
talker.role: Minister for the Arts and the Centenary of Federation

talk.start.para: —I have one question to ask of Labor members as they depart the chamber: who amongst you understood what the Leader of the Opposition was saying? Who could make any sense of that totally incomprehensible linking of long unstructured questions together? There was no rhyme or reason to that contribution. It did not make sense. Most of you were bored and uninterested, as was made obvious by your reactions. It is very hard for me on behalf of the government to respond to that contribution, because it is like wrestling with mercury. It did not make sense. There was no consistent line. It was a trip around the world. We heard fleeting references to aged care, Telstra, GST, compensation package, budget surplus.

speech.para: I tried to make a note of them as the Leader of the Opposition was going. I will give him credit: he can certainly spew forth the words, but there was just an avalanche of them, these long 60-word sentences that were—until you read the transcript—utterly incomprehensible. He made no sense. He would occasionally throw in the word `wedge' and think that somehow that was the linking theme to his contribution. He got to interest rates, inflation. He threw away sort of generalised vague insults against the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, the Minister for Employment Services, the minister for social security and, of course, the Prime Minister and the Treasurer. There was just everybody covered and everything, but none of it stacked up. It was totally incoherent. If I were a member of the opposition I would be genuinely worried about that performance, because the MPI promised so much. I remind members of the House of the challenge thrown down by the opposition, by the Leader of the Opposition, today in this matter of public importance:

quote.para: The social and economic consequences of the Prime Minister's failure of leadership and the resultant divisions within the government.

speech.para: We got none of that. We had no case made out about social and economic failure of leadership, let alone divisions within our own ranks. Really, it is very hard. I am going to have to junk my preparatory work for this debate. That MPI was a complete red herring. But I will say there was one serious aspect to the Leader of the Opposition's contribution. In the first three minutes he made a deliberate calculated accusation that the government is practising wedge politics. The media, to the extent that they are prepared to scrutinise the Leader of the Opposition's inconsistencies and hypocrisies, must hold him to proving his case. That is a damning, serious allegation to make. He made it at the beginning, cited the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, the Minister for Employment Services and the minister for social security as deliberately pursuing a policy of wedge politics—never substantiated it, never proved it, never asked questions of them in the House; just a generalised, vague, unsubstantiated insult to fill in time or to test the water. The Leader of the Opposition fails.

I believe the Leader of the Opposition should be held accountable. He has made that allegation. Where is the support for it? Where are the questions to the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, whom he accuses of `tweaking the tail of prejudice', or words to that purpose? To the minister for social security he made a quick unstructured sentence about single mothers. Again: ask the questions, make out the case. Do not spend three minutes quoting from today's Bulletin edition about an American practitioner of wedge politics and somehow link or assign that to the government. It is cowardly to make that charge without evidence, without any convincing case, within—I timed it—three minutes and then scamper from the chamber. He should be held accountable for what he has tried to do today, and that is slur the members of the government and a number of ministers very personally. I think it is pure cowardice on his part. As I best understood the Leader of the Opposition, after all of the rambling and the stupidity of his crazy thought processes, towards the end of his 15 minutes he alleges that there has been social collapse caused by the government's practice of wedge politics.

talk.start.para: —Social collapse?

—That is his claim: social collapse. But, again, it is at the end of his contribution. What does he mean by that? What is his argument? What is the purpose of making such an allegation as he is about to conclude, other than to leave it hanging in the air because he has no evidence. He is misleading the Australian public with allegations of that kind. It does him no credit. He does not have the courage of his convictions to come in here and pursue us at question time on these issues or to make out his case. He knows they are false allegations of the worst kind. And he has a lack of conviction, which is very worrying, on this whole issue of mandatory sentencing. Did he say anything as the Western Australian and Northern Territory governments introduced mandatory sentencing? He is fond of quoting newspaper articles, as we saw just now. As we know, Alan Ramsay, in the Sydney Morning Herald only two weeks ago slammed the Leader of the Opposition and said that it took some 24 days—if my memory serves me correctly—
—Thirty five.

—It took 35 days before publicity forced him to raise the issue of the tragic death in custody of a young man who was subject to mandatory sentencing—35 days. It is not serious to him. The Leader of the Opposition's cowardliness is further proved by the fact that he does not tackle the Western Australian government. Why doesn't he do that? Because it is an election year. I might have missed something—and I am happy to stand corrected—but has the Leader of the Opposition gone to Western Australia and, in front of Dr Gallop, the state Leader of the Opposition, said, `I will use the powers of a Labor government at the Commonwealth level to overrule the Western Australian parliament'? Will he do that? No, he will not. He always attacks, criticises and mocks the Northern Territory government as an easy target. Again, during that by-election for the seat of Shane Stone some three or four weeks ago, where mandatory sentencing was an issue and the Northern Territory Country Liberal Party won that seat in an absolute majority, did the Leader of the Opposition have the courage of his convictions and the strength of principle to go to Darwin and campaign on the issue of mandatory sentencing against the CLP? Of course he didn't. He is totally led by certain columnists, certain people in the media, and by a number of people from the left-wing within his own party.

speech.para: When are we going to see the Leader of the Opposition take centre stage with his own views, his own beliefs and his own policies? All of this is a distraction for somebody who is utterly incapable of preparing policies on all of those issues across government administration that, in the short and long term, daily affect and impact on the Australian people. That is the sadness of this whole issue. Through all of the noise and the screeching of the Leader of the Opposition just now and over the past 48 hours on the issue of mandatory sentencing, one telling point has been very much lost in all that debate—that is, that the range of views on the issue within the coalition government is very much reflective of Australian society. There is no getting away from that. Just as there is a range of opinions and views that are deeply held and sincerely believed by people at different ends of the debate in the community, so there is in our own ranks. I am not apologising for that.

The problem for the Leader of the Opposition is that towards the end of his contribution he said, `Australians know what a fair go is and that is what they want from a government on social and economic policy.' We agree with that, but the Labor Party do not because they will not allow dissent or a range of opinion within their own ranks. I would never argue that any view or any belief expressed by anybody in the community should be allowed, but I know that the Australian people instinctively or inherently know what is a point of view to be tolerated in a liberal democratic society. The David Irvings of the world have no place in community debate, as an example of somebody whom the Australian community will not accept. But, as somebody who was as much seared by the white-hot Hanson phenomenon as anybody, I have always been convinced that one of the major causes of the Hanson phenomenon was the Labor Party because they so extinguished any different point of view. They are so used to doing that within their parliamentary ranks that they think they can do that within the community.

The Australian people will decide fairly and equitably what opinions are totally out of line and off the wall and what opinions are semi-racist or what are not. The point is: let them decide. On these complex, difficult and sensitive social issues there will be differences of opinions within our ranks, but we stay united. Within the Labor Party there is no hope of expressing a different point of view. The Labor Party are therefore making the same mistake now that they have made before, especially during the Keating years. They will not allow a diversity of opinion in the community. They misread the ability of the Australian people to reach objective judgments on an issue such as mandatory sentencing. They are doomed to repeat the mistakes of their own very recent history. Their intolerance of different points of view in the community did more to fuel Hanson than anything else ever did.

You would never really know, would you, what Labor members of parliament believe on the issue of mandatory sentencing, any more than you would on other issues? If they are controversial and complex issues, you will not hear different points of view. That is why the Labor Party are not representing the Australian community. We know that from those who make up the frontbench. Correct me if I am wrong, but two-thirds or three-quarters—it was one or the other—are paid-up union officials. Two former leaders of the ACTU populate their front bench. So you are never going to get a proper understanding of individual enterprise and the need for reward in return for risk or for support for small business. The Leader of the Opposition is off to his national executive this Friday for a discussion or even for a policy formulation meeting, because in effect that is what it will be: a one-liner. What did the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business tell us today? He told us that something like 17 members of the national executive of the Labor Party are union officials. Again, that reflects, in almost exact percentage terms, the number of union officials who make up their frontbench. So no wonder you are getting an almost totalitarian handling of these issues. We are proud on our side of politics that people freely and indeed courageously put their points of view so that we can reach a united position.

Allegations made in the matter of public importance, which was written by some clever press secretary or speech writer in the Leader of the Opposition's office—but they were not mentioned here today, so the promise of the debate was so much more than the actual delivery—suggest that there have been social and economic failures of leadership on our part. Any way you look at it, that is not the case. In health there has been a seven per cent increase in rural doctors in two years. Private health insurance has increased—we have just had the fourth quarterly increase—and it is more inclusive of and more accessible to ordinary Australians, especially those with families. Look at the im-munisation efforts of the Minister for Health and Aged Care. In terms of employment issues managed by the Minister for Em-ployment Services, mutual obligation is widely accepted by the Australian people.

The attacks on him are unfair and inaccurate. On behalf of the Australian people, he is implementing Work for the Dole, Green Corps—that volunteers program—and Job Network, all of which the Labor Party skirt around. They support them. They know they are proper public administration policies so as to get jobs, but they do not have the courage to support them, because their union mates do not want them to. We can look at industrial relations. The unemployment figure is the key figure here, and it is so important. It is 6.8 per cent, down from Labor's almost 12 per cent. We can look at small business. We have reduced inflation to the lowest level in 20 years. We have given small business protection under the Trade Practices Act, and we have brought in the franchising code of practice. In summary, the Leader of the Opposition gave a very worrying contribution to the parliament. He made a grave allegation and then passed over it. He did not substantiate it and, in a coward's fashion, he ran away from it. He has totally failed to appreciate the Australian people's endorsement of government policies both economic and social.

talk.start.para: —I rise to support the matter of public importance, and I ask: where is the Prime Minister? I also ask: how could the Minister for the Arts and the Centenary of Federation ramble on for 15 minutes but spend only two talking about the leadership of his government? I think that says it all. I join with my colleague and leader in condemning the abrogation of leadership the Prime Minister has displayed in his handling of sensitive social and economic issues. I would like to quote from the immortal Bard:

quote.para: Let me not to the marriage of true minds
Admit impediments.

speech.para: What a magic concept—the marriage of true minds, the union of heart, soul, understanding, acceptance, tolerance, love, compassion and kindness. These are concepts the government has no hope, or indeed desire, of emulating. The government is not interested in bringing the people of Australia together. It has failed to live up to its election promise—as slurred as it was—of governing for all of us. It has no desire to unite the heart and soul of those we are privileged to represent—no, it seeks to drive a wedge of division between them. The latest round of government shame is a prime example of the Prime Minister's pandering to the lowest common denominator and his failure of leadership. The people of Australia cry out for their leader to rise above politics on matters of principle, on issues which demand `ticker'—whatever the hell that is. Our Prime Minister has shown time and time again that he has no heart.

The recent examples of the Prime Minister's failure on leadership are about dividing the nation. It is classic wedge politics where issues are used to split the people—as Laurie Oakes has said, creating resentment in a large group against a smaller one, whether whites against blacks or ordinary workers against people on welfare. How ironic that the Prime Minister tries to portray himself as a compassionate conservative—an oxymoron, I think—in a caring government in a caring society. I think not. The government is destroying the notion of Australia being a caring, tolerant, democratic society. It has destroyed the notion that Australia is a bastion of egalitarianism. The social vandals who sit opposite can only destroy and divide. The government cannot hide behind a smokescreen of grubby wedge politics. The people are not stupid: they know the GST will hurt them, they know the sale of Telstra will not bring advantages to the bush, they know the Minister for Aged Care has failed in her duty of care towards nursing home residents, they know there was a stolen generation, they know mandatory sentencing is not the answer and they know the Prime Minister cannot even lead his own party.

There is no greater test of the maturity of a nation than how it deals with its past wrongs. We have seen apologies from the Canadian government to their indigenous people and, most famously, we have seen the recent apology issued by the Pope. But there is still no official apology from the Australian government. The Prime Minister is reluctant to say sorry. This appears to be driven by his fear that an apology will encourage legal claims and his earnest belief that he is supported by the opinion polls. He may even be right, but is this a way to run a country? Australians have a right to expect their government to act in the national interest and to do what is right, even if it is not always popular. On top of this failure to issue an apology, the Prime Minister's weakness over mandatory sentencing is a pathetic attempt to play down the devastation caused by the forcible removal of children from a family. These three issues have done enormous damage to the reconciliation process between indigenous and non-indigenous Australians, undermined Australia's reputation as a progressive egalitarian society and unleashed the simmering divisions that lie within government ranks as many members on the other side of the chamber struggle to resolve their consciences with the poll driven ramblings of a cowardly Prime Minister.

The mandatory sentencing laws that apply in the Northern Territory and Western Australia should be vigorously opposed. They undermine a fundamental tenet of our justice system: that the punishment must fit the crime. In addition, Australia has legal obligations as a member of the international community, something the government also wants to ignore. Australia is a signatory to the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights and to the Convention on the Rights of the Child. They both contain provisions relating to the treatment of juveniles in detention. CROC article 3(1) states:

quote.para: In all actions concerning children ... the best interests of the child shall be a primary consideration.

speech.para: And CROC article 37 states:

quote.para: ... The arrest, detention or imprisonment of a child shall be ... used only as a measure of last resort and for the shortest appropriate period of time ...

speech.para: The basis for all decisions affecting young persons should be that they should be made in the best interests of the child. In view of the age of many of the young people and of their developmental needs, it is important that they be dealt with in a manner that focuses on how to assist them in gaining skills and which supports and corrects behaviour. In many cases, this will be the last opportunity to steer a young person in a different direction. The major focus of a juvenile justice system should be early intervention and prevention so that these people do not enter the criminal justice system. Where they have committed an offence, the emphasis should be on diversion rather than detention.

There is a need in the juvenile and magistrates courts for judgments to be made on all the relevant facts. That is why we have judges—to make judgments. To remove judicial discretion in relation to sentencing reduces the role of a judge to that of a cipher. The logical extension of the policy of the executive removing judicial independence is that judges are dispensable and all criminal matters may be dealt with by mandatory sentences. It takes wisdom and experience to make judgments that take into account the needs of all parties. Very little responsibility is taken for crime prevention. While more interest is focused on the punitive side of the criminal justice system, we are doomed to see young people inappropriately jailed with tragic, sometimes fatal, consequences. Let's consider the statistics. Aborigines in Western Australia are 21 times more likely to be jailed than non-indigenous people. Australian Bureau of Statistics figures for the December 1999 quarter released yesterday show that WA, which introduced mandatory sentencing legislation in 1996, saw a 25 per cent increase in indigenous prisoner numbers over the past year and had the highest rate of indigenous people in jail in the country. The average number of indigenous people in Western Australian jails increased from 785 in 1998 to 977 last year. So much for deterrence.

The Northern Territory, which introduced mandatory sentencing in 1997, recorded the highest proportion of indigenous prisoners—67 per cent. Indigenous people make up approximately 28 per cent of the Northern Territory's population. Again, these laws are not having the impact that this government say they will. To always jail every child with this background for often trivial, victimless property misdemeanours is literally a criminally negligent act, and this pathetic, listless, heartless, pitiless government do nothing when they have the power to intervene. John Howard is the Pontius Pilate of Australian politics, but he cannot absolve himself and his government from the consequences of their actions or, in this case, their culpable inaction.

The third act of reconciliation vandalism executed by the Prime Minister and his government has been the submission to the inquiry into the stolen generation, where Senator Herron, supported by his leader, tried to deny the existence of a stolen generation What constituted a generation? A life span of 30 years, 10 per cent, 30 per cent? Who cares! Playing with semantics and statistics is a horrendous thing to do when you are talking about people's lives, people who are still living with the open wounds caused by this dislocation. I am sure many members have read the poignant contribution to the debate made by the Essendon footballer Michael Long in the Age today. I would like to read from it. It says:

quote.para: How do I tell my mother that Mr Howard said the stolen generation never took place?
How does he explain to me why none of my grandparents are alive?
How do I tell my mother that her grandchildren were never affected by the stolen generation, that they don't know their aunties and uncles, their people?
Does Mr Howard understand how much trauma my grandmother suffered? It ripped her heart out, what she went through. Even when she died, her baby was never returned home.

How do I explain to my children I don't know a lot about my culture, the history of my people, because my mother was taken when she was a baby, taken to Darwin and put on a boat—she had never seen the sea before—screaming and yelling, not knowing what was happening and then crying herself to sleep. I call that trauma and abuse. I am so angry anyone could do this to a child just because their skin was a different color.

speech.para: I have a child. She is up two flights of stairs. I know it would be heart-wrenching to have my six-month old child taken from me. I do not think I could live with that, but we ask these people to actually wipe that away and say it never happened.

All that indigenous Australians are asking for is an acknowledgment of past wrongs, a commitment to fixing the horrendous social problems that bedevilled Aboriginal people and a genuine attempt to advance the cause of reconciliation. Too much to ask? I do not think so, Prime Minister, and if your backbench is a judge I think we can safely say that your wanton cowardice on these issues will be remembered bitterly by your party room, by all fair-minded Australians and, most importantly of all, by the thousands of indigenous people desperately in need of some compassion and positive action from this government.

talk.start.para: —Firstly, anybody who needs to rediscover some of their own humanity need only read a few pages of the report of the inquiry into separated Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander children. I confess that the first time I read it I was in tears myself. I think everybody, including any member of the government and the Prime Minister, has in some way been touched, if not moved, by this. Apart from anything else, the Com-monwealth government has committed over $63 million to try to do what it can by way of reparation for the people who were affected.

speech.para: What the debate is about and what has brought it on—and this is not to suggest that there is insincerity on the part of any one of the individuals who might contribute to it—is, as I said yesterday, politics. As evidence of this, I will demonstrate a couple of things to the House. The first thing is that in question time the member for Canning asked the Minister for Aged Care why, despite being about two per cent of the Australian population, Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people were significantly under-represented in Australian residential nursing home facilities. The answer to that question principally is that indigenous Australians do not live long enough to get to them. Half of the males are dead before they are 50, and four in 10 females are dead before they are 50. The second reason is that, unlike people in Anglo-Celtic culture, indigenous Aus-tralians prefer to be in their own com-munities. They do not like to be placed in residential care facilities away from their com--munities. The second point that I will use to illustrate the fact that this is about politics, for the members of the Australian community who are listening to this, is this: if, for example, any member of the current federal government, including the Prime Minister, were to say this, what kind of reaction do you think it would evoke from the Australian Labor Party? I quote:

quote.para: I am attacking negative welfare—that is, the provision of income support to able-bodied, working age people without reciprocity. It is this that is poisonous and socially corruptive. The provision of income support to able-bodied, working aged adults without reciprocity is the source of our social problems and the starting place for any solutions.

speech.para: Imagine what sort of reaction we would get if the Prime Minister or any member of the government's frontbench were to say that. I can tell you that those words were said by a great Australian, Noel Pearson, on 26 July 1999. Apart from other things, Mr Pearson himself—and I criticise him in no way for doing this—has indicated that at some point he would like to be a candidate for the Australian Labor Party. In fact, I think he would benefit the federal parliament.

Amongst other things in the parliament, I am the co-convener of the all-party group on population, planning and development. In 1998, I was convening a seminar in this place on population, development and reproductive health issues. About 12 kilometres out of Alice Springs there is an Aboriginal birthing service called Alukra. It is run by a congress, the Central Australia Aboriginal Medical Service. The representative from Alukra said in the course of speaking to the conference, `You know, we've actually got the best health minister for Aboriginal people that we have ever had in the form of Dr Michael Wooldridge.' She went on to say, `More has happened in the last three years for Aboriginal people and Aboriginal health than has happened in the past 30.'

I remind the House again, in terms of pointing out to the Australian community that what this debate is about is politics—it has nothing to do with the human beings that underwrite the issue—that in January 1994 then health minister Graham Richardson, one of the fellow travellers of the member for Watson, took Charles Woolley and a 60 Minutes crew to the Top End and Charles Woolley said to him, having surveyed the devastation, despair and existential demoralisation of indigenous Australians, `Why after 11 years in government is the situation still so bad?' Richardson said, `I've spent a lifetime reading polls and concern for Aboriginal people is not in the top million issues worrying the voters.' Mr Richardson was one of the key policy, if not political, strategists for the Australian Labor Party and it is quite clear that those kinds of values still underwrite what drives the Australian Labor Party. In other words, if there is not a vote in it, they are not prepared to support it. Beneath the matter of public importance that has been brought on today are real issues about people who die from diseases that the rest of the country forgot even exist. They are sadly not the topic of what is being discussed today.

What this country needs is a deficit reduction strategy on premature Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander death, a deficit reduction strategy on prejudice, ignorance, intolerance and political opportunism—the sort that we have seen here today.

talk.start.para: (Mr Jenkins)—Order! The Chief Opposition Whip will cease interjecting.

—When I was in Cairns in 1995, I asked the great Rose Colles, who spent her whole life as an Aboriginal woman working with alcoholism in indigenous com-munities, `What does reconciliation mean to you?' She said, `I've spent my whole life trying to reconcile this.' What she meant by that is that reconciliation is not a process where you can say there is an end point and it is going to be 31 May 2000. Reconciliation is about all of us, all Australians, indigenous and non-indigenous, understanding in unembellished ways what happened to those people who are Aboriginal Australians—the impact it had on children who may or may not have been taken from their families, the impact of European settlement—and those of us who accept the legacy, the good and the bad, understanding the impact that it had on our own society and then, together, at some point, as Australians, acknowledging that we have a common and shared future and shared objectives.

speech.para: It is not about political point scoring in the parliament. It is not about trying to draw points off what are legitimate points of view that many Australians hold that I may not personally happen to agree with. Reconciliation has a spiritual component; there is no denying that. But, if it is going to be more than label badges, nice posters at ALP conferences and glitzy dinners at which average Australians will never be, but certainly pay for, then these are the issues that have to be discussed—education, health, housing and employment programs; the sorts of things that have happened under this government. If anything is going to be delivered for people in this country who have neither power nor influence, people who live in poverty, not just Aboriginal people, you have to come into the parliament and support those things that are necessary to sustain high rates of economic growth.

talk.start.para: —Why don't you sit down, humbug.

—You cannot, for example, argue about a goods and services tax on the one hand and then argue about increases in interest rates on the other and not say a damn word about the CFMEU's claim for a 36-hour week and a 15 per cent pay increase.
