We know that here, in Canberra, if someone has a very ill child and they need to go to Sydney for specialist oncology treatment, generally what happens is that the whole family ups and moves for a period of some weeks or months and there are financial and other strains. This group, under the guidance of Yvonne Cuschieri—who I must admit is a wonder woman; she founded the group back in 1986 and it is now flourishing—does very good work.

Millie's family, David and Jane Hagan of Rivett in the ACT, are extremely grateful to the community for its reaction. The Eden Monaro Support Group of course are more than grateful because not only have they answered Millie's call but they have also been able to add to their coffers money that they need to hold so urgently for these people. Also, it is a reflection of the heart of this community in Canberra and the region. When the call is put to us, we really know how to react in this town.

I must report, sadly, though that the Eden Monaro Cancer Support Group's office got flooded overnight and they now need $10,000 to $14,000 to fix their equipment. I am sure that, again, the Canberra community will come to the fore and help them in whatever way they can. I just want to finish off by saying that the Eden Monaro Cancer Support Group, Marty and Erica from FM104.7 and everyone concerned need to really congratulate themselves on such an effort. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Tonight I want to take the opportunity to highlight the failure of the New South Wales Labor government to fund some reconstruction work on Woy Woy Road in my electorate. On 20 March, I put out a press release raising my concerns about the fact that the work on Woy Woy Road had been stopped for some months. My investigations have revealed that, in fact, the state government had refused a council application to fund those works. The only work that had been done on that road was under the federal government's black spot funding. We had, in fact, provided $500,000—the maximum amount under the black spot funding—to allow this work to begin. It was a small deviation in the road to allow two dangerous corners to be eliminated and hopefully to save motorists' lives.

speech.para: The council approached the state government to contribute and to match those funds to allow that project to be finished, but the state government has not contributed $1 to those projects. I understand budgetary concerns and I believe it is difficult to find money. But today—it was almost beyond belief—I read the local Central Coast Express Advocate to find a letter from Carl Scully, the Minister for Roads and Transport in the New South Wales Labor government. He had the audacity to write a letter to the paper berating them for their story about Woy Woy Road. He went on about how much the state government provides to Gosford council for road funding and that the council received money for regional roads on the Central Coast. He also mentioned that it had provided money for another project along that road. He then said, quite correctly, the black spot project on Woy Woy Road is a federal government-Gosford City Council project agreed to by the parties in 1998.

He forgot to mention that that road is a regional road. The responsibility for the funding for that road lies fairly and squarely with the state government and the local council. It really has nothing to do with the federal government, but the federal government recognised that these were dangerous corners and they were prepared to provide the maximum amount of $500,000 to allow those works to at least start. They presumed and hoped—I guess it was a vain hope—that the state government would make a contribution to that reconstruction. The federal government have already provided $1,294,916 in funding to Gosford council to allow the council to construct and repair local roads, so the federal government are certainly doing their bit.
The last bit of Mr Scully's letter in the paper was, I guess, the final straw that made me realise that I had to come and say something in the parliament tonight about his outrageous claims. He said:

quote.para: Mr Lloyd is clearly embarrassed by his Government's inadequate funding of blackspots across our State and is looking for a scapegoat.

speech.para: What a lot of rubbish. In 1999 the federal government provided $12.46 million in black spot funding to New South Wales, and yet Carl Scully has the hide to write a letter to the editor of the paper to say that I am embarrassed by our government's support of the black spot funding.

The other thing I want to remind the parliament and the community about is that in fact it was the Keating government that scrapped the black spot funding. When we came to government in 1996 we had to reinstate the black spot funding. The federal Labor government had scrapped the black spot funding; and yet Carl Scully, the state Labor minister for roads, has the hide to write these sorts of statements in the local paper. It just shows the sort of contempt with which the state Labor government is treating the people of the Central Coast. The message, as far as I am concerned, is loud and clear: every day that those upgrade works on Woy Woy Road remain at a standstill, putting motorists' lives at risk, they will stand as a monument to the state Labor government's arrogance and their contempt for and neglect of the Central Coast. I will continue to remind the residents of the Central Coast about this every single day until the state government puts in some money to fix this dangerous section of Woy Woy Road.

subdebateinfo.title: Welfare Reform: Reference Group Interim Report

talk.start.para: —I rise tonight to talk about the release of the interim report of the Reference Group on Welfare Reform released last week. Its terms of reference drawn up by the government uses terms like `increasing reliance on welfare', `reducing welfare dependency' and `broader application of mutual obligation'. But what does the government mean by these terms? If I had to hazard a guess I would say that this is all about cost cutting and blaming the victim. The whole notion is about spreading the concept of mutual obligation rather than examining how we can look at redistributing the wealth that has come with four straight years of economic growth. Where has the job growth been in that `miracle economy'? It is not there to be seen. I suppose I should not be talking about the miracle economy today after we have had another interest rate rise.

speech.para: To examine the government's form on this, you only have to look at the massive cuts to social security they have ushered in during their time in office. As described by my colleague the member for Lilley in his submission to the review, the Howard government have cut $5 billion from social services programs such as labour market programs, social security payments, disability allowances—the list goes on. This has created an enormous social deficit. The government are comfortable in talking about budget deficits but refuse to acknowledge the social black hole they created as if it is somehow less important.

My office is sort of in the golden triangle. Box Hill is supposedly in the leafy suburbs of Melbourne but my office, like many, is across the road from the Centrelink office. So the people go into the Centrelink office and have an argument with the staff in there, or cannot get to speak to the staff in there because the offices are currently so understaffed. I would like to praise the people in my Centrelink office in Box Hill because they do do a fantastic job. Nevertheless, there are problems generally with the inability to get appointments to meet people. So they come out of the Centrelink office and they come to my office but they are generally looking for money—which, of course, as a member of parliament, I am not allowed to give them. So then we dutifully walk them down to the community information agency, where they might be able to get a food voucher to survive. But generally they are looking for assistance to meet rental payments or for homeless or emergency accommodation. This process goes on, and we seem to be in this `vicious triangle'. If they cannot get something from the community information office, they go back to the Centrelink office and come back into my office—and we feel so incredibly frustrated that there is so little we can do for those people out there.

The report is really just a discussion paper but it did make a number of interesting points. It canvassed the idea of a single work force age payment. It approves of Labor's idea of tax credits and work bonuses and criticises the Job Network and the youth allowance—and I would like to endorse the view that those two things are not working. There are two main elements of this review and government welfare policy I would like to focus on: mutual obligation and redistributive justice. Mutual obligation is a term the government uses to justify its punishing of people on income support. It is a recipe for the government walking away from its part of the bargain. The government has tried to rid itself of responsibilities in finding work by closing down labour market programs and outsourcing responsibility, whilst expecting an ever increasing amount of compliance from recipients. I think that one of the greatest tragedies we have had is the closing of the MIFS program. Job Support, who operate in Box Hill, were running a wonderful MIFS program—a program assisting people with disabilities to get back into the work force. I think it is tragic that that program has been axed, especially as we are seeing the government now turning the blowtorch onto people with disability pensions.

I am also concerned that with a big jump in the number of people existing on disability pensions there may be an attempt to cut back their benefits as they cannot meet the government's tighter guidelines. Sadly, there are many people on these benefits, whether they be lone parents or people with a disability, who cannot work and are likely to come under enormous pressure or, worse still, have their benefits cut. Labor believes in the concept of reciprocal obligation where the government also meets its side of the bargain as well as the individual. The government's responsibility does not just extend to providing transfer payments and training programs; it must also ensure that those on welfare are not so marginalised that they become branded by the community as bludgers or no-hopers—further compounding their problems and weakening our social fabric.
This leads me to the concept of redistribution. I note in their submission to the review that the Catholic Social Services said the following:

quote.para: The question should not be `Can we afford our income support system?' but rather `Can we afford the social dislocation and unrest of a society deeply divided by the haves and the have-nots?'

speech.para: I was amused to see that the member for Lilley had been unable to find Minister Newman's usage of a range of terms like `investing in people' in her four years as minister. This was actually the campaign slogan I won the election on in 1998 and that I think should be the foundation of our social security system.

talk.start.para: —I rise this evening to speak on the white paper on water prepared by the New South Wales government, a paper that has raised much attention since its December 1999 release. The New South Wales government produced the paper to propose a new legislative framework. The proposed Water Management Act is supposed to promote the best use of water and support ecosystems, public health, town water, industry, agriculture and recreation. I personally hold grave concerns about the New South Wales government's white paper—namely that the paper is in direct conflict with the principles laid down in the COAG agreement, in that there is little or no consultation with affected parties.

speech.para: The New South Wales government attempts to confiscate a property right that has been sold on the open market since transferability was introduced. The reference to environmental flows completely ignores the historic river flows associated with Australian rivers before European settlement. I recognise that there is a need to review how we utilise such a valuable resource. However, the impact on communities from job losses cannot and must not be ignored. The New South Wales government does not address the social or economic effects of such a dramatic change at this time. The white paper does not address the problem of compensation for irrigators, who will have their allocations seriously reduced. These allocations have been the basis for substantial investments based on government allocations of water. I believe that the New South Wales government has a moral obligation to use the extra funds that it receives for implementing reforms to offset the cost to people who are adversely affected as a result of these policy changes.

Further consideration should also be given to the impact of a five-year limit on licences. There will be no investment in better water management techniques if a farmer cannot plan for a period greater than five years. Financial institutions will not even consider dealing with them on these terms. Agriculture is worth about $4 billion to my electorate of Riverina, of which the Murrumbidgee Irrigation Area accounts for about $2.5 billion. It is this $2.5 billion which will be in severe jeopardy if water reforms are tilted away from irrigators. Further damage will be caused by the multiplier effect devastating the economies of irrigation communities, such as my communities of Griffith, Leeton and Coleambally. The issue of water management is extremely complex, and the process of reform requires careful scrutiny to achieve a resolve, or else we place our entire irrigation industry at risk.

talk.start.para: —Including the Murray.

—Absolutely. My concerns reflect those of the irrigators in my electorate. I recently received a letter from an irrigation-dependent family. They are a farming family from Whitton in the MIA. In their letter, this family speak of their livelihood being threatened by the reforms proposed in the white paper. They stress that the new act needs to provide all water users with a secure property rights framework based on current entitlements, including off-allocation and other opportunity flows. Irrigation families cannot remain viable if they cannot access water: it is as simple as that. A sensible approach is required so that a situation does not develop whereby water is unaffordable for irrigators. This family sum up an appropriate course of action in their letter:

quote.para: To sustain our viability as irrigators and farmers we don't need these water entitlements to be taken away from us, we need independent and expert reviews of all of our waterways and rivers in consultation with our representatives to come to a just and reasonable conclusion to the problems that are facing us today and for our future generations so that we may be able to continue to supply our nation with cheap food.

speech.para: This is a very serious issue and one that requires the utmost care and attention.

talk.start.para: —As a result of the new tax system, the government now requires employers to report fringe benefits on the group certificates of individual employees. This can fundamentally impact on child support, HECS and superannuation surcharge liabilities, and on entitlements to family payments. Last year Defence personnel were understandably shocked to learn they were not exempt from these requirements. They pointed out that the fringe benefits they receive compensate them for the very real inherent hardships of service life, such as being compulsorily posted away from their home or town and moving their families over the length and breadth of this country. These benefits are not perks or forms of tax minimisation. There are very real, very stark problems that these people face, and that is why these fringe benefits exist.

speech.para: Following a strong campaign on the issue by the opposition, Ministers Moore and Scott jointly announced on 19 August 1999 that housing assistance provided to Defence personnel in Australia would be `totally exempted'—I stress `totally exempted'—`from FBT reporting requirements'. In view of subsequent developments, I would like to quote at length from the comments of Minister Scott in that joint press release. He said:

quote.para: As a result of today's announcement, the amounts paid by Defence for housing assistance for ADF personnel will not be reported on individual's Group Certificates ...

speech.para: `Will not be reported'. He continued:

quote.para: By totally exempting ADF members' housing assistance from the reporting measure, the Federal Government has addressed the primary concerns of ADF families. The Federal Government has addressed the concerns of Defence families about major losses to take-home pay due to loss of government benefits and increased payments such as child support.

speech.para: Subsequent feedback to me raised some comments about aspects of the decision, causing me to write separately to the Minister for Family and Community Services, Senator Newman, and to Minister Scott. The first matter concerned family payments provided by Centrelink. On 28 January 2000 I received a reply from Senator Newman's chief of staff, Rod Nockles, stating:

quote.para: From 1 July 2000 housing benefits received by Defence Force families will have no effect on family assistance ... Centrelink will therefore need to collect relevant information until FA [Family Allowance] is replaced by the Family Tax Benefit in July 2000.

speech.para: In plain English, this means that until 1 July housing assistance to Defence personnel continues to be taken into account in determining their eligibility for family payments, rendering some Defence personnel ineligible for assistance and reducing the rate payable to others. I acknowledge that for some years certain employer provided fringe benefits have been included in the assessment process for family payments. My concern is, however, that at no time did the announcement of last August suggest that the exemption would take place only a full 11 months later. With child support the situation is even more confusing. The letter to me from Senator Newman's office said:

quote.para: Employer provided benefits are not currently considered in determining child support liabilities, unless the payee requests that they be included under a departure from the formula. From 1 July 2000, fringe benefits will be taken into account, although Defence housing benefits and certain other allowances will be exempt.

speech.para: On 16 March I received totally different advice from Minister Scott's defence adviser, Brad Fallen. His reply, in contrast, said:

quote.para: Although housing assistance will be excluded from FBT reporting, it may at any time be considered by the Child Support Agency in child support assessments. The amount of child support that individuals are required to contribute to the support of their children is unrelated to the ADF exclusions from FBT reporting and is a matter that should be addressed through the CSA.

speech.para: Quite interesting buck-passing after such grand public pronouncements that they had totally solved the problem and there was going to be no reporting whatsoever.

It is absolutely outrageous that the offices of two ministers could give me such conflicting advice on a matter of vital concern to Defence personnel. Further, I totally reject their belated effort to argue that the FBT reporting exemption is somehow unrelated to the question of child support liabilities. The fact is that Minister Scott, as I quoted earlier, specifically referred to child support liabilities in the media release of 19 August, as did the Chief of the Defence Force. Any fair reading of these two media releases could only indicate that the value of subsidised housing would definitely not be taken into account in determining any child support liability for Defence personnel. Seven months later we are fed the preposterous proposition that the two issues are unrelated. The whole situation is obviously a total debacle. When I issued a press release on 30 March highlighting the confusion that currently applies, the response of the government was one of embarrassed silence. This is just not good enough. Defence personnel are entitled to know without delay the true position. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Mr Speaker, I rise tonight with a plea for action. The Victorian government is sitting on its hands while many selfless individuals who give tirelessly of themselves to care for people with disabilities wait for action. You might be aware that this is probably the third or fourth time I have raised issues regarding the disability community on behalf of not only the people with disabilities but also their carers and their family members and I called for decisive action to address areas of unmet need. The House may well recall the announcement of the Minister for Family and Community Services on 5 August last year that an additional $150 million would be made available by the Commonwealth over two years, in addition to the current Commonwealth-State Disability Agreement, to address the specific areas of unmet need. At that time the announcement was couched in terms that the Commonwealth was already overperforming in its obligations under the Commonwealth-State Disability Agreement, and was offering additional assistance to the states to fulfil their obligations under that agreement.

speech.para: I rise tonight to particularly speak about the area of accommodation. I was fortunate enough to be part of a demonstration organised by Headway in Victoria last weekend where carers and loved ones of young people with acquired brain injuries and other types of disabilities were campaigning, in support of their family members, for appropriate accommodation. At the moment, people with acquired brain injuries and the like often are accommodated in residential aged care facilities as that represents the safety net—their only alternative to receive the type of care and support that they require. Family members were campaigning for more appropriate care for these people so that they could be with people of their own age and with their own requirements and enjoy and be stimulated by one another's company and shared interests. It is interesting to look at the figures as they affect Victoria and to contemplate the number of young people that are accommodated in residential aged care facilities, often inappropriately. In Victoria more than 170 people under the age of 50 receive high care support in residential aged care accommodation. Those people are not appropriately accommodated in aged care facilities. They need more appropriate facilities designed for their particular needs and circumstances.

As we stood on the steps of the Victorian Parliament House last weekend, on a rather chilly day, hearing compelling and moving stories from family members and advocacy groups about the needs of these young people, I was again listening to the Victorian Minister for Community Services, the Hon. Christine Campbell, tell me that the Victorian government is working on a plan. That would not of itself have caused too much concern, other than the fact that that was exactly what I heard that very same person say back in October when I addressed the One Voice disability group and family members talked about the need for appropriate accommodation for younger people with intellectual disabilities. So all that time has elapsed—more than six months has passed by—with the federal government offering $150 million to state and territory governments to assist them with their obligations under the Commonwealth-State Disability Agreement, and what has happened in Victoria? Absolutely nothing has happened to advance the interests of those families who are caring for people with intellectual disabilities and acquired brain injuries. There is a chronic need for additional accommodation.

If the Victorian government wants to continue to sound empathetic and interested and be known as the doey-eyed, do-little government in the country, but cannot manage this task, it should give the Commonwealth a call. We have already identified where the additional money should be applied. If the Victorian government cannot organise itself to make a submission to match dollar for dollar that $150 million the Commonwealth has made available to help ageing parents and carers who are now in their 70s and 80s care for people with intellectual disabilities, provide appropriate retirement structures for ageing individuals who have an intellectual disability or address the young people inappropriately accommodated in nursing homes, maybe we need a new government in Victoria. It is not doing anything about a problem that is serious and that profoundly affects the lives of many people in my electorate. The Commonwealth is there with $150 million. All the Victorian government has to do is say, `We will match you. We will meet you dollar for dollar. We will put action in place.' This is indifference. This do-little government in Victoria needs to get off its backside and do something to help this very desperate group of people in our community because the Commonwealth is there, with the cash, ready to play its part.

talk.start.para: —Order! It being 8.00 p.m., the debate is interrupted.
to present a bill for an act to amend legislation relating to postal services, and for related purposes.

business.start.para: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Nehl) took the chair at 9.40 a.m.

talk.start.para: —This morning I want to briefly continue on the theme of changes to the social security system highlighted in the recent welfare reform report released by the Minister for Family and Community Services, Jocelyn Newman. This report has generated considerable interest in my electorate and, one would imagine, in everyone else's electorate as well.

speech.para: I want to place on record part of a letter written to me by Phil Nichol of Lymington who, on hearing the minister's comments on Radio National, wrote to me as follows:

quote.para: Anyway my feelings and those of others I know were one of optimism and I would hazard a guess that many people who feel left out of the prosperity of this present society felt good about what they heard. Most people receiving benefits and even low income earners hope others in society want to share in mutual obligation and social cohesion. Most recipients of benefits, no matter what type, I am sure would welcome organized community involvement but NOT if it is portrayed in a negative fashion, if there is stigma attached to the work, if it is seen in any way like a punitive measure, if there is resentment in the air and if it is not flexible and chosen in some way by the participant.

Many people on benefits live busy exciting useful lives even with small amounts of cash. If people on small incomes pay little tax that will also be rectified after July when benefit recipients too will be GST taxed.

Senator Newman on 29/3/00 indicated that Centrelink in the past has portrayed an abrupt non-inclusive type of front. The new Centrelink would be different. Personally I have always found individuals in Centrelink very nice—its what the people working there have been asked to carry out.

To my thinking her comments the next day ... seemed to backtrack from the 29/3/00. The whole feeling of trust, fellowship and furtherance seemed now to be at odds with comments the previous day. She seemed political and divisive. Imagine thinking low income earners would be glad that those receiving benefits would be obliged to do their dues. Why did she pick LOW INCOME EARNERS? Why not the rich, say those on $1 million a year, would those people also not feel glad of mutual obligation? This welfare reform must:
have no stigma of a negative kind attached to benefit recipients;
have no negative stigma attached to the type of work they do;
they, mutual obligers, should not be `told' what to do but should in agreement with a broad selection of community members choose the work they do for the benefit of all;
it must be flexible.
N.B. Benefit recipients might even be able to do or help with some of the work low income earners do then we can all be friends together bettering our communities.

talk.start.para: —I want to speak briefly this morning about the successful west RFA outcome in Victoria. The Victorian timber industry can now get on with the job of attracting new investment and value adding. There were a number of important aspects in these RFA negotiations. Firstly, there will be no net job losses as a result of the final two RFAs in Victoria. I am very pleased that we are going to achieve that. The Commonwealth and state governments together are providing a package of $42.6 million under the Common-wealth-Victorian Hardwood Timber Industry Development Restructuring Program to help businesses take advantage of RFA certainty and adjust to changes in resource availability. The bulk of this funding will be for industry development and value-adding projects. The program also provides a safety net for businesses and workers. This brings the available cash under FISAP to $33.8 million, of which $18.8 million comes from the Commonwealth and $15 mil-lion from the state of Victoria. A further $20 million is committed by the Victorian govern-ment to silviculture and plantation initiatives, improved inventories and tourism development. The resource reductions that were part of the RFA will be phased in over two years which will help the value-adding projects get off the ground.

speech.para: The conservation outcomes are also outstanding in Victoria. More than half of the total public land across all five RFA regions is now protected in the comprehensive adequate and representative—CAR— reserve system. Overall in Victoria, 68 per cent of all old-growth for-est in the five RFA regions are in reserves. In west Victoria the RFA adds about 194,000 hectares to existing reserves. This brings the total CAR reserve amount to 633,000 hectares, which means that 65 per cent of the region's public land is now set aside for conservation. Significant additions to reserves include the Pyrete Range in the Wombat State Forest, which is added to the Lerderderg State Park, and Tallageira, which becomes a nature conservation reserve.

I would like to pay significant tribute to both Minister Tuckey and Minister Garbutt in Victoria, who I think had very sensible discussions in relation to a very difficult issue. Also, there has always been a strong relationship between Minister Tuckey and the union movement in Victoria, who have worked very hard to protect the interests of their workers in conjunction with both the federal and state governments.

In the 30 seconds remaining to me, I would like to talk about the behaviour of the Depart-ment of Natural Resources in Victoria. The difficulty with this RFA was very much to do with a significantly reduced sustainable yield figure which was brought out late last year. Everyone involved in the industry had been relying on the figures of the state department. This is not a political comment; it is a comment about the state department, which had been telling us that all was well and then it turned out that it was not. This has caused enormous difficulties. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I would like to bring to the attention of the House a road safety ini-tiative that is operating in my electorate of Swan which targets primary school students. This initiative was started last year because we felt that young people returning to school needed to be made fully aware of road safety issues. We needed to look at issues such as how they could safely ride their bikes, skateboards and rollerblades. If they were having to cross streets on their way to school, we needed to make sure that they could do so safely, without being hit by vehicles.

speech.para: We looked at implementing a road safety competition. We involved local primary schools. We approached the principals and asked for their support and we found that that support was quite overwhelming. We talked to parent groups and found that they believed there was a real need to teach young people about road safety issues. Of course, we talked to the young people themselves and asked them what they believed would be a good way of getting them to be-come aware of road safety issues. We also approached an organisation called Constable Care. Constable Care in Western Australia is a child safety program. They run a whole raft of pro-grams dealing with the whole issue of child safety—stranger danger issues, road safety and a whole raft of activities aimed at ensuring that children are protected.

When we came up with the competition we thought we would need to have two groups of primary school students, so we looked at grades 1 to 4 and decided that we would introduce a drawing competition for them, whereby they would have to do a drawing on road safety and include a number of different points—which I will cover later. For children in grades 5 to 7, being in that older category, we thought it would be appropriate for them to write an essay on road safety. We asked the representatives from Constable Care to judge all the entries.

We asked the young people to look, in their drawings and essays, at the issues of children wearing bicycle helmets, children on skateboards et cetera, wearing protective pads, and chil-dren using the term `stop, look and listen' when crossing the road in order to ensure their safety. We asked them to illustrate crosswalk attendants in their drawings to show that they knew that the crosswalk was where they needed to go to cross the road on their way to school. We also asked them to mention or include a picture of Constable Care and to mention their school so that we could promote the activities of the school in supporting parents.

I am pleased to say that we have received hundreds of entries. The program has been ex-tremely successful. I commend the program to the House. If any member would like some more information on what we have done, I will be pleased to provide it.

talk.start.para: —I would like to take this opportunity to refute comments made by the member for Isaacs, Mr Wilton, in the House yesterday, particularly in relation to the Riv-erside Nursing Home and the Minister for Aged Care, Mrs Bronwyn Bishop. I would like to quote from an article in the Australian of 18 March 2000 by Amanda Hodge. She quotes the St Vincent's aged care chief executive, Kerrie Cross. The article stated that initially:

quote.para: Relatives feared that moving Melbourne's Riverside Nursing Home residents would kill them. But just 10 days after the move, nursing staff say the improvement shown by some of them is so remarkable they are comparing it to the restoration of the senses depicted in the Robert De Niro movie Awakenings.

speech.para: Kerrie Cross stated:

quote.para: `What we found is most of them were either overmedicated or receiving inappropriate medication ... We did expect residents to improve once they settled down, but we've seen some remarkable transfor-mations in the health and well-being of residents, and relatives have commented on that.'

From all that Ms Cross has already seen, there is no doubt in her mind that despite the initial trauma it caused, federal Aged Care Minister Bronwyn Bishop did the right thing by revoking the Riverside proprietors' licence.
Joe West, 64, is equally convinced.
Eighteen months ago he entered Riverside to help mend a broken hip and in that time he developed such horrific foot ulcers, `the size of CDs', that he could barely walk.
Now on the mend and one of only a few residents not suffering some degree of dementia, he regu-larly takes himself down in the lifts of St Vincent's for a cigarette and some sunshine.
Like many of the former Riverside residents, Joe has no idea where he will go from here.
All he knows is, even if the Riverside proprietors do have their licence reinstated, he never wants to go back.

speech.para: And for the benefit of those opposite I would like to repeat the fact that all he knows is that even if the Riverside proprietors do have their licences reinstated, he never wants to go back.

For the benefit of the member for Isaacs, I believe a few facts need to be incorporated into Hansard. The government's aged care reforms are designed to improve the quality of care and the vast majority of the `good' facilities are getting on with the business of providing high quality care and services. The poor performers are now under scrutiny and the media are highlighting this fact. This is a sign that the system of ensuring quality care in residential fa-cilities is working. It is not simply a matter of closing a home. We must protect the health and wellbeing of the very frail people in the home and, if one is closed, find suitable accommoda-tion elsewhere. It is only with the most careful consideration and planning that we would move residents. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —For quite a few years now, along with other members of the House, I have pointed out to the government the injustices that arise from anomalies in terms of eligibility for some categories of repatriation benefits for Australian former service-men who served in various theatres throughout South-East Asia over the last 40 years or so, most specifically naval personnel associated with the Far East Strategic Reserve during the Emergency in what was then Malaya in the late 1950s and early 1960s.

speech.para: Several years ago, the Minister for Veterans' Affairs did provide some limited relief to these veterans in terms of repatriation benefits. However, he failed at that stage to rectify the most substantial anomaly, which was denying the former RAN personnel access to service pensions which Army and RAAF personnel from the same theatre are entitled to. Really, the only justification that was ever offered for failing to correct that anomaly was a lot of legalistic mumbo jumbo that seemed to come out of the bureaucracy.

Last year, in May 1999, the minister announced a review of these matters and appointed Major General Mohr and Rear Admiral Kennedy to carry out a review of anomalies in respect of South-East Asian service. I will read a couple of paragraphs of that review. The key aspect is the recommendation that is now before the government:

quote.para: It is recommended that such anomaly—

speech.para: That is, the anomaly in respect of service pension—

quote.para: should be removed by placing naval seagoing personnel serving with FESR in the period 01 July 1955 to 31 July 1960 on the same basis as other members of FESR and in particular, to grant them qualifying service so that they will be eligible for the Service pension.

speech.para: The review makes the point that seagoing naval personnel formed part of the RAN contingent to the British Commonwealth Far East Strategic Reserve. These personnel have never been eligible for repatriation benefits until 1997. In 1997, the government accepted a recommenda-tion that their service be classified as operational service. Ex-service personnel organisations representing the interests of seagoing naval personnel, however, continued to press for the period of service to count as qualifying service for the service pension.

The minister now has this recommendation from the review he has commissioned before him. The recommendations are quite clear. I must indicate that the review is a little late; the minister expected it in October last year, but in due course it has arrived in February this year. He really now has no justification for failing to correct the longstanding injustice.

subdebateinfo.title: East Timor: Support for Service Families

talker.name: Brough, Mal, MP
Mr BROUGH
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business

talk.start.para: —Last week I found myself in Darwin on my par-liamentary duties and I had great pleasure in catching up with an old unit that I served with, the 5th/7th Battalion, Royal Australian Regiment. I only caught up with one of the officers because the unit is in Timor at the moment. They have been over there for seven months and they return on 3 May.

speech.para: I rise today in the Main Committee to commend the 5/7 RAR pit crew. The pit crew are the ladies who are supporting their husbands whilst they are overseas. All the attention—and rightly so—goes to the service personnel who are obviously doing a great job in Timor. But quite often we forget that the family members left behind have to carry on, run households and look after the children, and they need a great deal of support. I believe the CO's wife, Patti Jane Gould, instigated the very first pit crew, as she called it, and appointed a committee which was brought from all ranks—no rank-specific involvement at all. This committee was headed by Mrs Rebecca Tufekic, who I believe has done an absolutely fabulous job in keep-ing up the morale of the wives, the girlfriends and the families during the seven-month absence of their loved ones.

They have run a number of functions. They have produced continual newsletters. They have actually had their own operations room set up in battalion headquarters. I am led to be-lieve that they could well be doing a better job than some of their husbands. In fact, that is what they are trying to lead me to believe. Perhaps their husbands, when they return, may find themselves out of a job. There have been some very important aspects to their job because, as you can appreciate, in all walks of life we all have little crises that crop up from time to time, and not having the husband or the boyfriend around can obviously lead to greater distress. They have set up welfare phones lines so that they know where the soldiers are at any par-ticular time, what operation they are on and when the mail is likely to be getting through.

One quick story that was relayed to me was that each of the soldiers gets five minutes every week to ring home. This has been set up through Optus and it is a great initiative. One par-ticular fellow rang home to find that home was not there any more. That was his first five-minute call and, obviously, there was a bit of concern. The following week he rang his mother-in-law—for five minutes—who told him where his wife now was. So three weeks later, on the third five-minute phone call, he finally found where his wife had been relocated to. It was all fine, it was all above board, but can you imagine the angst for a soldier in the field having to wait an additional week to get a five-minute phone call. It was here that the members of the pit crew were able to come in and support the families on the ground.

I would also like to add congratulations to the two assistant adjutants, Lieutenant Paul Greive and Lieutenant Damien Kook, who both, I am told, have done a fabulous job in main-taining the morale of the battalion. They are due back in Darwin on 3 May. I am sure all of Darwin wishes them well and will give them a welcome return.

debateinfo.title: A NEW TAX SYSTEM (FAMILY ASSISTANCE AND RELATED MEASURES) BILL 2000

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 9 March, on motion by Mr Anthony:

motion.para: That the bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: —I rise today to speak on the A New Tax System (Family Assistance and Related Measures) Bill 2000. This bill forms part of the government's overall tax package and is all about how this bill is going to interact with the GST, family payments and a whole range of payments that families are going to get. That leads me, quite clearly, to talk about where the family is in today's society. The family is the backbone, the centre, of everything we do in this country. The family is that unit in our society which really holds us all together. It is really about what keeps us going, and it is the part that the government should be placing the most importance on to be able to deliver something positive. This is where this bill absolutely fails, because there is no way in the world that there is anything in this bill that looks to build on the family or to assist the family or to somehow compensate or make life easier in relation to the huge impost that the GST will have on families.

speech.para: Families are a changing composition in our society. What was previously seen as the nu-clear family has changed somewhat today. We are finding that more people are choosing to have fewer children, and there is probably a variety of reasons why that is the case. But it is clearly evident that today there are just not many people deciding to have three or more chil-dren. In fact, more couples are deciding to have only one child or to have no children at all. There is almost a trend developing. Australia is becoming a childless society. I think part of the reason for that is that people are actually struggling and finding it more difficult to make ends meet. They are finding that to have a family is actually a huge burden. There is not just the financial burden; there are all sorts of other burdens. Government policies are not family friendly—they are very much antifamily. If we have a close look at this bill, what we will find is a whole raft of antifamily policies. Every single one of them is part and parcel of the anti-family policies of this government.

If we have a look at the GST to start with, we can see that the whole GST is based on con-sumption. Who consumes more? Is it the upwardly mobile yuppie living on his own in a nice unit in the North Shore of Sydney, or is it the family with three children? Who has the most disposable income? Who actually consumes more in terms of disposable income? It is the family. The family with two or three children actually suffers. They are the ones who have less opportunity for work because they have children to care for, so they cannot do the over-time. They are the ones who have bigger costs when they go shopping. They are the ones who actually carry the burden for the high income earners. That is what this policy is all about.

But it goes much further and much deeper than that. We have all talked a lot about the costs and the problems associated with the GST for the family, but what about education? How does GST impact on education? We are all told that education is GST free. I beg to differ. I do not think it is GST free at all. I think education has a huge GST component to it, but I will have a look at that in a minute. If we look at health, who is it that pays the majority of the health cost? Is it the single person living in a unit on the North Shore of Sydney? No, it is the family. They are the ones that have to take the children to hospital. They are the ones that are being forced, through legislation, to have to take up private health insurance. So when I say that this government's policies are all antifamily, I am quite serious about that because every single area you turn to, every place you look at, every policy that this government has is anti-family. In particular, the A New Tax System (Family Assistance and Related Measures) Bill 2000 that is before the House is actually very much antifamily.

I think we need to take a new approach. It is time that this government and all governments looked very carefully at what government policy is doing to families. There needs to be a new approach, an approach that says, `We support families. We will do that not just through rheto-ric, but we will do it through our policies. We will actually give you something concrete. We will give you family assistance that means something. So that if you want to go from welfare to work, then you actually have an incentive through government policy,' not a disincentive. That is what this policy is about—disincentives for people to go from welfare to work.

I talk to people all the time who come to my office and say, `I would love to be able to go out and do a little bit more, but if I go out and I try to do a bit of overtime to give my family a little bit extra, the government slugs me. Not only am I slugged through tax, but I am slugged through family assistance.' So it is always a double whammy. Now, for the first time in this country, we are about to see the triple whammy take place. Not only are families going to be slugged on tax, not only are they going to be slugged on family assistance, they are about to be slugged with the GST as well. On 1 July the triple whammy hits, because on 1 July they will also carry the new burden in this country that is squarely being shouldered by all the families. It will be low and middle income families that will carry the load. It is not going to be a burden on the people earning $50,000, $60,000, $70,000, $80,000 or $90,000 a year. They are going to be better off. So if they are not carrying the burden, who is? Who is going to be carrying the burden for this country in the future under a supposedly new tax system for a new century? That is quite easy to answer—it will be families. Again, when I say that this bill and this government's policies are antifamily, I am quite serious about it because every-where I look I see only antifamily policies.

The government also talks a lot about what we might do in terms of education. There is talk of literacy and a whole heap of things, but there is very little talk in terms of money going back to families through early intervention programs and trying to do something positive. You do not see too much money going to early intervention programs. You do not see too much money going to programs that will assist people and take them from where they are today and give them a hand up, or just a bit of assistance. Rather, you see measures that are designed to create more bureaucracies, and more measures that are designed to move the goalposts just a little bit further every time, just to make it that little bit more difficult. There is a raft of things in here, which I will talk about shortly, that actually covers that.

The government also claims that inflation will be only 1.9 per cent—and it made a very big issue at the last election about that. This was the key to compensation packages and to selling this policy and legislation to the people. We all know that that is absolutely incorrect. The 1.9 per cent was probably blown on the first day. It is just not the case. Try about five per cent. Try a little bit more. What are we seeing today? What is the evidence we have right before us? If you pick up Choice magazine, they say, `You might be $3 better off with your shopping.' I do not agree with them. I do not think that is true at all. I and a lot of other people have actually been doing a price watch survey out there to monitor the cost of a fairly reasonable standard basket of goods, not after GST, but right now.

What has been the cost over the last nine or 12 months? Let me tell you. Since this government has put forward its policies, there has been a steady increase, an inflationary rise based on the expectation that GST will cause prices to go up, and not just in the services or goods sector where we know GST will be applied but also on things that have no GST, such as basic foods, milk and bread. I was shocked to see some of the results that have come out of that price watch over the last six months. What we have seen is what I would describe as some people taking the opportunity to actually raise prices and increment them slowly. That is all fine and well—1.9 per cent means absolutely nothing to most people because 1.9 per cent does not represent anything to do with reality and the real costs.

If you talk to a family about their real costs—what it costs them to survive week to week, because for a lot of them it is just survival—you will see the real picture, and that 1.9 per cent soon means absolutely nothing. What does the government do? It claims that raising a child under the GST will cost an extra 30c a week. I cannot even begin to imagine where that statement or a figure like 30c a week would come in because, through my own calculations, I can tell you now that it is not 30c. If we talked dollars, we would start getting closer to the figure. It will not be cents. It will be dollars and it will be big dollars—double-digit dollars. That extra cost has already occurred since 1998 and we have not even got to 1 July as yet.

It is ridiculous for the government to make all these claims about how the GST is somehow miraculously going to put some money in your back pocket. There is going to be no extra money in your back pocket. You are going to end up with a lot less. This bill is called `family assistance'. It is not family assistance, it is family dis-assistance. It is family anti-assistance. It is family anything but assistance. All the measures that are contained in this bill are about keeping people on welfare and keeping people down. There is nothing in here about giving people a hand up. It is almost about punishment. There is talk in this bill about zero tolerance. There is talk in this bill about a whole range of things, but there is nothing in here that says, `We are going to try and move people out of welfare traps and give them a hand up.' It is just not in here. There is nothing in here about trying to help a parent who is unemployed and give them more incentives. None of that is contained in here.

The recent welfare reform interim report recognised a number of problems contained in this bill, in particular the way the antifamily Youth Allowance interacts with family tax benefits. The report actually stated that this is:

quote.para: ... an extreme case where tight and poorly integrated social security income tests can severely discourage workforce participation.

speech.para: People who have looked at this quite closely actually concur that this is not about encouragement, it is not about existence, it is actually quite the opposite. Over a period of time we have become used to the fact, as my good colleague and friend, the member for Port Adelaide, has said on quite a number of occasions, that this is a government that uses newspeak, the language of government in 2000—that is to say, more is less and less is more. That is what this is about: more is less, less is more. It is amazing—and this is coming through in a whole range of government policies and bills—that somehow by giving you less the government is actually being good to you and giving you more.

talk.start.para: —Tough love!

—Absolutely. It is all about tough love: there is a lot of tough and very little love. It is all about less being more. The government claims in the interim report that, once again, this is all about families. I dispute that completely. It is all about punishing families. It really reinforces—and this is what concerns me—at a deeper level, I suppose, the long-term effects. This policy is antichildren. It is about childless societies. That is what we are pushing. That is where these policies are going. It might sound a little out there to make those sorts of comments, but what are the long-term effects when you look at the trend in today's statistics? There is a statistic out there that says something like, `If you have three children in your family, you represent only 17 per cent of the community.' I have three children, and I can tell you now that having three children is wonderful, that it is fantastic. It is great to have a family, but there are not too many policies out there that would actually encourage you. When I talk to my friends they say that I am crazy. They say that my wife and I are mad and that we are totally different from the rest of the community in that everyone else is having only one child. They ask, `Why would you have more children when you cannot afford it as one of you would have to give up work?' They say that a family with one working parent is finding it more and more difficult to survive.

speech.para: So where does family assistance come in in this bill? Nowhere. It is nowhere at all, because there is nothing in this bill that actually encourages a family to either stay a family or become a family. This bill discourages families, it discourages people having children. When we start talking about the backbone of society, what Australia is about and how we are all about families, I would like to see that backed up by a little bit of policy that actually supports it. I would also like to see it backed up with a reversal in trends. Somewhere down the track we actually have to look at the much deeper problem that exists.

What we are also seeing in this bill which is extremely disturbing is the new income estimates rule. This is very disturbing in the way that low and middle income families can incur debts. You are required by Centrelink to actually go in there on a fortnightly basis and estimate your income. On the surface, that sounds quite fine. You might not think there is a problem with that. But if you make a mistake of $1 or if there is an overestimation, you have to repay the debt incurred. That is fine. No-one disputes that if you incur a debt you pay it back. But I think the problem here is that currently 32 per cent of family payments are in error. They are in error because it is almost impossible to actually estimate your income from fortnight to fortnight and get it spot on every time. If you do not get it spot on, what is your reward? If you do not get it right with Centrelink, you have to pay back the debt.

Okay, so you pay back the debt. What happens when you have to do that? You get less money and that makes it tougher for you. What happens then? Again, life becomes harder. For the 32 per cent of families out there who have incurred a debt of, on average, about $1,000, that is $1,000 less they are going to have. Sure, they had it in the first place, but they have to pay it back. It is always easy to say, `You earnt that money. You got that money. We gave that to you, so give it back.' You hardly notice a couple of dollars a week or a few dollars a month coming in, but you really notice it when it is going out. When it is coming out of your pay and the government says, `Give us back our money,' then we have a real problem.

Currently there exists a margin for error, because the government has realised that it is not always possible to get it spot on. If you are working overtime, and you are doing those normal things that a family does, then the errors can creep in. But now the government is talking in this bill about `zero tolerance'—no 10 per cent margin, no buffer zone. These families are not cheating the system, they are just going in there and honestly trying to estimate. It is almost impossible because you work a couple of hours overtime one week and none the next: it is all over the place.

So what happens under zero tolerance? If you are $1 out, you have to pay it back—you in-cur a debt. So you become a debtor to the government. And if you become a debtor to the government under this bill, you then cannot claim an advance. Again it is every little bit, al-ways that little increment. It is always about ratcheting it up one more level to make it harder and harder. I keep questioning: what is the purpose of this; what are we doing? What is the purpose of handing out a few dollars to some people to try and assist them, and then making it as hard as possible, not only to qualify, to actually get the assistance in the first place, but to maintain it?

What zero tolerance means for this government is zero tolerance for families. That is what it is about. Zero tolerance means, `We are not going to tolerate your making a $1 error. We are not going to tolerate your making an estimate.' I always thought that an estimate was just that—an estimate. `Can you please give me an estimate of what you think this might be for the next fortnight?' `Well, since it hasn't happened yet, I will give you an estimate. That esti-mate might be out by a few dollars, and, sure, I might incur a debt and have to pay it back.' Why can't this government look a bit more closely at doing something positive, instead of trying to slug these people with an average debt of about $1,000, which they incurred quite unjustifiably? Again it is all about newspeak by the government: more is less, less is more.

There is a range of other parts of the legislation which are quite disturbing. A funny situa-tion arises with regard to the incurring of a debt, in that if you are a high income earner you can make your claim at the end of the year. You do not have to estimate anything; you can actually do it dollar for dollar. You can get the accountant to do it for you. If you are in that comfortable bracket and you are getting a little bit more, you are fine, but in the lower and middle income earners bracket—where the majority of people are and where this debt is actu-ally incurred—people actually need the money week to week. They need those few extra dol-lars. That is why the dollars are there. So they are the ones that carry the burden. Everywhere you turn in this bill, you find it is quite clear on a number of things such as zero tolerance. And who carries the burden? The burden is shouldered by those least able to afford it.

The legislation contains also a number of issues about shared care arrangements. Currently there is a 30 per cent care arrangement with the non-custodial parent, where if you care for the child for 30 per cent of the time, then you get part of the allowance and so forth. The government is going to reduce that to 10 per cent. It is an absolutely ridiculous proposition. There has been no consultation. The Single Mothers Council of Australia has rejected this idea, saying it means that, if you care for the child for one day a week or a little more, you can claim part of the allowance. So the main carer, who might have the child for 90 per cent of the time, suddenly loses money.

To wrap up: there is a whole range of issues in here and it would take me hours to go through them one at a time. What I would like to say is that this clearly demonstrates the antifamily values of this government. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —The A New Tax System (Family Assistance and Related Measures) Bill 2000 amends, to make viable, the consolidation of 12 family payments into three. The original act has merit, in my view, but this bill is a very lengthy one and re-veals some faults, at least in the planning process for the implementation of the government's intentions—announced at the election—for the consolidation. I believe consolidation is a step in the right direction, because the overlapping of a plethora of family payments with the tax system has created a lot of complexity. It has also created the problem of high effective mar-ginal tax rates. As benefits are withdrawn with earned income, the tapering effect of that withdrawal rate in relation to a number of the family payments is very high. Also, you are paying income tax on every extra dollar beyond the tax-free threshold. So to obtain the effec-tive marginal tax rate is quite simple: you add together the marginal rate of income tax and the withdrawal rate or the taper rate. Some of those effective marginal rates of tax are quite hor-rific.

speech.para: The damage that they do is concentrated on lower and middle income families because it has the effect of creating poverty traps, of making the transition from welfare to work that much more difficult because the incentives to move from welfare to work are greatly im-paired. Put simply, when someone who is receiving some form of government payment looks at the amount of money they will have in their pockets from making the decision to move from welfare to work or to move from, say, casual or part-time work to full-time work, they realise that there is very little left in their pockets. Quite rationally, in many cases, they make the judgment that it might be better not to take that extra work, not to take that extra job, but to wait for something better to come along because they are able to retain only such a small proportion of income from that extra effort, that extra work.

I have to say that some of these high marginal rates or effective marginal rates of tax are, in fact, the result of a number of very good initiatives that were taken by the previous Labor government to increase payments to low income families. I refer in particular to Bob Hawke's child poverty pledge when he was maligned for setting as a goal—and it was a goal—that no child shall live in poverty by 1990—

talk.start.para: —You missed out a word.

—In fact, the technical section of the whole documentation said that no child need live in poverty, and that did not make it into the speech. That is history. But behind that election statement were a huge number of dollars for low income families. It gives me, as a former employee of the then Prime Minister Bob Hawke, great pride to be able to report some of the impacts of that child poverty pledge and other initiatives taken by the Labor gov-ernment at that time.

speech.para: It is a fact that earnings inequality in Australia widened more sharply over the 20-year period from the mid-1970s to the mid-1990s than in any other OECD country. But this was al-most fully offset by the progressive income tax system and government transfers to low in-come earners, and government transfers to low income earners is really what we are talking about in this legislation. As a result, over that period from the mid-1970s to the mid-1990s, Australia achieved a fall in poverty, as was the intention of the child poverty pledge, which `was concentrated in the second decade when Labor was in power'. That quotation comes from Access Economics in a major report that it produced in 1999—just last year. And these findings of Access Economics have been confirmed by the National Centre for Social and Economic Modelling, NATSEM, which found, for the period 1982 to 1993, that:

quote.para: Changes in the tax transfer systems appeared sufficient to fully offset growing inequality of market in-comes, resulting in little change in the aggregate distribution of disposable income.

speech.para: What these two studies reveal is that market incomes did widen quite dramatically over the 30-year period from the 1970s through to the end of the 1990s, but in the latter decades, when Labor was in power, the transfers associated with the child poverty pledge and other commit-ments to lift up low income families meant that the inequality in Australia overall did not widen in spite of that dramatic, sharply widening gap between the earnings of high income and low income earners. I think it is actually a cause for great pride, on both sides of the parliament, that that was achieved. But what it inadvertently did was that, by piling these extra payments on top of each other, the withdrawal rates all compounded, so you did get very high effective marginal rates of tax. It was not an intended consequence; it was unintended.

There has been a great opportunity for this government to deal with that problem. Unfortunately, in the legislation, it makes some progress in some areas but, particularly in the area of the unemployed—people on Newstart—very little progress has been made. I refer to the example of an unemployed person receiving Newstart who is offered a job, say, in the range of $10,000 to $15,000 a year, which is quite common; if you have been out of work, it is not highly likely that you will be offered a $50,000 or $60,000 a year job. You may be offered a part-time job, putting a toe in the water so that the employer can have a look at you and you can have a look at the employer.

The effective marginal tax rate over that range of $10,000 to $15,000 has been reduced under the legislation from 90 cents in the dollar to 87 cents in the dollar. That is due only to the reduction in the marginal rate of income tax for lower income earners from 20 cents in the dollar to 17 cents in the dollar. So nothing in this legislation involves a reduction in the taper rate for people on Newstart over that income range, which I think is a great pity, because we could really have made some progress for those people. They remain, therefore, very much caught in a poverty trap. The incentive to move from welfare to work, I would argue, is very low when you are sacrificing, effectively, 87 cents in the dollar for every extra dollar of income earned. So an opportunity has been missed.

It is quite clear that, on the part of this government, reducing effective marginal tax rates for welfare recipients is not a priority. As I said, this legislation fails to do that for people on unemployment benefits. The government has completely rejected the idea of tax credits. It has rejected, for example, the Keating-Lambert proposal which would have consolidated the payments even further and which would have meant that there was a single taper. That was covered in the Financial Review today. There is some merit in the Keating-Lambert proposal, but the government has said, `No, we're not interested in that.'

I think it does reveal its social agenda. That social agenda is one in which we get the sort of rhetoric and inferences that people on welfare are bludgers. I refer to the words of the employment minister, who regards them as `job snobs'. There is this denigration of people on welfare who face effective marginal tax rates of 87 cents in the dollar, and even higher rates in some cases. These people are supposed to be welfare bludgers, but for high income earners who face a marginal tax rate of 48½ cents in the dollar, the government considers that that is a punitive rate of tax and that it removes the incentive to work harder and improve oneself and one's family. But an effective marginal rate of 87 cents in the dollar is fine for low income earners because it allows the government to continue to label them as `job snobs' and `bludgers'.

The Treasurer has said, `We've got to get this top marginal rate of tax down.' I refer here to statements that he has made. He finds that this is a great disincentive to work and he has declared himself to be an `income tax cut man'. He said that in a statement after delivering an address at the forecasting conference of the Economics Society of Victoria on 19 August 1999. That was reported on page 1 of the Australian Financial Review on 20 August 1999. He said that he was an income tax cut man and that he wanted to get the top marginal rate pushed out to be `multiples of average weekly earnings'. He said that in an interview on Meet the Press on the Ten Network on 30 May last year. So we have got the Treasurer of this country saying, `Oh, that 48½ per cent rate is punitive; it robs people of incentive to work. But 87 cents in the dollar is fine for low income earners because we can continue to label them as welfare bludgers and job snobs.' Such are the priorities and such is the philosophy of this government.

The government have said that the tax package, of which this legislation forms part, is going to be magnificent for families. They have now fallen into their own trap of making wildly exaggerated claims about the benefits of this risky tax scheme. The Prime Minister has said on a number of occasions that the average family will receive $47 a week in their pockets. The Deputy Prime Minister went one further—I think there is a bit of an auction going on here—and said in the parliament on 5 February, talking about a single income couple with a baby in Collarenebri on $30,000 a year—a typical family in that little town—that they will have an extra $65 a week in the home to spend. And then, not to be outdone, the minister for workplace relations, Mr Reith, said on 2UE recently, `What about an assurance for someone on 30 grand a year who, under us, is going to have $71 a week more in their pocket. For that person on $30,000, $71 a week is a lot of money. That is $3,500 a year.'

So we have the Prime Minister saying $47, the Deputy Prime Minister saying $65 and, not to be outdone, the minister for workplace relations saying an average family is going to get $71 a week. Each and every one of them completely failed to mention the war, the three-letter word—GST. They all failed to mention the GST. What is the latest assertion? Is it that the GST will cost people nothing? I believe that this will condemn them once the GST actually comes in because I reckon that there will be very few Australian families who believe the government when it says, `You are $47 a week better off,' or `You are $65 a week better off,' or `You are $71 a week better off.' They will say, `Funny, it does not feel that way.' So the government is sowing the seeds of its own demise in making these wildly exaggerated claims about the impact of this risky tax scheme.

It is a fact that with the GST, every time you have a child you enter into a higher tax bracket because those children consume, and what is being introduced is a tax on consumption. It is a tax on virtually all of the things that babies consume—all of their clothes, all of the services that for the first time are going to be subject to tax. Overall, when you weigh one side against the other you realise that essentially what this legislation is about is an attempt, but not a very good attempt, to compensate families for the impact of the GST. Really, this is compensation. On its own there is merit in it, and we supported the original legislation last year because it did provide extra family payments, but it fails the test of adequately reducing the effective marginal tax rates for low income earners. It has to be seen in the context that it is really an attempt to compensate for the GST, and for lower and middle income families that compensation is not adequate.

I ask members of parliament to spare a thought for that other category of people, single people, who are the forgotten people in this tax package because they get very little. It is quite easy to demonstrate that single people on low and middle incomes are going to be clearly worse off under the risky tax scheme that the government is putting in place.

Another category of single people is age pensioners. Many age pensioners, obviously, live alone; they have lost their partners. We have had the government saying, `But age pensioners are going to receive this bonus of $1,000,' which in most cases is just untrue. They are going to receive dollar for dollar on any investment income that they have. In my electorate, and in the electorates of the members for Sydney and Melbourne Ports, there are thousands of pensioners who derive no income at all from investments. They have not got any investments because they could never afford to have them. They will not get this $1,000 bonus.

The government have been quite misleading before, during and after the election in assert-ing that as well as getting this $1,000 bonus—which many age pensioners will not get—the age pension is going to go up by four per cent. What they failed to mention, other than in the fine print, is that there will be an initial four per cent in the pension but half of that will be grabbed back on 31 March next year. Half of the four per cent will be clawed back—so there will be a two per cent rise, not a four per cent rise. And this is meant to compensate for all of the price impacts of the GST. Clearly, it will not be able to compensate adequately for that.

The consolidation of family payment does have merit, but the government has squandered an opportunity to improve the incentives to move from welfare to work. This is just another instalment in widening inequality in the information age. There is a new economic agenda that is only being pursued by one side of politics—and that is the Labor Party. It is part of being the knowledge nation to put extra resources into making sure that young people and older people, through lifelong learning and reskilling, have the skills to be able to compete for jobs successfully in the information age.

Over three years, $20 billion of government surplus is being taken from the new agenda and from giving skills to people from disadvantaged areas to pay for the old agenda. The old agenda is a GST. The Australian government said that because Europe has a GST we have to have one. This is the old economic agenda. Labor pursued an economic agenda of micro-economic reform through the 1980s and the 1990s, reducing tariff barriers, deregulating the financial system, floating the dollar and creating more competition in the economy. Most of those measures were supported—sometimes grudgingly—by members of the present government. But the government says there is unfinished business in the old economic agenda. We have to have a GST, which Labor has not supported and has never supported, and we have to have further changes in the industrial relations system to make sure that we can depress the wages of families who are already on low incomes. The government have taken $20,000 million from the new economic agenda, including from education and all those vital social services that would create a proper and decent fair society, and used it to pay for what they consider to be the unfinished business of the old economic agenda.

What we face now, as a result of the government's inaction on the new economic agenda, is a fractured and increasingly unequal society. A fractured society is an unsafe society. If high income earners cannot find the motivation from altruism to pay their fair share of tax and stop engaging in aggressive tax avoidance schemes—more of which we have seen revealed in the last few days—and cannot find in their hearts the altruism to say, `We have to pay our fair share of tax so that kids from disadvantaged areas can be lifted up and given a decent education and future,' they may have to look at the motivation of self-interest and understand that, as income inequality continues to widen and social exclusion becomes more commonplace, this fractured society is becoming an increasingly unsafe society. They are going to have to confront the reality that, if they are to look after themselves and their families, they are going to have to pay their fair share of tax.

The government talks about welfare bludgers and job snobs, but it never talks about tax bludgers. The country is full of high income earners who go to all these respectable functions. They present themselves as respectable people in society and yet they are engaged in aggressive tax schemes to minimise tax. If they paid their fair share of tax, they could contribute to the new economic agenda to a fair and more decent society.

talk.start.para: —I rise to speak on A New Tax System (Family Assistance and Related Measures) Bill 2000. I was struck by the inclusion of the term `family assistance' in the title of the bill. I sometimes wonder whether these bill titles are ironic. The other reminder of the irony of the titling of bills was `more jobs, better pay'. While much of this legislation is uncontroversial, there are aspects that will undoubtedly hurt families and, particularly, hurt children. With this bill coming in the week after the release of Jocelyn Newman's report on welfare reform, people might be forgiven for wondering whether this government's support for families is no more than rhetoric.
