speech.para: The aspect of the bill of greatest concern to me relates to the cut to the family tax benefit for the primary carer when the non-residential parent has more than 10 per cent care of a child. Under previous policy, family payments were shared once there was a minimum of 30 per cent care from the non-custodial parent. That is consistent with child support payments which currently recognise that a significant commitment of 30 per cent care is needed by the non-custodial parent before their child support liability is reduced.

This legislation proposes that the family tax benefit for the primary carer would reduce as soon as the non-residential parent has 10 per cent care. That is less than one day a week; it is only 36 days a year. It is likely to cause significant hardship for single parents who stand to lose up to $40 per fortnight for each child that is subject to these arrangements. Of course, anyone who has primary care of children realises that your expenses do not necessarily diminish that much if you do not have the children one day a week. You are still responsible for rent, clothing, putting food on the table and all of the ordinary expenses of child rearing.

This government is full of talk on how it supports families, yet it looks for any opportunity to take money away from the poorest families. The government has cut child-care assistance, axed retraining programs and severely restricted employment support schemes such as JET, aimed at getting parents back into work. The recent report so paraded by the Minister for Family and Community Services just continues this trend. Patrick McClure, Chief Executive of Mission Australia and the chairperson of the federal government's reference group on welfare reform, stated quite clearly:

quote.para: Without a fundamental change in the direction of the nation's social support system, far too many Australians are at risk of long-term poverty. This is one of the findings of the interim report.

speech.para: He is right in saying that the risk of poverty is much too high, but this report and this government have no solutions for that. This minister does not see it as her job to address unemployment and disadvantage, or intergenerational poverty. She sees it as her job to save a few dollars on the budget bottom line, to throw a few single mums off the pension and get those lazy disabled people back down the mines or up the chimneys. To do the job of welfare reform properly, the minister would have to get her government to commit to a program over many years, indeed decades, and to spend billions of dollars to actually get people from welfare to work. Such a program would have to address social and educational disadvantage, parenting skills and, most particularly, support for working families. Welfare reform is not just about saving nickels and dimes; it is about helping people to become independent when they can be and it is about giving security and peace of mind to those people who continue to rely on benefits. Providing support and assistance to sole parents and disability pensioners may be the emphasis of the report but, as Tony Eadley points out, `it is underpinned by the government's veiled threats of compulsion and sanctions'. It reminds me of some of the more punitive measures that were taken up by some of the North American states. In a book called No one left to lie to, Christopher Hitchens says:

quote.para: ... we are endlessly instructed, while rich people will not work unless they are given money, poor people will only work if they are not. (These are the two modern meanings of the term “incentive”: a tax break on the one hand and the threat of the workhouse on the other.) And, once the Democratic party had adopted this theology, the poor had no one to whom they could turn. The immediate consequence of this was probably an intended one: the creation of a large helot underclass disciplined by fear and scarcity, subject to endless surveillance, and used as a weapon against any American worker lucky enough to hold a steady or unionised job.

The evidence lies all around us, and will be around us for some time to come. Whether it is gleaned from the most evenhanded and “responsible” reporting, such as that of Jason DeParle atop the great rampart of the New York Times.

speech.para: He goes on to say:

quote.para: ... we shall have to accustom ourselves to stories like this. In Missouri, under the Direct Job Placement scheme (such schemes are always known officially as “initiatives”), the state bureaucracy mutates itself into a hiring hall for cheap labor in junk-nutrition conglomerates such as Tyson Foods. Welfare recipients are told to sign on and gut fifty chickens a minute, or be wiped from the rolls of the new Poor Law. They are directed to an industry which is well used to turnover among employees:

speech.para: Here is a story of a particular person affected by these laws. He writes:

quote.para: As one woman on welfare discovered [never mind her name] even having a newborn baby and no means of transportation is no excuse. When the thirty-year-old mother informed her case managers of these extenuating circumstances, they were not sympathetic. “They told her she had to work at Tyson's even if she had to walk to get there—a six-mile trek,” says Helen Chewning, a former family advocate with the Missouri Valley Human Resource Centre in Sedalia. “They sanctioned her while she was pregnant, and then ordered her to work at Tyson's when her baby was just eleven days old. She hasn't had any income for six months. How are they supposed to live?”

speech.para: That, of course, was all reporting from Christopher Cook, but Christopher Hitchens goes on to say:

quote.para: The process of “sanctioning”—the new state euphemism for coercion via the threat of cut-off—involves facing defenceless people with the rather old choice between “work or starve.” It is the tactic by which welfare rolls are being “trimmed”, if you will allow another Clintonian euphemism. You can be “sanctioned” if you refuse any job, or miss any interview.

I did not select Missouri because it's a famously unsentimental state. I selected it because President Clinton in an August 1997 address to businessmen in St Louis, touted it as the model laboratory for his welfare reform. It's useful only for dialectical purposes to mention that Tyson Foods uses the Direct Job Placement scheme as its taxpayer-funded recruiting sergeant. The first shock of recognition, experienced by those who are supposed to be grateful for a dose of nonalienated and dignified labor, is the “puller job.” This involves gutting birds—later to provide tasteless nourishment at the tables of the badly off—at a rapid rate. The fingernails of the inexperienced are likely to be the first to go; dissolved in bacteria and chicken fat. Of Missouri's 103,000 poultry workers, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics, almost one-third endured an injury or an illness in 1995 alone. That this may be an undercounting is suggested by the experience of one hard-pressed toiler on the Tyson chicken-thigh assembly line named Jason Wolfe: “They want you to hang forty or fifty of these birds in a minute, for four to six hours straight, without a break. If you miss any, they threaten to fire you.” He himself was fired because of too many “sick days.”

Supplied by the state with a fearful, docile labor force, the workhouse masters are relatively untroubled by unions, or by any back-talk from the staff. Those who have been thus “trimmed” from the welfare rolls have often done no more than disappear into a twilight zone of casual employment, uninsured illness, intermittent education for their children, and unsafe or temporary accommodation. Only thus—by their disappearance from society—can they be counted as a “success story” by ambitious governors, and used in order to qualify tightfisted states for “caseload-reduction credits” from the federal government. The women among them, not infrequently pressed for sexual favors as the price of the ticket, can be asked at random about the number of toothbrushes found in the trailer, and are required by law to name the overnight guest or the father of the child if asked. Failure or refusal to name the father can lead to termination of “benefits” or (an even better word) “entitlements.”

speech.para: Christopher Hitchens goes on to describe in quite a lot of detail what the effects of the American states' views of mutual obligation have been and, in fact, the deleterious effects that they have had, of course, on the welfare recipients but, perhaps even more importantly, on the children that rely on those parents.

Mike Steketee wrote in the Australian of this government's attitudes towards people receiving welfare benefits that show they have lost touch with the community when they believe that `... a strongly performing economy must have opportunities for everyone and those that remain unemployed are bludgers'. He is pointing out that for most people, the vast majority of people, unemployment is not a choice. It is not a lifestyle decision.

The government has tightened economic policy at the expense of programs to help the long-term unemployed. The government has clearly betrayed families, contrary to the Prime Minister's assertion that `families are the essential building block of a dynamic and decent society'. If the Prime Minister believes this, it is difficult to understand how 770,000 children now grow up in families where neither parent has a job. When the figures were last taken in 1999, that was an increase of 96,000 people since the election of the government. In a speech to the Australian Federation of Childcare Associations in 1997, Senator Newman promised `a high quality child-care system ... flexible, affordable and accessible'. Yet, child care under this government has gone up at least $20 a week for most families following cuts of $850 million from the child-care budget. It is obvious that these measures have been responsible for the drop in the participation rate of women in the economy and, certainly, for increased insecurity and cuts to the hours of numbers at work.

It is unfortunate that, on the one hand, the Minister for Family and Community Services is undermining every effort of families to return to the work force, particularly burning the bridges that are necessary for single parents to re-enter the work force, and then feels it necessary to punish those people who are suffering from these cuts to programs. Peter Edelman, a US worker in the area of welfare policy, points out that there are class issues involved here. Of a similar situation in the United States, he said:

quote.para: There is a submerged class question here. I always get at it in my speeches by pointing out the hypocrisy in the rhetoric as to who should stay home with their children. Many on the right (and elsewhere) are saying mothers should stay at home with their small children because the new research data on brain development shows that small children need that stimulation. These same people then turn around and say poor moms have to go out and work immediately. (Many states have work requirements beginning when an infant is twelve weeks old, and the vast majority of the remainder require work when a child is a year old. That is a pretty class distinction..

speech.para: It is interesting as well that this minister who seems to believe that caring for children is not valuable work on its own and who ignores the fact that there are currently 28,000 disabled people on waiting lists for training—these same people that she is saying need to undertake some work tests—manages to claim two pensions herself. On top of her salary as a cabinet minister, the minister is entitled to a parliamentary widow's annuity and a defence force spouse benefit. Of course there is no reciprocity demanded of her—and nor should there be. She is entitled to these benefits and she claims them. Yet at the same time as she is claiming these benefits she is looking for ways to trim the social security lists. Surely is it obvious that there is some irony here, where people who do not need benefits are allowed to stick their hand out and claim them and those people who are just getting by, who are just managing, are being told to get out there and get off the social security lists.

The agenda of the government is based on their view that the disadvantaged, the sick, the disabled, those raising children, the unemployed, the carers and those struggling to survive owe a debt to society rather than that they are Australians who need a hand in unfortunate times. Gerard McEwen of Glandore in South Australia put it very clearly in his letter to the Australian in March this year. He stated that the current government's definition of mutual obligation is:

quote.para: ... in return for less money than it takes to live, the recipient agrees to be grateful for being humiliated and bullied.

speech.para: Adele Horan, of the Sydney Morning Herald, has suggested a number of times over the last year that one way in which the necessary costs of welfare reform could be found would be—and the member for Rankin spoke of it earlier—if the government were willing to crack down on tax dodgers, the big end of town cheats. She said:

quote.para: Where might the money come from to provide the extra Centrelink staff, the social workers and the psychiatrists, the job training and the childcare that the committee sees as prerequisites for many sole parents and disability pensioners to make the transition to work? Who will pay the very necessary increased rate of benefit implied in the report?

speech.para: I think the sad answer is that no-one is going to pay it. This government does not have a commitment to making the investment that is required to get people from welfare to work. To blame those most disadvantaged in society, to penalise them, is wrong. To set up a situation where people are punished for not complying with mandatory work is wrong. To fail to acknowledge that work undertaken by a single mum in caring for her baby is wrong. This difference between the Howard government's rhetoric on welfare and the reality of its policy in action is wrong.

Labor's vision for welfare reform and an adequate welfare system involves acknowledging the work that parents do—the importance of caring for children and for caring for people with disability. We believe that it is necessary to protect people from poverty and destitution. That seems a very obvious thing to say but, given the experience in many states in the United States where these most punitive measures have been introduced, it is not something that modern civilised societies can any longer take for granted. Those social payments that were instituted, very often 60 years ago, during the 1930s, can no longer be taken for granted. There is no assumption that children born into poverty will actually receive a helping hand. There is, in fact, every indication that the trend is being reversed.

Labor believes also that we need to give people choices about how they manage their family and work responsibility in early years of child rearing and about the types of activities they undertake to get back into work. There is no point in asking people to weed along railway tracks if that is never going to lead to a real job, if it is going to be a cycle of punishment and humiliation that does not deal at all with the underlying problems that have led to the unemployment in the first place. What we need to do in welfare reform is to help people to move forward and to become independent, rather than just to threaten, bully and harass them, and pull the rug out from under them.

talk.start.para: —I rise to speak briefly on the A New Tax System (Family Assistance and Related Measures) Bill 2000. In some respects this bill sums up the whole folly of the government's tax reform proposal. It is some 300 pages long and it has an explanatory memorandum of some 203 pages, so we have over 500 pages of detail. Its development lacked consultation with the opposition subsequent to its introduction, and it amends eight other acts. In some ways it demonstrates, in this drive for simplification around tax reform, actually more complication and more confusion.

speech.para: When we look at the issue of family assistance in the context of the new tax system we have to look also at the question of whether that assistance is in fact fair, reasonable and just, particularly in relation to compensation on the basis of the changes that have been made with respect to the GST. What we see is a number of flawed assumptions that have come in as the basis for how compensation has been worked out, a number of flawed assumptions around the question of what has occurred. We now know that the figure for inflation that was estimated in the first place is not correct—that the impact on inflation and therefore on prices has been underestimated. Beyond that, having seen the development and the consideration of this system in respect of a range of different areas, we know that the price implications for a range of goods and services have been underestimated. That is going to have an impact on Australian families and on the assistance that they require in order to meet their daily bills.

In particular I would like to focus, very briefly, on the health area in relation to that, be-cause it has implications for many Australian families. All of us are users of health care prod-ucts, and, in the circumstances, that area is something that the government has got terribly wrong. The government said continually that health would be GST free, and only recently has it actually started putting a few riders on which products are covered and which are not. When we look at that area we see some very interesting implications.

Let us look at the circumstances of people who need family assistance and people on bene-fits. Often they will be in a situation where they are on pensions such as disability pensions and often they will be sufferers of various types of chronic illnesses. Those who are suffering from chronic illnesses often require health care which involves a range of different products. Some of those will be prescription products, which therefore are GST free, but often they will be products that are not GST free: although they are clearly of medical benefit, they have not made the poisons schedule as, effectively, products that require supervision by medical prac-titioners with respect to how they are used and so they will be subject to GST.

When you look at the question of people with chronic illnesses, you often find that we are talking about significant amounts of expenditure being required. People with some skin dis-eases sometimes require a range of different products, including things like specific shampoos to deal with skin conditions, and ointments and creams for those conditions. Many of those products will not be GST free. The estimate from within industry about the price rises ex-pected in these areas is of up to eight or nine per cent on occasions, depending on the product, so it is almost the entire 10 per cent. And the assistance and compensation packages outlined do not take into account the level of requirement for people in those particular sets of circum-stances. I have seen letters from members of the community saying that the bills they could be facing over a monthly period could be as high as $150 to $200. The circumstances are that they are going to rise seven to eight per cent.

This goes right through to herbal remedies and a range of other products that are used in preventative health care. This government has really only focused on four issues in the pre-ventative area: sunscreen, condoms, personal lubricants and folate. Although I support those four exemptions, there is a range of other products that should be considered, like calcium for people with osteoporosis. So we see with this bill that a range of amendments are required. It is a huge bill and it requires huge adjustment because this system is just not right. It was not right when it was brought in, it has not been right since then in terms of the adjustments that have been made, and I am sure we are going to be seeing many more amendments to this bill right up until 1 July and, also, post the event.

talk.start.para: —in reply—First of all, I thank all the members for their contributions to this debate on the A New Tax System (Family Assistance and Related Measures) Bill 2000. Admittedly, many from the other side were misguided. But I would particularly like to thank the members for McPherson, Hughes and Mitchell.

speech.para: This bill is part of the government's vision for a new tax system. As part of the govern-ment's plan for a new tax system, the structure and administration of family assistance is be-ing recast and simplified with effect from 1 July 2000. This bill complements last year's tax reform legislation and, in particular, the family assistance package provided primarily by A New Tax System (Family Assistance) Act 1999 and A New Tax System (Family Assistance) (Administration) Act 1999. These acts have already made huge contributions to reducing 12 forms of assistance currently available through the tax and social security system to three new family assistance payments: family tax benefit part A, family tax benefit part B and child-care benefit. The bill refines the existing legislation package to clarify the operations of various aspects of family assistance law, to replace regulation making powers with substantive provi-sions, to insert relevant savings and transitional provisions and to make miscellaneous techni-cal amendments. It also makes consequential amendments to other relevant legislation.

I would like to talk in some detail about some of the provisions contained in the bill. Under the current family assistance arrangements, many matters are dealt with by way of regulation making powers. The bill replaces existing regulation making powers with substantive provisions in the primary legislation. This replacement provision includes claiming, determining and payment of the child-care benefit—CCB—obligations of claimants and approved care services and payments of advances to services. The bill refines and clarifies the operations of the family assistance law and makes some technical and consequential changes to the family assistance law and other Commonwealth acts. The bill contains necessary transition and savings provisions.

The bill provides for special benefit recipients who would otherwise not be eligible for family tax benefit or child-care benefit because of the residence rules to access these payments. This means holders of temporary visas who satisfy the residence requirements for special benefit will also be able to access the family tax benefit, FTB, and the CCB. This change mainly affects the holders of spouse temporary visas who retain the care of the children after a partner's death or desertion or separation due to domestic violence. Under the current rules these people can access special benefit but not family allowance or FTB from 1 July 2000. I cannot understand why the opposition would oppose that. This also ensures that refugees holding a temporary protection visa who receive family allowance will continue to receive FTB.

There are provisions in the bill which ensure that any unrepaid family tax benefit advance is a debt under the family assistance law. This is in cases where the advance recipient ceases to be entitled to family tax benefit part A before the advance is repaid or the recipient's part A rate drops to a level which is insufficient to recover the advance in the advance period. The debt provisions will also be amended to prevent entitlement to an FTB advance arising where a person has an existing debt. These changes are consistent with the treatment of unrepaid advances of income support payments under the social security law.

The bill provides for amendments to overcome a technical anomaly relating to the payment of rent assistance. Amendments will be made to ensure that a person who only has the shared care of a child or children is assessed for rent assistance at both the `with child' and `without child' rates and paid at the higher rate. Amendments of the CCB rate for formal care ensure that the CCB hourly rate for the fourth and subsequent child in a family will be the same as for a family with three children in care, including indexation.

The bill provides for amendments to child-care benefit to taper out the 10 per cent part-time loading in long day care centres so that families using less than 34 hours of care continue to get the 10 per cent loading. However, families using 34 to 37 hours get a lesser loading so that they do not get less CCB in total than those using 33 hours. Changes are also made to the child-care benefit so that the minimum rate for informal care for school children will be reduced to below the corresponding rate for younger children. The bill will allow the child-care benefit eligibility provisions to align the child-care benefit immunisation requirement with the current child-care assistance and child-care rebate immunisation requirements. The amendments exempt children born before 1 January 1996 from the immunisation requirement.

The bill also contains provisions allowing an approved child-care centre to have the discretion to decide the CCB rate applicable to an individual experiencing hardship. Amendments provide that a service can lose this discretion if it has demonstrated a pattern of inappropriate use of the discretion. Other amendments in this bill increase the rates of the CDEP participation supplement, pensioner education supplement and carer allowance by four per cent. This increase will compensate recipients for the effect of the goods and services tax. The bill also makes minor technical changes to the A New Taxation System (Bonus for Older Australians) Act 1999 to take account of the subsequent enactment of the Social Security (Administration) Act 1999.

I take this opportunity to address some of the comments made by opposition members, particularly the honourable member for Lilley. As usual, the member for Lilley embarked on his standard diatribe. He spoke of his `insecurity index'—an insecurity index which makes no sense. Madam Deputy Speaker, this government is certainly about helping families, as you well know. It is not about scaring families. This is certainly in contrast with the member for Lilley's so-called family insecurity index. Like the member for Lilley, the index is based more on scare than on substance.

When you take a closer look at this farcical index, to start with, the figures used are from the time of the last Labor government. The last time he was in this place, of course, was back in 1995. Of the 61 numbers used in constructing his index, 29 are wrong. It is hardly surprising that, with 29 incorrect numbers, it is hard to take this index seriously. With 29 incorrect numbers, you cannot provide a measure of anything, let alone changes to family insecurity. Some of the index's components are irrelevant, while other important elements are missing. The index has been weighted incorrectly. Some statistics used have been measured incorrectly. Finally, the index is being used in a selective and misleading way. Rather than providing security to Australian families, many members of the opposition are more concerned about scaring people and scaring families.

The member for Lilley has accused the government of pushing this legislation through at the last minute. The opposition believes that there has not been enough time to analyse the bill. Nothing could be further from the truth. The government introduced the bill into the House four weeks ago. The member for Lilley has been given ample briefings from my department on issues relating to the bill. I am certainly quite happy for the member for Lilley to receive further briefings—perhaps it will enlighten him. It is a bit rich for the opposition to feel that it has not been given adequate time to look at the bill.

I would like to explain in detail some of the aspects of the bill that obviously have been lost on many members of the opposition, and particularly the member for Lilley. For a start, he claims the family tax benefit B reduces a single family's tax-free threshold by almost $5,000 when a child turns five. However, additional assistance is provided to single income families with a child or children under five to enable these families to choose a balance of child care and work responsibilities appropriate to them when their children are very young. The additional assistance ceases to be paid once the child is five years old on the basis that this is the age when children generally commence school and many parents have a greater opportunity to take up part-time or full-time employment. I do not think that is unreasonable.

The member for Lilley is also concerned by the estimate rules contained in the bill. I would like to clarify some of these things for the benefit of the opposition. This was passed in the original act almost a year ago. Where family tax benefit has been paid based on an estimate of family income, the family's actual entitlement will be reconciled at the end of the financial year when their actual taxable income is known. A top up payment will be provided if the customer has received less than their entitlement, and a repayment will be sought if the customer has received more than they are entitled to.

The reconciliation process will ensure that the customer receives their full entitlement for the financial year. Reconciliation addresses one of the major complaints about the current family tax system which recoups overpayments but does not top up underpayments. Customers will be able to opt to overestimate their income so as not to incur an overpayment because they know they will receive a top up at the end of the financial year. Reconciliation will also mean that families claiming through the tax system will generally receive the same level of assistance as those who receive fortnightly payments.

There will be no need for a margin of error when estimating income, as exists under the current family allowance system, as the reconciliation process addresses both underpayments and overpayments. Income support recipients will receive the maximum rate of family tax benefit A, which will be quarantined from the reconciliation process.

The member for Lilley and the opposition have also raised concerns about the shared care arrangements contained in the bill. The 10 forms of assistance that will make up family tax benefit parts A and B currently have their own separate and different shared payment ar-rangements. The current arrangements vary from little or no restriction on the shared pay-ment—for example, family allowance, dependent spouse rebate with child, and sole parent rebate—to no sharing at all for some payments such as guardian allowance and the basic par-enting payment.

The 30 per cent threshold applies only to the family tax initiative. The government consid-ers that 10 per cent is a reasonable test for material care, recognising parents with this level of care will incur significant costs in caring for children. Parents with this level of care or higher incur relatively significant costs due to the need to provide a bedroom, furnishings, food, clothes, health care and entertainment. This measure forms part of the response to the 1996 family law reforms which were introduced with the intention of promoting the parenting role of both parents and their continuing role in the lives of their children following separation.

The member for Lilley claims that the tax reform will not benefit low income families. The opposition appears to overlook the generous compensation provided to low income families as part of the new tax system. Generous ongoing compensation will be provided to compen-sate income support recipients for the impact of the GST. This consists of a four per cent up-front increase in payments. This will apply to all payments, except the maximum rate of rent assistance, which will increase by seven per cent. For all pensions, a four per cent increase will be paid as a supplement in addition to the basic pension that will continue to be indexed to male total average weekly earnings or inflation, whichever is the greater. As part of a com-pensation package, there will also be a 2.5 per cent increase in the incomes and assets test. Free areas apply to all income support payments and there will be a reduction in the taper of the income test for pensioner payments from 50 per cent to 40 per cent.

As I have already said, this bill forms part of the government's vision for a new tax system. It builds on last year's tax reform legislation and complements and consolidates the family assistance package this government has delivered. The 12 forms of assistance currently avail-able through the tax and social security system are reduced to three new family assistance payments: family tax benefit part A, family tax benefit part B and the new child care benefit.

This bill gives effect to the family assistance package provided by the new tax system. Many of the provisions debated in the House over the last two days have already been incor-porated in the new taxation system bill last year. This includes the share care measures and the 10 per cent estimated provisions, so I am a bit surprised that there is this sudden revelation of indignation by the opposition. This is a great achievement and will benefit all Australian families immensely. I commend the bill to the House.
Motion (by Mr Anthony) agreed to:

motion.para: That further proceedings on the bill be conducted in the House.

subdebateinfo.title: Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade Committee

subdebate.2.para: Debate resumed from 6 March, on motion by Mr Hollis:

motion.para: That the House take note of the report.

talk.start.para: —I am particularly pleased to be talking today on the report of the visit to East Timor on 2 December 1999 of the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, not only as a member of the delegation but also as the deputy chair of the committee. It was particularly appropriate that a delegation from this committee go to Timor, as we did in early December of last year, not only because of the work we do on that committee but also because each of the subcommittees that we have was very involved in what is happening in Timor. There is the foreign affairs subcommittee itself; there is the human rights subcommittee—and it is very important for us to get a first-hand view of what happened in the human rights area in Timor; and there is the trade subcommittee. I see the chair of the trade subcommittee is here. Unfortunately, he was in New York when we visited East Timor, but we had a briefing in Darwin before we went to Timor and briefings when we came back from Timor about the trade potential there for Australia in Timor. There is also, of course, the most recently formed subcommittee which is looking at Australia's relationship with the UN itself.

speech.para: It was important for the committee to have a look at the way the UN responded to the crisis in Timor, and especially important to know the lessons that can be learnt from that. I thought it important that most of the members of the delegation were either a chair or a deputy chair of the various subcommittees. We also had Senator Maurice Payne and Senator Vicki Bourne, who had been there during the so-called consultation period. They could give a perspective on what they had seen when they were there a couple of months before compared to what Timor was like when they returned on that December visit.

Few Australians today would not be aware of East Timor, but for many years from 1975 East Timor was said by some to be an embarrassment or an irritant to successive Australian governments. Governments did not want to know too much about our nearest neighbour. That was except for a small group of Australians who kept East Timor on the agenda. Within this parliament there has been a parliamentary East Timor support group which has been quite active. The numbers were very small; when East Timor became fashionable, they suddenly grew.

Xanana Gusmao visited this parliament before going back to East Timor. Many members of the parliament did not even know who he was before that, but within that fortnight I was amazed when I went into a room and I saw about 50 or 60 members of parliament there all shaking his hand and having their photographs taken. I remember that for years when the East Timor support group used to meet, you would be lucky to get four or five members there—people like Laurie Ferguson and Peter Andren, after he came in here, and a few others. So it did seem that—

talk.start.para: —And Colin Hollis.

—I was too modest to say that, but it did seem that East Timor suddenly became very much the flavour of the month. I do not know whether it was because of the tragedy, but let us hope that an interest remains in East Timor because it most certainly will need it.

speech.para: There has been much discussion about the timetable leading to the vote and what has happened in East Timor and there have been arguments about how much Australia knew or did not know. I do not want to enter into that debate in any great length, except to say that I believe that our foreign affairs department knew a lot more than has been made public. I say that because, if for no other reason, I believe our intelligence and our knowledge on Indonesia, for all sorts of reasons, is the best of any country. Of all the countries in the world, the department and various officials in Australia would have had a fairly good idea of the possibility of the wanton destruction that happened afterwards. Whether we responded appropriately or not I leave for others to debate, but I think that we had a fairly good knowledge of the possibility of what could happen there.

Having said that, there are some people who were involved in East Timor in that difficult period that I do not think adequate recognition has been given to. I pay tremendous tribute to our Australian forces there and all the forces there. It seems to me a great pity that we have not given that same recognition and tribute to members of the Australian Federal Police who went there and were there at a period when they had very little back-up support. Some of those people have been severely traumatised by what happened in East Timor. I think it is a great pity that there has not been adequate recognition of their work. Indeed, some of them were not paid for some time after they came back. One Australian Federal Police officer who served in Timor said to me and to other members of this parliament, `If you—' that is the parliament `—are going to send us to hell and back, don't have us grovel for our entitlements when we return to Australia.' That is true. They had to grovel for their entitlements. So I just want to put on the record my appreciation of what the Australian Federal Police did there un-der terribly difficult circumstances.

Everyone was shocked at the mindless, senseless violence that we saw in Timor. We saw it on our television night after night. I, like many other people, felt absolutely frustrated about our inability to be able to do anything. So I think it was very satisfying when in early Septem-ber the INTERFET forces eventually went in there. On 15 September 1999, the Security Council voted unanimously to authorise the establishment of a multinational force under chapter 7. I think it was very important that it was under chapter 7—and I would say that only under Chapter 7 could it have been successful—that the Charter of the United Nations, to be led by Australia, authorised the states participating in the multinational force `to take all nec-essary measures to fulfil its mandate'. That last point—`to take all necessary measures to ful-fil its mandate'—is very important. The force was to be known as INTERFET. This force was asked to restore peace and security in East Timor, protect and support UNAMET in carrying out its task and, within force capabilities, to facilitate humanitarian assistance in operations. The first elements of INTERFET arrived in East Timor on 20 September and, at the time of the visit by the joint standing committee, the force comprised some 9,000 personnel from 20 nations.

There have been some comments on the force. Some Indonesians and others have criticised the INTERFET forces and said there was an unnecessary show of force. What did they ex-pect? They were not going to village picnic parties. They have seen death and destruction wrought there. Bear in mind, when we are talking about these forces, in the main we are talk-ing about young people—20-year-olds, 21-year-olds and 19-year-olds. Most of them had not been in a combat situation before. Despite all their training, unless they had actually been in a combat situation, they and their officers would not know what to expect. They did not know when they went out on the streets of Dili in the evening when they arrived how they were go-ing to be met or what to expect. It was very important, I believe, that that show of strength be made. You have got the militants there terrorising people with all sorts of equipment. You are not at a party; you are in a life and death situation. I think that any criticism that has been di-rected has been unnecessary criticism. The proof has been in the result of what was achieved. They achieved the mandate that the United Nations gave them to achieve and without loss of life. I think it has been a magnificent effort and I think that the criticism that has been di-rected, such as it is, has been totally unwarranted.

There are all sorts of questions of course coming out of the Timor exercise. One that I know my colleague the member for Chifley will probably elaborate on is this ongoing debate about whether we train our forces for peacekeeping or for combat duties. One subcommittee I unfortunately did not mention when I was listing our subcommittees is the defence subcom-mittee. In one of the inquiries we are holding at the moment on the suitability of the Austra-lian forces we are grappling with this problem. You may have seen some comment in the me-dia recently regarding New Zealand who have made a comment that they are going to train their forces for a peacekeeping role. This happened with the Canadian forces with, some say—I do not say—disastrous results over the last couple of years when the Canadians put a particular emphasis on peacekeeping.

My own view is, and I think it has been shown to be true in Timor and other places, that if you train your forces for combat duties they can adapt to the peacekeeping role. That is what I feel in the main. Except for one officer who briefed us who argued very strongly that there should be training for the peacekeeping role, most of the other people I have spoken to, espe-cially in Timor, have said that Timor showed that training for combat duties was the right de-cision to take.

We are going to be engaged in Timor for many years. We have got a role there and other countries have got a role there. I actually have a personal resentment of the Portuguese over the whole Timor thing. It annoys me considerably when they pontificate and take the high moral ground. Always bear in mind that Portugal was a colonial power in Timor for over 400 years and, apart from teaching a bit of the Portuguese language, did absolutely nothing. The Indonesians, for maybe all the wrong reasons, did a hell of a lot more in Timor than the Por-tuguese ever did. This is one of the surprises that the Indonesians had in Timor. Because they had put so much infrastructure there compared with the other provinces of Indonesia, they were surprised that the Timorese were not more grateful for them. The Portuguese, when they were there, did very little but they are now taking the high moral ground.

I think nothing prepares you for actually going to Timor and seeing the destruction there—even if you have seen photographs of it. During our visit there we travelled to Suai, which is on the border. It was interesting to note that when the Australian forces arrived there—I do not know how many people were in that town, perhaps 7,000 or 8,000—there was not one person in that town. When we went there, all we saw was a blackened spot on the ground where a wooden hut or a grass hut had been and no corrugated iron left where a concrete house or something like that had been—that had all been taken away. We were flying by heli-copter, and this came across very visibly to us. Interestingly, when we were returning from Suai to Dili we were caught up in quite an interesting storm and had to divert. That enabled us to fly over a couple of other towns where, again, we could see the wanton destruction throughout that area.

There will be some challenges facing us in Timor. One of the great challenges now is not only the rebuilding but also employment. The young people, especially, have no work, and until we can get them doing something instead of standing around, resentment is going to build up as they see the lifestyles of some of the aid agencies in the floating hotels. So it is important that we do what we can to ensure there is work there. There has been some criticism that the UN and other aid agencies are moving too slowly, but you have to realise the level of destruction and the huge task ahead. I was criticised recently because I said that there had been some duplication within the aid agencies. I still think there is an amount of duplication, but I do acknowledge that ACFOA is doing a good job in coordinating those aid agencies. When you have over 70 aid agencies there— say, 50 from Australia and also a number from other countries—there is going to be a certain amount of duplication. But it is an important point, because there is a lot of work to do in infrastructure, schools and health—in a whole range of things.

The one thing we must never overlook is the psychological impact on the people there. We have to take account of that. It is very important, too, that the rebuilding is done by Timorese. We have to have consult with them. It is their country, and we have to be aware of that. I was very worried when we had the `Thongs for Timor' campaign and everyone sent in their thongs and then the `Teddy Bears for Timor' campaign at Christmas. I did not criticise at the time, because I thought that was not appropriate, but it was during the rainy season and all these teddy bears—the Timorese do not celebrate Christmas as we do; Bishop Belo said that—did not fit in. I had visions of all these houses in the wet season without roofs and all these sodden teddy bears, and I thought their only advantage would be as pillows. People gave their thongs and their teddy bears with the best of intentions, but how Australian—thongs and teddy bears. What the aid agencies needed was some cash to start rebuilding and to buy things. I hope that we have learnt a few lessons from that and that we take advice from the Timorese on the rebuilding.

Everyone wants the relationship with Indonesia restored, but we do not want it restored at any cost. There are problems with foreign affairs and the military, but Australian troops did not burn the villages or kill the Timorese or drive the refugees across the border, and they are not terrorising the refugees in the camps and stopping them returning from West Timor.

The other point I want to make is that those responsible for the terrible violence, the violations of human rights, must be brought to account. If the UN as a world body, and world opinion, mean anything, it is no good the current government of Indonesia or anyone else saying, `Look, this all happened in the past. Let's move on to the next chapter. Let's forget this as being in the past.' We will not forget it as being in the past. And the reason why we will not is that we must never let this happen again. Such things will happen again; it is inevitable—the violations of human rights in so many parts of the world are a tragedy. But we must make sure that this does not happen again. Our relationship with Indonesia is important, perhaps the most important relationship that we have with any foreign power. We will re-establish that relationship, but I hope on a more realistic line.

Finally, I would like to place on record my thanks to both the foreign minister and the Minister for Defence for making the trip, and especially the plane for it, available. I would like to pay a special tribute to the leader of the delegation, Senator Alan Ferguson, who led the delegation with great distinction. We were there for only a day, but all members of the delegation worked well together and since we have come back it has had an impact on us all. I pay tribute to our adviser, Lieutenant Colonel M. J. Ward, and most of all to our hardworking secretary, Margaret Swieringa, who accompanied the delegation and did so much to make the trip the outstanding success which I believe it has been. Thank you very much.

talk.start.para: —Perhaps I could take up where the honourable member for Throsby left off and sincerely congratulate the leader of the delegation to East Timor, Senator Ferguson, and the deputy leader of the delegation, the member for Throsby. I reiterate our thanks to Colonel Michael Ward and to Margaret Swieringa, the secretary, who accompanied us. I think I can say for all of us who went to East Timor that it was a privilege. I would like to read into the record one bit of the report:

quote.para: The members of the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade are grateful to the members of the Australian Defence Force who have deployed to East Timor in support of INTERFET. We acknowledge the sacrifice that this entails for each of you, particularly those who will remain in East Timor over the Christmas period. You should be conscious that the thoughts and good wishes of the Australian people go out not only to you but also to your families and loved ones.
We can be, and are, justifiably proud of our Defence Force and the people who comprise it. We wish you all continued success in your mission and a safe return.

speech.para: In a way, that sums up the report, A visit to East Timor, 2 December 1999. I can say, Mr Deputy Speaker, that as in Bougainville—to which you and I went—and in Rwanda and Somalia, to see our peacekeepers in operation makes us intensely proud to be Australians, not only because of the efficiency with which they do their job but because of the real esteem in which they are held by people who are the victims of massive human rights abuses.

I would like to comment on the debate that the honourable member for Throsby talked about as to whether training should be for peacekeeping or for war. The lieutenant colonel who was attached to the committee, Simon Gould, made the very good point that there is no doubt that you need to have your fighting force trained for combat, for killing—that is what you have defence forces for; it is a most unpleasant business—but, when you are aware that there is a likely deployment, some valuable time can be spent in thinking about what the likely humanitarian or chapter 7 task is going to be and what you are likely to do, to start pre-paring for that. The Australian defence forces have yet to learn that lesson and it is something that we can pick up in our current report.

This deployment, unlike any other, included not only full-time soldiers or ADF personnel but also some 600 reservists, and they not only served in East Timor but also filled holes back in Australia. We owe them a special thanks, particularly when you recollect the figures quoted by my colleague the shadow minister Mr Ferguson that some 20 per cent of reservists who served in the Gulf War—I think there were about 100,000—lost their jobs on return to United States. I ask the minister to keep a tally so that we have some understanding of the circum-stances of people, reservists in particular, returning to Australia.

I have a lot of concerns about our defence situation and the lessons that may need to be learned out of East Timor. I particularly regret that neither the Minister for Foreign Affairs nor the Minister for Defence is really putting on the table what their experiences are, what their views are and what direction they will take. The honourable member for Throsby made a point that I think is a deeply disturbing one, and that is: was there, as the government has in-sinuated, an intelligence failure in the likely outcome of the poll? If there was a failure, the important point is that we need to understand what that failure entailed and how it may be addressed. I still think there is some benefit in a public discussion of this and in the ministers putting the matter on the public record. But clearly, from the Four Corners program and the leaked documents, there was no intelligence failure. Where does that leave us? Given Austra-lia knew very well the likely implications of the post-ballot period, what action did we take?

It is true to say that it is without precedent that we did not have a secretary of Defence at the time. We had a secretary, Paul Barratt, who had got a good report card from Max Moore-Wilton and continued on in his post, and suddenly there was this confrontation with the min-ister. Putting that to one side, the result was that we did not have a secretary of the depart-ment. You have to understand the lengths the ADF went to, on both the military and civilian sides, to build relationships in our region. But the situation meant that that secretary could not pick up the phone and talk to his Indonesian counterpart. The other issue of concern is that I think it was also unprecedented that the calls that Minister Moore made to his counterpart, General Wiranto, were not answered. I cannot recall a precedent for this. It is most alarming.

I asked what we could do with the intelligence that we had. Could we have tried to play the connections that we had made within Indonesia? Clearly that was failing; that was not possi-ble. But it would be interesting to know the extent to which we tried. The other thing we could have tried was to call in the one power that was going to have an effect, and ultimately did have an effect, and that was America. We are not in a position to know—and we should be in a position to know—whether or not attempts were made in that direction and what the response was, for whatever reason.

That is the situation. I want to say—and I want to be generous about this point—that I thought the government did a very proper thing in getting an extra brigade up for extra readi-ness. Some might say, `Well, blind Freddy could have done that.' But they did it, and it is im-portant that they did it. It would have been absolutely horrific had that not been done. So I credit the government with that.

I want to make this point: had our INTERFET forces been required to stay there for a longer period—some 18 months—we would have been awfully stretched. Also, I do not believe we could have handled a second emergency. From the parliament's point of view, it is wrong to have a member of parliament speculating about these matters. Where is the ministerial statement by the Minister for Defence that discusses these issues of our rotation and our ability to sustain another operation involving quite a number of personnel, albeit not on as large a scale? There is none. Questions were asked in the parliament on several occasions about how the troops were going to be rotated. Of course, the minister was most dismissive of the issue. `Don't you worry about that sort of thing'—apparently a Queensland mentality. Of course, the cat was out of the bag when one of the military officers briefed the press on rotational issues. It is disappointing that the minister could not have taken the parliament into his confidence.

There is not only an issue of rotation; the issue is the extent to which we have had to scramble for equipment to get these extra units in readiness as a rotational force. What has that meant in terms of our other battalions? What is the manning level of those battalions? What is the equipment level? We do not have a picture of the actual numbers of people in battalions, their equipment level and what we need to remedy it. Here we are, in the largest deployment since Vietnam, having a debate in which we are speculating about these issues. This should not be a matter of speculation; it should be a matter of the Minister for Defence taking the people of Australia into his confidence and saying, `These are the things that I confront. These are the things that we need to see opened.'

We have had two cabinet submissions lodged on the reserves. I do not know how long it has been going on, but we know it has been going on for months and months. There has been an announcement that we are going to be able to mobilise the reserve for peacekeeping. I absolutely support that. But the really difficult cabinet submission deals with the structure of the reserves and what is going to be done. Again, there is a real hiatus on the part of this government while we await the outcome of the strategic white paper. Are we saying that the government, which has commissioned the paper, which has a cabinet subcommittee dealing with the issues that will be in the white paper, has such a lack of knowledge about what the outcome will be that it cannot make critical decisions, that it cannot make a decision on the reserves? I think those decisions need to be made.

I absolutely question the ADF's proposition that the only way we should use the reserves is to fill gaps in the full-time Army. I think it is an absolute waste of our reserve potential. We have 23,000 reserves, an establishment of 30,000, and they are a phantom army. We cannot use them in the way we are supposed to use them. I do not blame this on the government but I say that we need to address this issue. We have to work out where we are going to go. I am saying that this minister and the government should be taking the people of Australia into their confidence. Do they think that we need another Ready Reserve type scheme? Or are they quite satisfied with the current situation of the reserves? I am not; the reservists are not. The Army is not. They believe radical changes need to be made.

Why can't we discuss these issues? Why is it that I am raising these issues in the House and the Minister for Defence is not putting out a statement about the current situation and the parameters for reform, so that we can have a decent debate? Mr Deputy Speaker, as you would know, the joint committee has had a tradition of bipartisanship. We think these issues of national security are so important that, irrespective of our parties, we should work together in the national interest. But you cannot work together in a vacuum. So I am really disappointed.

We have also got in the department this curious phenomenon of almost communist like self-criticism, as if they have been sent to special camps and need to confess their past sins. Any department needs to change and improve. I know this department is highly capable and professional, but still it would be the first to argue it should be improved, even significantly improved.

We know that there is going to be a purge of staff. We know the Chief of Army is going; we know the CDF is going; we know the Secretary has already gone; and we know most of the deputy secretaries are on the way out. Is this the way to run such an important department, by purging the staff of the department? I have never seen a situation comparable to this. Talk to people and find out what their morale is. Here we are at a critical point in our nation's history where we need to make some real changes, and morale is at absolute zero. Despite this, we have a minister who will not make a statement, who will not take us into his confidence, and who cannot show us his light at the end of the tunnel.

We are actually demonising the submarines to such an extent that the other weekend the Prime Minister had to say, `I think these subs are going to be a pretty terrific purchase.' That was the extent of the demonising of the acquisition process. More than most, I know what needs to be done to improve the acquisition and logistics process, and I support some changes there. But to get changes you do not have to demonise a department or demonise individuals. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Mr Deputy Speaker, in making some comments on the report, A visit to East Timor, 2 December 1999, I feel somewhat inadequate after hearing both you and the member for Chifley. Both of you have been on so many of these critical defence visits. You have been to places like Somalia, Rwanda and East Timor. Nonetheless, as a new member I would like to make some comments that I believe take up some of the issues that both you and the member for Chifley have raised.

speech.para: Firstly, I would like to note that in my electorate one of the local government organisations, the City of Port Phillip, has organised what I hope will be a precursor to what many other cities in Australia will be doing: it is forming a joint relationship with the city of Suai, a city which is described in your report. In your remarks earlier you described the total destruction there, the burning down of all of the houses, the wrecking of the solid concrete buildings, and that there was not one person left in Suai when the ADF got there.

Abel Guteress, the representative of the CNRT, was at the joint launch of the Port Phillip-Suai relationship, and I was very proud to see a municipality in my electorate initiating such a joint relationship. I hope that such a joint relationship will be established with a lot of towns in East Timor. I note that when Senators Payne and Bourne went to Suai—they had been there earlier to do the report around the time of the referendum—they said that the TNI-sponsored violence that destroyed Suai had left the entire place, like Dili, almost totally destroyed. They had seen it before the destruction, and they saw it afterwards when they were there with your mission, Mr Deputy Speaker.

Let us remember the vote on 30 August in East Timor. Ninety-eight per cent of registered voters went to the polls and, of those, seventy-eight per cent voted for independence. What a triumph for the democratic spirit that was, that in the difficult circumstances of early last year 98 per cent of the people in that country who were registered to vote voted, and despite the violence 78 per cent of them voted for independence.

I know there are some difficulties with the remarks by the former Prime Minister, Mr Keating, about Indonesia and East Timor and that just this week, the foreign minister has been attempting to score points off the former Prime Minister. I was not in this place when the former Prime Minister was here but I do remember seeing him and the current foreign minister, who was then the Leader of the Opposition. It seems a shame to be very courageous in attacking the former Prime Minister when he is not here. Some people would say that the current foreign minister's courage in attacking Keating is in inverse proportion to the ability of the former Prime Minister to respond in this place and to his presence in the parliament.

The Minister for Defence, Mr Moore, prior to the 30 August referendum, suggested—and so has the government—that the critical issue we should be looking at is the role that the gov-ernment took in demanding that there be a referendum. They argue—and this, in my view, is a simplicity that both the members for Chifley and Throsby addressed—that, if there had not been a referendum, there would be no independence in East Timor. No-one can disagree with that. If we had demanded, they say—as the shadow minister for foreign affairs requested con-tinually through the first half of last year—that there be a UN peacekeeping force, then there would have been no referendum.

I do not think there is such a simplistic equation. The member for Chifley made a very in-teresting point when he focused on the inability of the Minister for Defence to get through to General Wiranto. It is interesting to note that when General Shelton, the Head of the US Joint Chiefs of Staff, eventually spoke to General Wiranto on the phone afterwards he was immedi-ately able to call off the TNI dogs of war and the violence in East Timor ceased almost imme-diately from the time that the head of the American Defense Force contacted General Wi-ranto. In a question on notice to the Minister for Defence, I asked:

quote.para: Since he has held the portfolio and prior to the 30 August 1999 referendum in East Timor had he (a) met with or (b) spoken in 1999 on the telephone to (i) Lt General Shelton, the Chairman of the US Joint Chiefs of Staff, or (ii) William Cohen, the US Secretary of Defense; if so, (A) when and where was or were the meeting or meetings held, (B) where was or were the telephone calls made and (C) are there any notes, memoranda or other documentation concerning the (I) meeting or meetings ...

speech.para: The minister confirmed in his response to me that he had, in fact, spoken to General Shel-ton and Mr Cohen once in the entire period between becoming the minister and the violence in East Timor. I think that once is very significant in its singularity. In my view, the Minister for Defence should have been on the phone to the Americans in that period alerting them to the situation in East Timor. I believe that the Minister for Defence met the US Joint Chief, Gen-eral Shelton, at a public gathering in Washington on 5 May and that he spoke to Secre-tary Cohen at the same time. I believe that there were a number of opportunities that he did not take up in that period mentioned previously by the shadow minister for foreign affairs and the shadow minister for defence, and they should have been taken up. In that historical conun-drum we will find why the Indonesian military thought it could unleash its militia dogs of war.

Much more positive circumstances have happened since then. I want to mention particu-larly the President of Indonesia, the new, democratically elected President Wahid, and his visit to Santa Cruz cemetery accompanied by the leader of the East Timorese people, Xanana Gusmao. That was a great act. It was an act of reconciliation that will perhaps in the future lead to some relationship between the Indonesian and East Timorese people being put on a more sensitive basis than the relationship has been conducted in the past.

We still have some 1,500 Australian troops deployed in East Timor with the UN forces that are there. I note that 150 of them are reservists who have volunteered for full-time service and have undertaken months and months of training to achieve the kind of proficiency that our regular forces have. I can only echo what the member for Throsby and the member for Chi-fley said with regard to the professionalism of our forces. I have not been, as they have, to the various trouble spots in the world to see the ADF, nor have I been to Timor but recently, as the co-patron for the last several months of the Bandiana Safe Haven, which has been admini-stered by the ADF, it has been my pleasure to see the total professionalism with which those very sensitive circumstances have been conducted. If that is their behaviour overseas, then we have everything to be proud of.

I believe Australia will have a presence, perhaps not militarily, in East Timor for a long time. The situation has been calmed down to a great extent by General Cosgrove and INTERFET. It is marvellous what those 9,000 INTERFET troops were able to accomplish, which 25,000 troops in the TNI were not able to. I am sure the Blue Berets of the UN will continue their work, but Australia will have a relationship with East Timor that goes far be-yond our military involvement and deployment there at the moment. The member for Throsby remarked rather ironically on the few people who were interested in the issue of East Timor and were able to be active in this parliament in keeping that issue alive over the last 25 years. Those people of course should be honoured, but I think the issue now has been burnt into the Australian consciousness. I hope the efforts of the municipality in my electorate in Port Phillip will be indicative of the Australian people's attitude to people in East Timor from now on.

talk.start.para: —I am very pleased to participate in this discussion this morning. I was not part of the delegation to which this report entitled A Visit to East Timor, 2 December 1999 refers, but I was in East Timor at about the same time on a trip with the Leader of the Opposition, and I have been there on one other occasion around that time.

speech.para: I think the fact that this parliament has taken such an active role and that the committee was so quick to make itself available, and indeed get the support of the government to take a trip to East Timor so early, is very important. It raises significant issues, as has been pointed out by the various speakers who have made a contribution. But as someone who has been associated with this issue since 1975 and someone who has spoken in this parliament on a number of occasions prior to the East Timorese being given their independence—at least in so far as they no longer have the Indonesian occupying force as an invader—I said that the Australian community owed the East Timorese a debt of honour. That debt of honour originated in the contribution made by the East Timorese to Australia's war effort in the protection of Australian commandos from the 2nd/2nd and 2nd/4th independent companies during 1942 and the early part of 1943. The records are clear about this.

It is asserted that perhaps as many as 40,000 East Timorese died directly or indirectly as a result of the protection of a handful of Australians and there were very few casualties among those. It is therefore with some pleasure that I noted a report very recently in the media in which the East Timorese independence leader, Xanana Gusmao, gave Australia and General Cosgrove, who did such a magnificent job, high praise. He said that Australia had now repaid the historical debt owed to East Timorese soldiers killed by the Japanese in World War II for protecting Australian diggers. I quote, `Peter, you have now repaid the debt and we honour you for that.' I regard that as a very important statement. It is very important for Australia to understand that, as a result of its efforts over the last while, in the minds and eyes of the East Timorese leadership we have been able to settle that debt. I do not believe we have actually settled it in whole but at least in part. The work which has been done by the Australian military in particular, needs our highest commendation and it has been given on a number of occasions by many people in this parliament, including the Prime Minister and the Leader of the Opposition, so I am not going to repeat that praise.

The contribution has been recognised of General Cosgrove and the Australian troops and indeed all of the forces from the United Nations who were involved. As the member for Chifley commented, the troops who are about to move into East Timor from 6RAR will be re-placing the Darwin based 5/7RAR under the control of Lieutenant Colonel Simon Gould. I just want to make the observation that these are troops from my electorate. A large number of them have been involved in East Timor since the United Nations force went in. They have done a magnificent job. I had the fortunate experience to be able to visit Lieutenant Colonel Gould in his headquarters whilst I was in Dili. I had a meal with him and met some of the troops. To me that was very important but really no more important than accepting that, whilst we give appropriate praise to these people who have been doing a very fine job in East Timor, we should also acknowledge the support that is being given to those troops by their fellow armed service personnel in Australia who, unfortunately from their point of view, were not able to share in that experience of being in East Timor, yet were vital to the success of that operation.

I am now talking about the support people who have worked in and around Darwin in particular, whether military or civilian or police or customs, in assisting with the United Nations effort in East Timor. The defence force personnel who have worked their backsides off on an ongoing basis in Darwin in particular, I do not believe have received adequate recognition for the work they have done. I want to place on the public record—and I am sure it would be shared by all members of this parliament—our respect and applause for the very important and dignified way in which they have carried out their duties in supporting our personnel in East Timor.

There is a range of issues which is now confronting us in relation to East Timor and I think those issues need to be recognised. We have an opportunity here, with the assistance of others, to be involved, in a very fortunate and important way, in developing a new nation. We need to acknowledge that it is a difficult task and that the East Timorese have required extreme patience in dealing with the presence of the United Nations and all the non-government organisations who have visited the community since the Indonesians withdrew. It is my belief that the United Nations administration has not been an altogether happy experience for many people. We need to acknowledge that, whilst we see on the surface the fine works that have been done and the words uttered by key personnel within the United Nations administration, a great deal of frustration is being felt by many within the United Nations bureaucracy in East Timor about their inability to be able to deliver services as promptly as the East Timorese would expect. That is something of which we should be very mindful.

It is also important—and I believe it is a very important issue for this parliament and, indeed, for this country—that there ought to be the level of expertise available to the United Nations to carry out their work. It is my humble view—and I might well be wrong—that, in selecting the key leadership personnel to be involved in the United Nations administration, they have not necessarily chosen the right people. I believe that there is a shortage of people with appropriate public policy and public administration experience within the United Nations administration. That has been the cause of a lot of frustration. I have been involved directly in providing assistance in the form of getting gowns and wigs for judges in East Timor and in providing contact for people to provide furniture for these judges so that they can furnish their courts. I would have thought that was pretty pathetic, given the nature and importance of the maintenance of law and order. You would have expected that the United Nations would have moved heaven and earth to ensure that the resources were made available so that these judges and other court officials could be properly kitted out so that they could undertake their functions in an appropriate way. That was not done. That was no fault of the people in charge of that part of the operation in East Timor. It was simply as a result of the failure of the United Nations administration to ensure that funds were made available and that those resources were appropriately allocated so that the work could be properly done.

It is also worth noting that there is a deal of dissatisfaction within elements of the United Nations administration about some of the policies which are being pursued within it. I note a report in the Sydney Morning Herald of 13 March relating to infighting involving senior United Nations staff. It asserts that this is threatening the transition to independence. I believe that is true. I believe that much more needs to be done in terms of auditing the United Nations' performance in East Timor. Indeed, Australians should have a particular interest in that audit function. We need to be concerned that what we understood to be happening in East Timor is in fact happening. I am uncertain, frankly, whether the United Nations administration in East Timor is properly audited or, indeed, how the United Nations administration as a whole in relation to the East Timorese operation—that is, the headquarters in New York and the administration in Dili—is being monitored in terms of evaluating the outcomes of the investment which is being made. I quote from the article in the Sydney Morning Herald of 13 March:

quote.para: The policy dispute has led to the resignation of the UN's head of district administration, who claims “Stalinist” and “colonialist” practises by several senior staff members are jeopardising the UN mission.

speech.para: I know quite a few people who work within the United Nations administration and I have to say that, sadly, that view reflects theirs: there is potential for a real problem. We need to make very clear, through our Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, what we think are accept-able performance criteria for the United Nations. There are very willing people involved in working with the United Nations in East Timor who are keen to facilitate the transition in a way which is acceptable not only to the international community but, most importantly, to the people of East Timor.

I could say a great deal more about that but I will address, briefly, just one very important matter, the role of entrepreneurs who are going into East Timor. We should be very aware that there are a lot of carpetbaggers and spivs who have made it their will and their intention to rip off the East Timorese and the international community, and we have got to be concerned that these people may be given credibility by the Australian media. I have heard a story which is very unsettling to me, that a reputable organisation from Australia went into East Timor in October or November, made an arrangement with a person who occupied a dwelling that they could use that dwelling for administrative purposes and subsequently, through a range of pro-cesses, demolished the dwelling and built a hotel. This was without the approval, I under-stand, of the United Nations, the local administration or the person who owned the property.

It seems to me that, if this sort of practice is happening, we as Australians should be most concerned. I note a report from the Age of 26 February of some words by a leading East Timorese businessman, Oscar Lima, a person whom I know:

quote.para: Oscar Lima says business is welcome, but only in legitimate joint ventures that ensure some profits stay with the Timorese people. Anyone seeking a quick buck need not apply, he says.

“You see, we've heard it before. In the old days the Indonesians said they were going to come here and help the Timorese. In the end they left nothing, they took everything, and left us here to start again from zero. This time we want people who are going to help us, to teach us, to assist us and when they leave us we have something to continue on with.”

speech.para: That should be a fundamental objective. We should be most concerned that any Australian businesses which are seeking to operate in East Timor do so with the highest regard to their obligations to the East Timorese community and to the Australian community. (Time expired)
