talk.start.para: —I rise in the Main Committee today to congratulate the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade on its report A visit to East Timor, 2 December 1999. This very useful report covers a range of issues arising from the INTERFET operation in East Timor and, in particular, the most excellent military deployment led by General Cosgrove. I would like to address just a couple of issues which arise from the report and which are related to it. The first concerns the events leading up to the initial deployment of INTERFET; the second is our current delivery of aid to East Timor, and in that respect I note and support the comments just made by my colleague the member for the Northern Territory; and the third is our aid delivery and broader diplomacy as it relates to the repatriation of the 100,000 East Timorese still resident in refugee camps in West Timor.

speech.para: On the first of these questions, which is the events leading up to the INTERFET deployment last September, I noted carefully and support entirely the comments made by my colleague the member for Chifley on this point earlier in this debate. There was no failure of intelligence, as far as the Australian intelligence community is concerned, about a probable range of scenarios which could have ensued after the conduct of the ballot on East Timorese independence on 30 August 1999. What we do not know, however, is the nature of the analy-sis made by the Australian policy community in response to that intelligence, nor do we know precisely, in all the detail, the arguments underpinning the precise nature of the government's response to the analysis thus delivered.

I am not privy to the intelligence traffic, I am not privy to the policy analysis undertaken, nor am I privy to the ultimate policy advice provided to the government and the basis for it. I have, however, worked in this sphere for many years in a previous incarnation. I would simply observe, as an external analyst of those events, that it was an entirely credible scenario that, in the event of the East Timorese voting decisively for an independence outcome on 30 August last year, there would be an adverse reaction by pro-Indonesian militia and that that could or would have been supported by the regular armed forces of the Republic of Indonesia, TNI. It was not necessarily the case that that would have been the only scenario but, using the tools of credible policy and intelligence analysis, it was a credible scenario which could have ensued.

The government's policy response to the intelligence that it was receiving seems, to the external observer, to have been one which was primarily driven by hope over analysis; a hope that things would turn out in the end; a hope that, if there was a strong and decisive vote for independence on 30 August, the Indonesian government of the time, exercising command and control, as it hoped, over the Indonesian armed forces at the time, would have accepted the outcome of the verdict and simply packed up and gone home. As we know from the events which did ensue, that did not occur.

The argument which I wish to advance today is simply what could have occurred and should have occurred in the immediate weeks prior to 30 August last year and immediately subsequent to it. I refer to the specific diplomatic challenge which existed at that time—given there was a credible scenario that things would go radically wrong after 30 August in terms of the maintenance of security within Dili and elsewhere in East Timor—on the negotiation of heads of agreement of a prospective and possible multinational force for immediate deployment to East Timor should that scenario have unfolded.

As I said before, the government seems to have operated at the time on the assumption that it would all work out in the end. When it unfolded that it did not work out in the end, the previous policy position of hope over analysis seems to have yielded to one of panic over analysis, because what then unfolded was the unsightly public performance of a prime minister and a foreign minister publicly negotiating with the President of the United States and the Secretary of State of the United States about when, if and in what form the United States would participate in any military deployment in East Timor. The member for Melbourne Ports, who spoke earlier in this debate, made similar observations, which I would support. There was a mad scramble to cobble together—

para.inline: A division having occurred in the House of Representatives—
Sitting suspended from 12.24 p.m. to 12.50 p.m.

talk.start.para: —When events turned sour on the ground in Dili and in other parts of East Timor immediately after the independence ballot on 30 August last year, there was not an orderly policy response from the government to what was previously quite a conceivable scenario. What we saw, in fact, was a mad scramble to try to cobble together two things: at the diplomatic level, a coalition at the United Nations in order to obtain the necessary mandate to underpin any subsequent deployment of an international force; and, secondly and simultaneously, a credible multinational force capable of giving execution to such a mandate.

speech.para: As I said before, we saw the public manifestation of all this when the Prime Minister and the foreign minister became engaged in a public debate with representatives of the US administration on the extent of US participation in such a multinational force. In fact, this was handled in such a manner that it led to something approaching an Australian public opinion confidence crisis in the ultimate underpinnings of the alliance. We had been taught for gen-erations in this country that if we were part of the ANZUS alliance and Australia found itself in difficulty, under the terms and spirit of the treaty, military assistance from the United States could comfortably be relied upon. Short of the formal terms and operational clauses of the treaty, the treaty had nonetheless provided a framework within which such consultations could occur over a long period of time.

The disturbing thing from the analytical community's perspective is: what substantively did the government, prior to the events of 30 August and the two weeks subsequent to it, do in their highest level diplomatic communications with the administration in Washington? The Prime Minister, not long before then, had visited Washington and met with President Clinton. We presume that the foreign minister, Mr Downer, had met on a number of occasions with his US counterpart. We presume also that there had been some contact between the Australian defence minister, Mr Moore, and his American contact. What we know as an empirical fact is that by the time we got to the first week after 30 August last year, when all of Australia could see on their television sets that the security situation in East Timor was falling apart at the seams, the plain reality was that we had no heads of agreement for any level of military coop-eration with the United States, nor any public statement from them in terms of the extent that they were willing to participate in such a force. Things became so desperate that we had pub-lic beratings of President Clinton by the Australian Prime Minister as the Australian public and community reaction became more intense.

As I said in my earlier remarks, I, as a member of the opposition, was not privy to any of the diplomatic communications which occurred at this time, nor to the precise content of the intelligence despatches which would have been delivered to the government here in Canberra, as well as, I presume, in part if not in whole, shared with the US administration in Washing-ton. However, at about that time I actually had the chance to meet with the chairman of the US House Subcommittee on Asia and Pacific Affairs, which is a subcommittee of the House Foreign Relations Committee of the US Congress. I had extensive discussions with him in Sydney and some later discussions with him here in Canberra. This was just prior to the events of 30 August. The discussion was about possible US participation in such a force should the scenario which I referred to earlier in my address to the Main Committee today actually come to pass. Very interestingly, the congressman's response to me was that there was zero possibility of the United States participating in an up-front military involvement with Australia. There would be some capacity for the United States, he told me at that stage, to participate in the provision of heavy lift capacity in order to deliver international troops to East Timor as well as broader support in communications and intelligence. However, the proposition that there would be American foot soldiers landing on the equivalent of Omaha Beach with Australian diggers in the deployment of an INTERFET force was not on the radar screen of possibilities.

I would submit that the chairman of the relevant US house subcommittee on this matter was in a position of reasonable authority to speak on these questions. His reasons were simply that this was our theatre of engagement and the US was more than happy to play a support role but not a direct role. That conversation occurred just prior to 30 August, yet for the two weeks subsequent to 30 August we had the Prime Minister and the foreign minister engaged in this extraordinary public diplomacy, the implication and often stated assumption of which was that a credible US deployment would only consist of troops on the ground.

The consequence of this was that we had, for a period in excess of a week, coming out of the Prime Minister's management of this diplomacy, a substantial public questioning in Aus-tralia of the continued relevance of this alliance. What the Australian public were not aware of was that at a substantive level the US was never going to commit to troops on the ground, whatever the public rhetoric of the Australian government may have been at the time. I be-lieve the Australian government should have brought the Australian community into the picture, there and then, that this was not a prospect. But instead we had some damage done to public standing of the alliance. This is not a view held uniquely by me; it is a view held by others, who have professional custodianship for the US-Australia bilateral relationship.

There was a second consequence of the failure on Australia's part, at a private diplomatic level prior to the events of 30 August, to have a heads of agreement as to precisely what would constitute the elements of a force in being. That consequence was that what General Wiranto and others saw on their television screens from Jakarta was a weak and divided rabble which was the broader international community of nations' response to the unfolding security scenario on the streets of Dili and elsewhere in East Timor. We can safely conclude that when General Wiranto saw one thing—weakness, and a lack of resolve and of unity on the part of the countries which were interested in possibly participating in such a force—Wiranto's response on that basis was that TNI, supporting the militia, could afford to continue the sorts of tactics which they were then adopting and which, as we know, were highly destructive, in terms not just of the civilian population but also of the public infrastructure of Indonesia.

We know also that the only time at which Wiranto and others finally took heed of the international community's reaction and acceded, through the Indonesian government, to the deployment of an international force under a UN mandate, was when the US administration got on the telephone to him and told him the game was up. My simple thesis, as it relates to those critical events at that critical time juncture, is this: there was a failure of Australian diplomacy. Those sorts of communications should have been held on the basis of credible scenario planning well prior to 30 August—even two weeks prior to 30 August would have been sufficient—so that, if that scenario unfolded in the first week of September, as subsequently proved to be the case, then both the negotiations with the Americans on the composition of a military force and the appropriate statements to be made by the US administration to Indonesia would have been secured, and we would probably not have seen the level of destruction and loss of life that we saw in the period which followed.

We have seen in the House of Representatives this week some extraordinary performances by the foreign minister, criticising former Prime Minister Keating and others associated with his administration in terms of their knowledge of Asia. I would simply suggest that we would have faced a much greater crisis in our diplomacy in the region, and in relation to East Timor, had the minister's diplomacy not been masked to some extent by the professionalism of his department and the professionalism of General Cosgrove on the ground. (Time expired)
Debate (on motion by Mr Neville) adjourned.

debate.para: The following answers to questions were circulated:

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Health and Aged Care, upon notice, on 26 August 1999:

quote.para: (1) Will he provide details on the level and effectiveness of Government programs since 1996 designed to deal with hearing impairment within the indigenous community.
(2) What funds have been allocated to hearing services since 1996, and what proportion of those funds was used to service the needs of the indigenous community.
(3) What proportion of funding for hearing services was used in programs to prevent hearing impairment in Aboriginal children.
(4) Will he provide details of hearing impairment programs to prevent the onset of hearing impairment for indigenous children.
(5) Is he able to say how long it will be before it will be possible to provide preventative medicine for all newborn indigenous children so that they do not contract hearing impairment diseases.
(6) Are future programs proposed to eradicate all acquired hearing impairment from the indigenous communities; if so, what are the details.

talker.name: Wooldridge, Dr Michael, MP
Dr Wooldridge
talker.role: Minister for Health and Aged Care

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) The Government's approach to hearing impairment within Indigenous communities is based on recognising the importance of primary health care in preventing ear diseases which may lead to hearing loss, and the provision of hearing services to assist where hearing impairment has occurred.
General Primary Health Focus

The Department of Health and Aged Care has developed a comprehensive long-term strategic framework for improving Indigenous health. Implicit in this framework is the recognition that there are no easy or quick solutions in the area of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander health. The strategy has four main components:
- Developing the infrastructure and resources necessary to achieve comprehensive and effective primary health care for Indigenous peoples;
- Addressing some of the specific health issues and risk factors affecting the health status of Indigenous peoples;
- Improving the evidence base which underpins the health interventions; and
- Improving communication with primary health care services, Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples and the general population.
Achievement of the first component is primarily through the funding and development of a national network of Aboriginal Community Controlled Health Organisations.

As the Aboriginal Community Controlled Health Organisations provide comprehensive primary health care, it is not possible to report on the extent to which resources in any service are specifically committed towards the prevention, identification and treatment of hearing impairment among Indigenous people.

The Commonwealth has increased the level of funding provided through the Office of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Health from $130.6m in 1996/97 to $155.2m in 1998/99 with a further increase announced in the May 1999 budget of approximately $100m over the next four years.
Hearing Strategy

Building on the national network of Aboriginal Community Controlled Health Organisations and in response to recommended goals of the National Aboriginal Health Strategy (1989), the Minister in December 1996 approved implementation of the National Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Hearing Strategy 1995/96 - 1998/1999.

The aim is to provide a strategic approach to improving Indigenous hearing health by targeting children 0-5 years through primary health care organisations, with a focus on hearing and broader child health services. The strategy consists of four main elements:

Child Hearing Health Sites : 30Aboriginal Community Controlled Health Organisations were identified as the Child Hearing Health Sites to incorporate hearing screening and treatment into a comprehensive 0-5 year old child health program. Specialist hearing health workers have been employed in some centres to improve coordination and continuity of care between health care and education sectors at the regional level.

Equipment and Training : An audiometric equipment and two-stage training program is being provided to Aboriginal Community Controlled Health Organisations funded by the Office of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Health (OATSIH). The equipment and training program is delivered by Australian Hearing Services through a MOU with OATSIH.
- Since 1996, 466 Aboriginal Health Workers have participated in hearing health training, with 191 Aboriginal Health Workers having completed both stages of the training program;
- To date, 95 sets of audiometric equipment have been issued to Aboriginal Community Controlled Health Organisations together with an ongoing equipment maintenance and calibration regime.

Capital Infrastructure Program : Soundproof testing facilities have been provided in 15 Aboriginal Community Controlled Health Organisations (with a further 14 awaiting completion) to improve access to community based specialist hearing testing facilities.

Strategic Research : The Office of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Health in conjunction with the National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC) and the Aboriginal community controlled health sector, have undertaken a process to identify agreed best practice evidence based protocols for secondary and tertiary treatment for hearing impairment. This has provided a framework for a more strategic approach to hearing health research which reflects the importance of otitis media and hearing impairment as a key health issue in Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander children. In addition, this shifts the historical focus from medical and epidemiological issues to service delivery and action-oriented research. Two projects in this area have recently been funded through the NHMRC.

An evaluation of the hearing services to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people, involving the Office of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Health and the Office of Hearing Services will be conducted this financial year.

(2) As indicated above, it is not possible to identify, from the funding provided to Aboriginal Community Controlled Health Organisations, the proportion going towards Indigenous hearing activities specifically. These services adopt a holistic approach to primary health care of which hearing health is but one component.
The 1995/96 Federal Budget allocated $5.7m over four years for the specific Hearing Strategy described above for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander children.

Australian Hearing Services (the public hearing services provider) is funded to provide a range of services as `community service obligations' (CSOs). Last financial year total funding for `community service obligations' was $26m. The funding is for the provision of hearing services to Australian young adults and children up to 21 years of age; eligible adults with special needs or living in remote areas; eligible Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples; and for research.

It is estimated that 2728 Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people received services from Australian Hearing Services in 1998-99 through the CSO funding. In addition, about 100 applicants (out of a total of 130,000 applications for a Hearing Services Voucher received by the Office of Hearing Services) identified as Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander adults and received hearing services through the Voucher System. These numbers are almost certainly an underestimate because they are derived from self-identification by the client on the Voucher Application Form.

(3) As already noted, Australian Hearing Services is funded to provide a range of functions that together are called `community service obligations'. Last financial year total funding for `community service obligations' was $26m. The Government currently does not specify how the funding is to be broken down against these groups, but expenditure on all children (including Indigenous people) was approximately $17m in 1998-99.

(4) Australian Hearing Services has a full-time National Indigenous Services Manager. In each State and Territory there is a senior audiologist who is the Australian Hearing Services Indigenous Programs Co-ordinator. Each Australian Hearing Services Hearing Centre has a designated Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander contact officer. All of these people work closely with local Indigenous community organisations and individuals.

Australian Hearing Services works collaboratively with various government and non-government agencies who are also involved in the provision of services to Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders. An example of this would be the Australian Hearing Services program of assistance to the Tiwi people on Bathurst Island, where they work closely with the Menzies School of Hearing Research and the Northern Territory Health Department.
During 1998-99 Australian Hearing Services audiologists made a total of 260 visits to 97 Indigenous communities and sites. Many of these visits were for a period of up to one week.

Specialist audiologists who deal with these children are able to relate to and work with Indigenous individuals and communities, and to have a thorough knowledge of otitis media and its sequelae, especially as it affects Indigenous children. Services are delivered to Indigenous Australians either in a Hearing Centre, or through an extensive outreach program. There is emphasis on working with the family and community to get the best outcomes. Ongoing arrangements for outreach services are negotiated with the community, taking into account the numbers of new and on-going clients who require services, and the level of support required by Aboriginal Health Workers and teachers. Australian Hearing Services also provides appropriate individual and classroom amplification devices.

(5) Essentially there is no medicine to absolutely prevent hearing impairment diseases which are the result of the interaction of a complex number of factors. Factors including inadequate accommodation, overcrowding and limited access to clean water, contribute to high rates of cross-infection. Poor diets also place the population at risk because of lower immunity to infection.

(6) In addition to the above, in October 1998 the Government, recognising the need for further research in this area of hearing health for Indigenous people, called for expressions of interest to conduct research into the priority areas identified as primary prevention, secondary prevention, social and behavioural factors and surgical issues. The criteria used in the selection process included, in addition to scientific merit and relevance to the objectives of the program, three others specifically identified as relevant to research in Indigenous health. These were the transferability and sustainability of the research and the level of community participation.
The two projects recently approved for NHMRC funding include a focus on the major priority areas identified for research including surgical and social/behavioural issues.

The first project at $178,840 to be administered by the Kimberley Public Health Unit is to conduct a two-year scientific project; “Evaluation of tympanoplasty in Aboriginal children in WA and factors associated with successful outcome”. The project will evaluate the outcome of operations done to repair ear drums in Aboriginal children and identify factors associated with a successful outcome. The second project at $153,458 to be administered by TVW Telethon Institute of Child Health Research is to conduct a two-year scientific project; “Socioeconomic risk factors and treatment-seeking behaviour for otitis media in the Aboriginal population of Kalgoorlie-Boulder region.”The project will investigate socioeconomic factors predisposing to ear infections and their effect on compliance with treatment in Indigenous populations of the Kalgoorlie-Boulder region.

talk.start.para: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 6 December 1999:

quote.para: (1) How many aged persons does the Government estimate will qualify for the Aged Persons Saving Bonus component under subsection 12(1) the A New Tax System (Bonuses for Older Australians) Act.
(2) How many qualifying persons does the Government expect will receive less than $500 under the scheme.
(3) How many aged pensioners does the Government expect will receive no bonus at all.

(4) How many self-funded retirees does the Government estimate will be eligible to receive the Self-Funded Retirees Supplementary Bonus component pursuant to subsection 12(2) of the A New Tax System (Bonuses for Older Australians) Act.
(5) How many qualifying self-funded retirees does the Government estimate will receive less than $500 under the scheme.
(6) How many self-funded retirees does the Government expect will receive nothing at all.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (3) This will be known once the final number of claimants is known.

(4) and (5) Subsection 12(2) refers to Family and Community Services customers of aged pension age, who are neither in the tax nor social security system. Between 15,000 and 20,000 of such persons are estimated to receive the Self-Funded Retirees Supplementary Bonus. Of these, few are expected to receive less than $500 of the Self-Funded Retirees Supplementary Bonus, as they are expected to have savings and investment income and spouse income high enough so as to make them ineligible for the pension.

(6) The Department of Treasury does not hold income information for the entire Australian population of self-funded retirees. As such, it is unable to reliably estimate the number of self-funded retirees who will receive no bonus at all.

subdebateinfo.title: Coal Industry: Face Emplaced Services Support Device
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1206)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industry, Science and Resources, upon notice, on 6 March 2000:

quote.para: (1) Has the Minister's attention been drawn to an invention called a Face Emplaced Services Support device, designed for use in the underground coal mining industry (Patent Application Number PCT/AU92/00555 and PCT/AU95/00038).
(2) If so, who (a) has owned the intellectual property and (b) is the current owner.
(3) Are any Australian and international companies involved in underground mining using the Face Emplaced Services Support device; if so, which companies.
(4) What is the estimated value of the intellectual property to Australia.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Industry, Science and Resources has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

quote.para: (1) Yes.
(2) IP Australia's records indicate that the ownership details are as follows:
PCT/AU92/00555 Patentees: John Edwin Pink
(Patent No.668524) Brian Lesley Joseph Buffier; Barbara Joan O'Brien
PCT/AU95/00038 Applicants: John Edwin Pink; Barbara Joan O'Brien
According to IP Australia's records, both the patent and the application have lapsed.

(3) There are a large number of Australian and international companies involved in underground mining. My Department does not have details of the particular types of technology all these companies are using.

(4) The Government is not in a position to determine the value of this intellectual property. This is a matter determined by the market, and is dependent on many factors. Success in the marketplace is the ultimate test of the commercial worth of an invention.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, upon notice, on 16 March 2000:

quote.para: (1) Have mobile phone complaints increased by 42% nation-wide in the last twelve months.
(2) Do the majority of complaints relating to mobile phones relate to users not being made aware of the terms and conditions of the contracts they have entered into.
(3) What action is the Government taking to ensure that users are aware of the terms and conditions of their contracts.

talker.name: McGauran, Peter, MP
Mr McGauran
talker.role: Minister for the Arts and the Centenary of Federation

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

quote.para: The Government does not have data on the total number of complaints about mobile phone contracts and therefore cannot confirm whether complaints have increased by 42%. The Government would expect that most complaints would be made directly to the telephone company. Complaints may also be made to the Telecommunications Industry Ombudsman (TIO), the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC), and various State and Territory courts and tribunals such as the New South Wales Office for Fair Trading.

As the Government is not a party to complaints made to telephone companies, the TIO, the ACCC or State and Territory agencies it is unable to confirm whether the majority of complaints regarding contracts relate to users not being made aware of the terms and conditions.

The Department of Communications, Information Technology and the Arts sought input from the TIO and the ACCC regarding complaints related to mobile telephones, and in particular complaints relating to contracts.

The Telecommunications Industry Ombudsman (TIO), the body responsible for handling complaints about mobile phones that are not resolved by the telephone company, has supplied the Department of Communications, Information Technology and the Arts with a breakdown of mobile telephone complaints received by them over the last two years:
. In the period 1 March 1998 to 28 February 1999 4,782 complaints about mobile telephone services were received by the TIO; and
. For the period 1 March 1999 to 29 February 2000 the total number of complaints rose by 22% to 6,150:

. Over this period the proportion of complaints related to mobile telephone contracts remained steady at around 63% of all complaints to the TIO. This suggests the increase in complaints to the TIO is probably due to a greater awareness by consumers of the TIO scheme, and not due to increasing problems with mobile contracts.

The ACCC has informed the Department of Communications, Information Technology and the Arts that it received 241 complaints regarding mobile telephones for the period 1 March 1998 to 1 March 1999. In the period 1March 1999 to 1 March 2000 the total number of complaints received by the ACCC increased by 13% to 278. The ACCC is not able to say how many of these complaints related to contracts.
There are a number of existing safeguards to protect consumers from unfair or misleading contracts:

. The Australian Communications Authority (ACA) has made a requirement that all telephone services, including mobile telephone services, that are supplied under a standard form of agreement must be accompanied by a plain language statement outlining the terms and conditions of the agreement.
- At present mobile telephones that are supplied on individual contracts do not have to be accompanied by such a statement.
. General rights under the Trade Practices Act 1974 (TPA). The TPA is administered by the ACCC.
. Access to the TIO scheme.
. Industry codes of practice developed by the telecommunications industry's self-regulatory body: the Australian Communications Industry Forum (ACIF).

In September 1999 the Communications Law Centre (CLC) released a report into the usage of mobile phones by young people. This work, which was funded jointly by the Commonwealth Government and the Victorian Consumer Credit Fund, found that a large number of young consumers did not fully understand the individual contracts that they were asked to sign. The CLC report recommended that:
. All mobile phone contracts should be accompanied by a plain language statement explaining the terms and conditions of the agreement; and
. The Australian Communications Industry Forum (ACIF), the telecommunications industry's self-regulatory body, should develop an industry code of practice that:
- Incorporates the plain language statement explaining the terms and conditions of the agreement; and
- Includes a cooling off period, and guidelines allowing consumers to change mobile plans without penalty, other than the reasonable costs of effecting the transfer.

The Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts subsequently wrote to the Chief Executive Officer of ACIF on 21 January 2000 to draw its attention to the findings of the CLC report.

The Government believes that ACIF, as the telecommunications industry self-regulatory authority, is the appropriate organisation to develop a code of practice for mobile telephone contracts. If ACIF chose not to develop a code of practice for mobile telephone services the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts may issue a Direction to the Australian Communications Authority to develop a compulsory code of practice that all telephone companies must adhere to.
